LEAD: THANKS to a change in state law three years ago, restaurants and bars are now allowed to make and sell their own beer, thus providing visitors with the perfect antidote to the often blistering effects of the sun.

LEAD: GLASS was made in Bohemia, the northern region of Czechoslovakia, as far back as the time that the country was inhabited by Celts. Later, in the 8th and 10th centuries, glassmaking flourished in what was then called the Great Moravian Empire.
LEAD: SEXING THE CHERRY By Jeanette Winterson. 167 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $19.95.

LEAD: Bella Spewack, co-author with her late husband, Samuel, of a string of wacky comedies for Broadway and film - including such hits as ''Boy Meets Girl'' and the Tony Award-winning ''Kiss Me, Kate'' - died Friday night at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old.
LEAD: A shortage of professors and a growing number of students is leading the University of Chicago to suspend a program started after Watergate called Politics, Economics, Rhetoric and Law.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Virginia Field Reiland Webster, a daughter of Deborah de Land Sendax of New York and Thomas Clarkson Hunter Webster of St. Thomas, Pa., was married yesterday to Christophe Genin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michel Bernard Genin of Paris. The Very Rev. Arnold E. Mintz officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr,

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: THE rare visitor to Tibet can still see the Potala, the 1,000-room palace overlooking the capital of Lhasa, but something vital will be missing. For the heart of Tibet has been transplanted to the tiny hill town of Dharmsala in the foothills of the Indian Himalayas. It is here that a 54-year-old monk named Tenzin Gyatso (also known as the 14th Dalai Lama, winner of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize and Tibet's spiritual and temporal leader) makes his home.

LEAD: It shouldn't surprise me that Nelson Algren, clearly one of the best novelists of his time, is not much read these days. It's the ''kill the messenger'' syndrome, I suppose, for the news that Algren's works brings us is not good news: if the world he describes is at all like our own, then it's not morning in America, and it hasn't been for a long, long time.
LEAD: A DESERTED island in Long Island Sound just off the New Rochelle coastline is the focus of a bitter dispute over a proposal to build a $1 billion residential community for 3,700 people.
LEAD: OUR COUNTRY The Shaping of America From Roosevelt to Reagan. By Michael Barone. 805 pp. New York: The Free Press. $29.95.

LEAD: AS reports circulated late last year that the Bush Administration was planning to cut back support for high-technology programs, Andrew S. Grove, president of the Intel Corporation, the Silicon Valley computer chip maker, sent a violin to Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director. ''If what I hear is true,'' Dr.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

LEAD: When some 50,000 Haitian-Americans marched in protest across the Brooklyn Bridge recently, their complaint was arcane - the Government won't accept their blood. But it's a deeply felt issue. It pits their understandable fear of being stigmatized against a slight extra chance of contaminating the blood supply with the AI

LEAD: Q. I am trying to fasten a fairly large hook to a hollow-core door. I have tried plastic anchors and plastic toggles, and in both cases they loosened because the plywood or veneer covering the hollow core is quite thin and not very firm. Any suggestions?

LEAD: June wedding plans for Karen Louise Peterson and Gerald Louis Sauer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Sauer of St. Louis, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Peterson of Kailua, Hawaii.

LEAD: The Stanley Congregational Church in Chatham, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Nancy Ellen Dunn, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Dunn of Summit, N.J., and Steven Bryan Grune, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Grune of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Gilbert Harttree performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Colleen M. Horan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Horan of Bethpage, L.I., was married there yesterday to Anthony P. Sofronas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Sofronas of Little Silver, N.J. The Rev. Patrick Hanley officiated at St. Martin of Tours Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Sofronas, 26 years old, graduated from Villanova University and is an analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York.

LEAD: Because of a plan change by the publishers, a review of ''Landscapes of a New Land: Fiction by Latin American Women'' in The Times Book Review today misstates the book's format. It is available from White Pine Press in paperback only.

LEAD: The anniversary of Portugal's 1974 revolution is still marked as a public holiday here each year, but nowadays April 25 is more of an occasion for escaping to the beach or the countryside than for banner-waving at political demonstrations.

LEAD: There are connoisseurs of choruses for whom the name of David Willcocks is still inseparable from the famed King's College Choir of England's Cambridge University. Never mind that Mr. Willcocks - Sir David, since 1977 - gave up conducting the Cambridge choir as long ago as 1974; that he spent a distinguished decade at the helm of London's Royal College of Music; that he's had parallel careers as music director of London's Bach

LEAD: Jane H. Choremi and Walter G. Roll were married yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Resurrection in Glen Cove, L.I. The Rev. Emmanuel J. Gratsias officiated. Mrs. Roll, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alec M. Choremi of Glen Head, L.I., graduated from the Foxcroft School and Wheaton College.

LEAD: NOT LONG AGO, A MIDDLE-AGED friend with a bit of a bohemian streak stopped sleeping on a mattress on the floor and bought a regular bed. The reason: when he woke up in the morning his stiff and creaky joints had begun to make it difficult for him to get up off the floor. Now sleeping in a normal bed gave him a 20-inch head start.

LEAD: Hundreds of families returned to their town in the Christian heartland northeast of here today, but they were given only 36 hours to inspect their houses, which have been demolished in three months of fighting between Christian army troops and rival militiamen.
LEAD: Most of his 35 Indy-car victories have long since been forgotten, and much of his prize money has long since been spent, but the way Bobby Unser sees it, he is now assured of perpetual renown.
LEAD: A BID by the Kent Water Company to raise its rates is raising the ire of many of its customers.

LEAD: As far as Chuck Crim could recall, the only time he had ever been ejected from a game was during his college days in Hawaii. ''And I didn't even say it,'' the Milwaukee relief pitcher said. ''It was the guy behind me.''

LEAD: The hatters of the ancient Andes were artisans of great sophistication, flair and a genius for weaving. The remarkably expressive caps they wove - the corners embellished with tassels or peaks - were worn by warriors as status symbols from the 4th to the 10th centuries in Peru, Bolivia and Chile, and were interred with their owners at death.
LEAD: THE SHATTERED BLOC Behind the Upheaval in Eastern Europe. By Elie Abel. 278 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $20.95.
LEAD: Long after the speeches are over and the grounds are swept up, it is the number of those who turn out for today's anti-abortion rally that will be remembered.

LEAD: Judith Ann Goodfarb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Goodfarb of Ardsley, N.Y., was married last evening to Marc Chamlin, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Chamlin of Yardley, Pa.Rabbi Albert L. Sturmer officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.
LEAD: In Utopia, athletes do not get paid for spending their off days signing thousands of autographs, copies of The New York Times are free, and hospitals don't charge for their services.
LEAD: THE basic law of Nicaraguan politics has always been clear: the winner takes all.

LEAD: AFTER THE PLANE TOUCHED DOWN AT CLEVELAND HOPKINS Airport, six young black athletes straightened their blue-and-gold team parkas and started toward the baggage claim area. As they strode through the corridor with their parents and coach, a black woman squinted from behind the Avis counter at the ''PDR Swimming'' insignia on their backs and hustled out to catch them.

LEAD: Jules MasseneT (1842-1912) created music in the mainstream of French opera that ranged over three centuries from Lully to Poulenc. Hector Berlioz (1803-1869) was a Frenchman who nonetheless managed to keep outside that mainstream. Christoph Willibald Gluck (1714-1787) was a German cosmopolitan who worked in Paris for pleasure and profit.

LEAD: As Eastern Europe struggles toward democracy, it must also grapple with a ravaged environment. Corrosive soot has fouled water and soil, and in blackened industrial cities the air is laced with heavy metals and chemicals. In a world ruled by production targets, there was no pressure to clean up.

LEAD: In the 19th century, rulers of one country often sought to impress the rulers of another with some rare and exotic gift. Occasionally, the gifts were coins. The King of Siam presentation set of rare United States coins donated to the Asian monarch by the United States in 1836 is one example.

LEAD: It is an enormous pleasure for those of us who have argued against the lousy way we grow food to find articles like ''America Tackles the Pesticide Crisis'' (October 8, 1989), by Susan Gilbert. For the Federal Government to publish reports saying that the agri-chemical ways not only poison us, but aren't effective or cost-efficient, is a cause for great wonder among people who have been saying that for decades.

LEAD: A RESPECTED West German newspaper publisher recently tried to convince an American visitor that foreigners were making far too much of German unification. East Germany was only the size of a large West German state, he said, so its absorption could hardly increase Germany's size or power all that much.

LEAD: The balloon over Robin's head in the latest products from the Bowe Industries factory in Middle Village, Queens, might carry the words: ''Holy logo, Batman, we're staying in New York!'' Indeed, after considering a move to the South, the owners of Bowe will remain in New York and expand their T-shirt factory as a result of a $4.1 million bond financing arranged by the city's Industrial Development

LEAD: The more I read articles such as Carin Rubenstein's ''The Baby Bomb'' (October 8), and the more I try to analyze why my own 19-year marriage (producing four wonderful children) failed, the more I conclude that perhaps one of the most frequent reasons for disintegrating marriages, particularly those with children, is this: we enter marriage and parenting with unrealistic expectations of ourselves, our spouses and our children.

LEAD: Matilda Cuomo's timely article, ''Taking Aim at a Preventable Tragedy'' (April 8) alerts all women to the benefits, indeed urgency, of the early detection of breast cancer and to the more than 90 percent survival rate if this deadly disease is diagnosed early enough.
LEAD: IN THE ARENA A Memoir of Victory, Defeat, and Renewal. By Richard Nixon. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

LEAD: A searchlight from the pickup truck scanned the darkened field near the St. Helena gold mine until it fixed on a couple lying in the long grass. The night patrol lurched to a halt. Several armed men in khaki uniforms jumped out.

LEAD: TO a reviewer emerging from Manhattan, the Noyes Museum, 100 or more miles away, seems ideally suited to its present show about locomotion. ''Trains and Planes'' this is called, and though a few of its images are drawn from the Herndon Collection of early to mid-20th century art, most date from the 1980's.

LEAD: Aural privacy has its points. With earphones, you keep the music all to yourself. Not that you're esthetically stingy and unwilling to share your pleasures. It's just that not everyone else in the house may be in the mood for the Appassionata.

LEAD: The Faculty Senate at the University of Connecticut at Storrs narrowly defeated a proposal last week that would have allowed time spent finishing Ph.D.'s to be counted as time that must be worked before tenure is considered.
LEAD: For George Holz, fashion photographer, form does not always follow function.

LEAD: The engagement of Marcy Anne Berg to Michael Weinsier, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Weinsier of Kings Point, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. F. Steven Berg of Buffalo. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: There was a chill wind off the Potomac and the rain fell in sheets on the cherry trees, but inside her office Zelda Fichandler, who had just announced her retirement after 40 years as producing director of Washington's Arena Stage, was cheerfully reflective.
LEAD: REPRESENTATIVE WILLIAM J. CIBES Jr., co-chairman of the General Assembly's tax writing committee and a Democratic candidate for governor, says the end is near for Connecticut's tax system.
LEAD: SOMETIMES these days they are called au pairs. More often they are still referred to as nannies. But except for rainy weather, they don't come with umbrellas.

LEAD: For the last 11 years, the anniversary of the Marxist coup here on April 27, 1978, has been celebrated by a mass parade of troops and tanks. But this year President Najibullah canceled the parade and marked the anniversary at a 20-minute ceremony, held 36 hours early, in a bunker near his palace.

LEAD: Not only does Britain have the oldest continuous music festival - the 263-year-old Three Choirs Festival, held this year in Worcester - but it also seems to offer more music festivals, excluding folk festivals, than any other country: more than 40.
LEAD: NOW I know what I should have said. But when the woman approached me, I was too busy studying the barbecued chickens.

LEAD: Sarah Elizabeth Krauss Bosch, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Paul F. Bosch of Waterloo, Ontario, was married yesterday to Warren Buckley Bischoff, a son of Nancy K. Bischoff of New York and Richard T. Bischoff of Jupiter, Fla. The bride's father officiated at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in New York.

LEAD: Lauren Sue Aaron, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Aaron of Roslyn, L.I., was married in New York last evening to Barry Alan Fishbach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Fishbach of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi James Prosnit performed the ceremony at Temple Rodeph Sholom. A cum laude graduate of Lehigh University, the bride, who is 26 years old, is the promotion manager for the Thomas Regional Directory publishing company in New York.
LEAD: Despite the Pete Rose tax business, I am indifferent.

LEAD: The defending champion Detroit Pistons took a two-games-to-none lead this afternoon in their first-round National Basketball Association playoff series with the Indiana Pacers as Isiah Thomas and Bill Laimbeer took charge down the stretch for a 100-87 victory.

LEAD: IF you can obtain tickets - and hotel reservations within an hour's drive - a pilgrimage to a big, glamorous European music festival can be a delightful experience. But festivals have proliferated in recent decades, and the most rewarding are not necessarily the most famous. Going to a less fashionable festival may be easier (or may not be: some are already sold out for this year) and may be just as musically enjoyable.

LEAD: Schedule listings in the Television section today for Wednesday evening and Thursday evening carry erroneous entries supplied by Channel 5 for 8 P.M. The film ''Trading Places'' will be shown on Wednesday at 8 and ''All of Me'' on Thursday at 8.

LEAD: SEVEN years after the state took over the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, it still has no long-range artistic mission - and no short-range schedule of performances. The managers of the American Festival Theater, as its is now known, are struggling to assemble a brief summer season. But they say they are trying to avoid the problems they encountered last summer, when they hastily reopened the theater for six weeks.

LEAD: Not every customer of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Michael R. Milken, has been jumping for joy at the latter's recent guilty plea in Federal Court. We have all read the articles that called Mr. Milken and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. criminals. Well, if it's a crime to donate tens of thousands of dollars to rescue a company from bankruptcy and save hundreds of jobs, maybe Congress ought to take another look at the law.

LEAD: Claire Elizabeth Turner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Turner of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary to Michael Schlesier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond H. Schlesier of Seaford, L.I. The Rev. James P. Swiader officiated.
LEAD: Thomas Hearns retained his World Boxing Organization super middleweight title when he won a unanimous 12-round decision over Michael Olajide Jr. at the Taj Mahal here.

LEAD: CLASSICAL Beethoven: Mass in C (Op. 86), 'Calm Sea and Prosperous Voyage' (Op. 112) Audrey Michael, soprano; Lilia Bizimeche Eisinger, mezzo; Markus Schaeffer, tenor; Michel Brodard, bass; Gulbenkian Chorus and Orchestra, Michel Corboz, cond. Erato 2292-45461-2; CD only. The grandly scaled ''Missa Solemnis'' has so overshadowed Beethoven's earlier Mass in C that performances of the latter are today offered almost as specialist footnotes.

LEAD: Thomas J. Smith, the Computer Science Corporation's director of human resources, was mildly surprised to discover that turnover among professional women at the Moorestown, N.J., information services company was 50 percent higher than for professional men. But when he polled the women who left, he was shocked.

LEAD: The Jupiter Symphony, a chamber orchestra of young freelancers and students, usually performs under the baton of its enterprising founder, Jens Nygaard. On Monday evening, though, the orchestra was conducted by Robert Mann, the first violinist of the Juilliard String Quartet.

LEAD: In Craig Lucas's romantic fantasy ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' the protagonist, Peter, has a nervous moment when he meets the family of Rita, the woman with whom he has fallen in love. As preparations began recently to move the play from the Circle Repertory Off Broadway to the Helen Hayes Theater, where it opens on Tuesday, Timothy Hutton found himself in much the same position.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Terence R. Blackwood of Centreville, Md., have announced June wedding plans for Mrs. Blackwood's daughter Betsy Van Oot and Christopher Dennin Ruppel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip F. Ruppel of Larchmont, N.Y.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Wellesley College started a recycling program this month intended to involve all members of the college community.

LEAD: DR. CHUNG S. YANG, a cancer researcher at Rutgers University's College of Pharmacy, says he is not convinced that popular nutritional supplements, like vitamins and garlic capsules, should be used to prevent or treat serious disease.
LEAD: SWANS will be laying their eggs along the Connecticut coast during the next few weeks without interference from the state.

LEAD: I must agree with Irene M. Symons of the Queens Library, who wrote to comment on a statement attributed to me in a recent article on my book ''We Remember the Holocaust.'' There are many books for young readers on the topic. I state in my preface, '' 'We Remember the Holocaust' is not meant to be the only book a young person will read about the Holocaust.

LEAD: The emotional devastation was still fresh, and so the analysis being offered was emerging through a filter of anger and anguish. The analysis on the part of the Rangers, though, was neither superficial nor cliched. They agreed, with a unanimous and frank sense of remorse, on how precisely they had been eliminated by the Capitals from the Patrick Division final.

LEAD: Kathleen Barry Lewis, the daughter of Margaret S. Lewis of Barrington, R.I., and Roger S. Lewis of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Burdick Tyree Jr., a son of Joan Brophy Tyree of Pawling, N.Y., and the late Mr. Tyree. Msgr. Oscar Ferland, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Chapel by the Sea in Newport, R.I.

LEAD: PEOPLE ASK WHAT I THINK ABOUT when I'm swimming laps, and whether I don't get bored - perfectly reasonable questions. I would like to be able to say that I think profound thoughts underwater, that I write poems or work out complicated dilemmas. But the truth is that I sing the same songs to myself over and over (Roy Orbison is a current favorite) and concentrate on counting laps - from one to eighteen, four times.

LEAD: Catharine Mauze O'Neill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George D. O'Neill of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married there yesterday to Kevin Patrick Anthony Broderick, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Peter-Kean Broderick of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Charles A. Ribaudo performed the ceremony at St.

LEAD: In late March, Donald J. Trump was putting the finishing touches on the exuberant publicity campaign that attended the April opening of his Taj Mahal Hotel and Casino. The result was industrial-strength hoopla, during which Mr. Trump burbled about the thrill of finally completing the vast and long-delayed project and the vitality it would inject into all of Atlantic City.

LEAD: RESIDENTS of Valley Cottage in Rockland County say nothing ever happens there and they love it that way. This bucolic four-square-mile unincorporated hamlet, part of the Town of Clarkstown, has few sidewalks, and building lots are zoned for one-third of an acre to six acres. Street lights are few and far between because they are installed only for safety and when residents request them.

LEAD: INSIDE THE PLO Covert Units, Secret Funds, and the War Against Israel and the United States. By Neil C. Livingstone and David Halevy, in cooperation with the Ethics and Public Policy Center, Washington. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $21.95.

LEAD: After a confrontation between the Oberlin police and demonstrators, many students boycotted classes last Tuesday while professors canceled other classes to attend a communitywide forum on what they say was police brutality. Townspeople also attended the forum.

LEAD: Still buoyant over their historic deployment of the Hubble Space Telescope, five astronauts prepared today to end their five-day shuttle flight with a landing Sunday morning, weather permitting.

LEAD: After reading Diane Ketcham's article April 8 (Fire I. Village Restricts Beach), I was incensed! As a homeowner in Ocean Beach, I am quite familiar with the situation reported in that story. As it reads, one would think that all sides of this issue were represented, albeit not equally. Actually, this article only scratched the surface and was not researched, nor reported accurately.

LEAD: The wedding of Margaret Anne Maher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Maher of Garden City, L.I., and John M. Rogers, a son of Mary Rogers of Southold, L.I., and the late Francis Rogers, took place yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City. The Rev. Charles Bierne officiated.

LEAD: London seems fascinated these days with fakery, pastiche, and imitation. The city's largest redevelopment schemes are latter-day Venetian piazzas and Roman squares. A night at the opera may feature Macbeth warbling Verdi with a chorus of Nazi storm troopers. The historical novelist Peter Ackroyd fills bookstores with simulations of Oscar Wilde's diaries, Hawksmoor's dark plottings, and Thomas Chatterton's frauds.

LEAD: HARRY AND I HAVE been wondering,'' writes Lois Reasoner of Westport, Conn., ''about the origin of the phrase going to hell in a handbasket. We have heard it used in conversation five times in the past few months.''

LEAD: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV never seemed more the master of his nation's opaque and treacherous political process than when he dealt with objections in the national congress and had himself upgraded earlier this year to what was lightly termed the ''super president.'' He assumed executive emergency powers the czars might have envied, and all without the bother of going to the people for popular election.
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins announced the expansion last week of a New York City program that finds and rents apartments for homeless people with AIDS.

LEAD: Every time I think we as a society are prudent in our decision-making abilities, an article comes along to prove me wrong. In the article about high schools and smoking, I was reminded of how foolish we are in teaching Smoking 101 on our school grounds. As role models, school faculty cannot be faulted for smoking; after all, they probably picked it up in high schools they themselves attended.
LEAD: A woman paralyzed with Lou Gehrig's disease died within an hour of being taken off a respirator Friday after she convinced a judge that death was what she wanted.
LEAD: Mongolian opposition groups today protested for a second day in the capital, Ulan Bator, despite a stern warning from the Communist Government that they were breaking the law.

LEAD: I must respond to the letters to the New Jersey editor on March 18 about Caller ID. It seems to me there are people who are so separated from the world that they would trivialize this excellent service.

LEAD: INVENTING OURSELVES Lesbian Life Stories. By the Hall Carpenter Archives Lesbian Oral History Group. Illustrated. 228 pp. New York: Routledge. Paper, $12.95. Cloth, $35. WALKING AFTER MIDNIGHT Gay Men's Life Stories. By the Hall Carpenter Archives Gay Men's Oral History Group.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MY FATHER AND I are driving alone across miles and miles of flat prairie on a private retrospective of his work as an architect: small-town churches, banks, schools. Until now, his career, like all parts of his life with which I haven't been directly involved, is something I've known only vaguely for the simple reason that he's almost never talked about it.

LEAD: ''America Tackles the Pesticide Crisis'' has a nice sensational title that will surely garner readers who didn't realize we had a crisis. Before synthetic agri-chemicals, one farmer was able to feed about 18 people; now, with the help of these chemicals, he can feed about 80. Who would have fed them if farmers hadn't changed the way they grow food?

LEAD: Dan Quayle must have been relieved to hear William Safire assert that the Constitution prohibits Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d from running on a national ticket with fellow-Texan George Bush (''Bush's Cabinet: Who's Up, Who's Down,'' March 25). But the 12th Amendment only prohibits a delegate to the electoral college from casting ballots for Presidential and Vice

LEAD: One of Washington's annual springtime rites is the required Congressional budget resolution. This year, the debate will encompass many things, but a centerpiece will be the proposal by many leading figures in Congress to raise tax rates for the rich, starting with the infamous ''bubble.'' The bubble is, of course, the anomaly in the income tax code that has marginal tax rates rising to 33 percent for taxpayers at roughly the $75,000 level, then dropping back down to 28 percent for those with incomes over roughly $200,000.

LEAD: Over the last year and a half, from Zubin Mehta's announcement of his resignation as music director of the New York Philharmonic until the orchestra's designation the other day of Kurt Masur as his successor, a cloud of pessimism had gathered over New York's orchestral life.

LEAD: On the social circuit this week, there was talk of the attractive way John and Patricia Kluge, who are said to be the country's wealthiest couple, are dissolving their marriage of nine years. It sounded like a divorce made in heaven, which was refreshing, since everyone had had enough of the other kind.

LEAD: When Job, a champion weight lifter who is one of two characters in Fernando Arrabal's allegorical comedy ''The Body Builder's Book of Love,'' hoists a barbell to his chest, he prefers not to concentrate on the mechanics of his sport. A mystical ascetic who has committed his spirit to an unseen woman named

LEAD: For a century now, those who love beauty have reveled in the lucid landscapes of Claude Monet. But an exhibition of 95 of his works at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston makes the surprising case that Monet was a political artist as well. ''Monet in the 90's,'' which closes today, reopens May 19 at the Art Institute of Chicago.

LEAD: If the Government's proposals for monetary and economic union of the two Germanys are adopted, East Germans can expect to find their freshly printed and minted West German marks quickly falling prey to a less pleasant element: taxation.
LEAD: Kite fliers may be kids at heart, but it is difficult to dismiss the sport as just kids' stuff anymore.

LEAD: VOCAL music - opera, song recitals, choral music and a variety of folk performances - crowds the calendar this week. It begins tonight at 7 o'clock in Scarsdale's Hoff-Barthelson School, where the Japanese composer Yoshinao Nakada is to be honored.

LEAD: IT isn't an X-rated movie that is trying to entice customers with promises of ''two magnificent hours of lust, intrigue and madness,'' not to mention ''opium, adultery and murder.'' That's the advertisement for the Westchester Opera's double bill: ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''L'Oracolo.''

LEAD: It is a matter of concern that after many ups and downs over the years, educational exchange is once again coming on hard times. Despite rising costs, it appears that the Administration and Congress intend to let stand a flat budget for Fulbright scholarships for the fifth straight year. In doing so, they will ratify a 23 percent decline in the number of participants over this five-year period.

LEAD: EXPERTS IN AERONAUTICS WILL recognize the shape on the computer screen at right as that of an L-1011 aircraft. The image was generated as the plane approached Philadelphia International Airport by the radar dish shown above, more than a mile and a half away, at the University of Pennsylvania's Valley Forge Research Center, evidence that radar is now capable of identifying objects as more than blips.

LEAD: Q. I am trying to fasten a fairly large hook to a hollow-core door. I have tried plastic anchors and plastic toggles, and in both cases they loosened because the plywood or veneer covering the hollow core is quite thin and not very firm. Any suggestions?
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: As Japan's longtime financial ambassador to the world, the Bank of Tokyo became used to seeing its fortunes mirror the international successes of corporate Japan. But in a striking example of how deregulation and competition are transforming the financial system here, this proud institution is now in the fight of its life.

LEAD: A union study claims that violations of safety precautions against AIDS and hepatitis B are needlessly exposing thousands of workers at private hospitals and nursing homes in the New York City region.

LEAD: The fact that there has been so much hoopla surrounding the latest architectural works commissioned by Walt Disney World for its kingdom in Orlando, Fla., goes to show how little we recall our own architectural history (''Disney Deco,'' by Patricia Leigh Brown, April 8). The idea of using architecture to lure crowds to entertainment and commercial ventures is hardly a new phenomenon - world's fairs have done this for more than a century.

LEAD: When they were ready to step out at night, many women used to throw a daytime coat over their most elaborate evening dress. After all, who was going to notice in the limousine or taxi? Now, evening coats are being seen more often. And there's a new twist, at least in Europe, where fashionable women are donning embroidered velvet evening coats during the day.

LEAD: Because of the March of Dimes Walk America fund-raiser, Lexington Avenue from 23d Street to 96th Street will be closed today from 7 A.M. to 2 P.M.

LEAD: TO most people, the debris of modern life - torn pantyhose, worn-out wire hangars, used containers and cans - is just that, rubbish. But to Nina Johns, it becomes the stuff of folk art, one that draws upon her American Indian heritage.

LEAD: OVER the last two decades, New Yorkers have seen their taxes rise on just about everything. But not on gasoline. When this year's state budget is finally adopted, taxes on dozens of goods and services will likely rise once again. But not on gasoline. In politics, it seems, some things are indeed sacred.

LEAD: THE medicine ball, an exercise tool from the 1930's, is making a comeback. If he fails, he will be asked to resign from his $30,000-a-year post.

LEAD: Redoubled contracts are very rare, but are more likely to occur, for mathematical reasons, when the redoubler is not vulnerable. In a competitive auction the redouble is usually based on some doubt about success rather than on total confidence.

LEAD: It hardly seemed like a growth industry a few years ago. In Paris, the citadel of made-to-order clothes, couture designers were turning their energies to ready-to-wear. The designation ''couture'' was being bastardized, with the word frequently used to describe expensive ready-to-wear.

LEAD: ''There's light at the end of the tunnel,'' a New York politician said the other day upon learning that capital punishment may finally be returning to the Empire State. What did he have in mind? Burning at the stake? Not likely. Politicians receiving big news tend to grasp for the nearest cliche, and ''light at the end of the tunnel'' happened to be lying around when he heard the cheery news.

LEAD: After living together for 15 years, CLAIRE BLOOM and PHILIP ROTH were married on Sunday at the Manhattan home of BARBARA EPSTEIN, a co-editor of The New York Review of Books. ''We just thought it was about time,'' Miss Bloom said.

LEAD: About halfway through his show at the Meadowlands tonight, the singer Don Henley introduced a tune of his, ''Sunset Grill,'' with a little talk. The song was about a person named Joe who owned a hamburger stand on Sunset Boulevard, Mr. Henley said. If someone didn't like the hamburgers, he could go and talk to Joe, who wasn't afraid of this responsibility.
LEAD: In Tokyo yesterday, the Imperial Household Agency said PRINCE AYA, the second son of EMPEROR AKIHITO, would marry KIKO KAWASHIMA on June 29.
LEAD: Marjorie Anne Reed and Ellery Gordon were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York by Caroline K. Simon, a retired judge of the State Court of Claims.
LEAD: Al Bianchi, in the final year of a three-year contract, expects to return as the Knicks' general manager next season. And if Bianchi returns, Stu Jackson will return as head coach.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company announced new sales incentives for cars and light trucks, with rebates ranging from $500 to $4,000 and financing rates from 6.9 percent to 10.9 percent. The program, in effect until May 31, applies to 20 of Ford's 1990 cars and trucks as well as a 1989 model of the Mercury Tracer and 1988 and 1989 models of the Merkur XR
LEAD: A Government AIDS researcher is under suspension while a grand jury considers whether he hid a financial interest in a company that contracted with the laboratory where he worked.

LEAD: He paid his dues for four years as head coach at Pan American University and for four more at Kansas State, and now, as Lon Kruger gets ready for his first season coaching at the University of Florida, he is truly in a bonus situation.

LEAD: International A2-12 Moscow's annual May Day parade this year included throngs of protesters who jeered President Gorbachev and the Kremlin leadership. The protesters were allowed to march through Red Square at the end of the parade. Page A1 Old May Days fade away, and fun arrives
LEAD: Coming Out Under Fire The History of Gay Men and Women in World War II By Allan Berube Illustrated. 377 pages. The Free Press. $22.95.

LEAD: A New York City Council committee yesterday unanimously approved a bill to stiffen penalties for people responsible for buildings with fire-safety violations, including illegal social clubs. The bill would also create a temporary commission to study how the city can help clubs run by legitimate community groups comply with safety laws.
LEAD: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, named Michael Halloran executive vice president and general counsel. He will succeed George Coombe Jr., who will retire.

LEAD: Albert Jocelyn Pyle, an electrical engineer, died of pneumonia on April 25 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Elsmere, Del. He was 94 years old and had lived in Manhattan most of his life before returning to his native Wilmington, Del., about six years ago.
LEAD: Has it come to this? Dave Winfield, role player, out with the coaches and the manager, Bucky Dent, taking advantage of the time allowed in the batting cage for the extra players.

LEAD: Tim Breene has said he would resign as chief executive of Eurocom WCRS Della Femina Ball, the parent agency of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS in New York.

LEAD: ''The world's a really terrible place - it's too precarious,'' says Rita, the young heroine of ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' the Craig Lucas play newly arrived on Broadway. Rita (Mary-Louise Parker), a bartender aspiring to be a graphics designer, lives in a modern city whose ills are all too depressingly recognizable.

LEAD: Responding to Democratic proposals on campaign financing, Senate Republicans today introduced an alternative that shifts the focus from limiting spending to eliminating political action committees and barring political activity by any tax-exempt organization.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a proxy fight being waged by the Torchmark Corporation for seats on the board of the American General Corporation referred incorrectly to the company that derives most of its premiums from life and health policies sold primarily in the rural Southeast.

LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d leaves for Europe on Wednesday for the first six-nation talks about the future of a united Germany, carrying a briefcase full of ideas that he hopes will help the Soviets accept what the United States sees as inevitable: a unified Germany in NATO.

LEAD: George H. Beebe, a former managing editor and associate publisher of The Miami Herald, died of cancer on Monday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: Roger Holland, who as chief executive of Champion Products Inc. engineered its success as a maker of athletic apparel, hopes to do the same for the Signal Apparel Company, where he was named president and chief executive yesterday.

LEAD: The average salary of classroom teachers will pass the $30,000 mark for the first time this year but the gap in teachers' pay among states is still huge, according to statistics compiled by the National Education Association. The average teacher salary rose to $31,304 for the 1989-90 school year, 5.9 percent higher in current dollars than the previous year's figure of $29,547.

LEAD: A Federal district court in Tennessee cleared the way yesterday for shareholders of the American General Corporation to vote today on the Torchmark Corporation's attempt to win a third of the 15 seats on American General's board. At the annual meeting in

LEAD: At a time when college students are usually preoccupied with final examinations and graduation, many at St. John's University in Queens are also focusing on the case of three students who have been accused of sexual assault and suspended from school.
LEAD: For the 16th month in a row, the number of Soviet Jews arriving in Israel increased sharply in April and for the first time exceeded 10,000, Israeli immigration officials said today.

LEAD: The leaders of the European Community may still be uncertain about what a united Europe will mean, but that does not faze Robert Maxwell, as he prepares to introduce what he calls ''Europe's first national weekend newspaper.''
LEAD: The White House announced that President Bush would meet with the prime minister of the Lithuanian independence government. Page A10.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Robert Hill, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has left the company. The termination of the contract was by mutual agreement, said a spokeswoman for City Ballet and Mr. Hill, a former member of American Ballet Theater. Mr. Hill, who joined City Ballet last year, said he had commitments to dance with the Royal Ballet of London and the Scottish Ballet as a guest artist starting in July, and would have had to be away from New York for much of the winter.
LEAD: Construction spending fell 1.4 percent in March, the steepest decline in more than a year, the Government said today in a report that indicated renewed weakness in the building industry.
LEAD: The season's final episode of the most talked about new television series of the year, ''Twin Peaks,'' is to be moved to 10 P.M. on May 23, ABC announced yesterday.
LEAD: THIS is the tale of a mother, a daughter and codfish puffs.

LEAD: Domestic steel production totaled 1,929,000 net tons for the week that ended on Saturday, down 1.3 percent from the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported on Monday. The week's production represented 85.8 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said.

LEAD: The tentative agreement between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders to extend the New York State sales tax to magazines and a number of service industries was attacked by representatives of those industries yesterday. They said that it would drive many businesses out of the state.
LEAD: The pitcher Zane Smith, in a rare pinch-hitting role, doubled in the winning run in the 13th inning tonight, giving the Montreal Expos a 2-1 victory over the Houston Astros.

LEAD: Scores of people were hurt today when anti-American demonstrators clashed with policemen outside a United States Air Force base north of Manila, as Filipino militants carried out nationwide May Day protests against the American military.

LEAD: Steve Elkington, who won the Greater Greensboro Open two weeks ago, yesterday disqualified himself from a 21st-place finish last weekend in the USF&G Classic in New Orleans and forfeited $10,000.

LEAD: THE penny-stock market has had its share of bad publicity and regulatory action of late, with the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking to bar Blinder, Robinson & Company, once the largest penny-stock firm, from the securities business for 45 days.
LEAD: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, said its shareholders overwhelmingly defeated a proposal that would have banned the company from selling infant formula directly to the public.

LEAD: The United States has suspended the Peace Corps program in Liberia and told American diplomats they and their families could leave the country if they chose as fighting between the Liberian Army and rebel forces increased, the State Department said today.
LEAD: A drought-fed brush fire was contained today after it burned 5,500 acres of Everglades grassland, a park spokeswoman said.

LEAD: An article yesterday about a case of adultery being prosecuted in Wisconsin misattributed an article listing states in which adultery was still prohibited by law in 1987. It was in The Harvard Journal of Law and Public Policy, not The Harvard Law Review.

LEAD: Lawyers Told to Help Poor New York's chief judge told lawyers that if they don't voluntarily expand free legal services to the poor by 1992 he will force them to. Page B1. Chrysler Earnings Tumble The auto maker's profit fell 79.8 percent in the first quarter because of an industrywide slowdown, but analysts had been expecting worse.

LEAD: In a spur to the Bush Administration's Latin America policy, the Senate today approved giving $720 million in economic aid to Panama and Nicaragua after an impasse of several days over an assortment of unrelated amendments.

LEAD: Police officers in riot helmets entered Tompkins Square Park last night after a Parks Department enforcement patrol officer was injured by a bottle thrown during a May Day concert for affordable housing that erupted into a night of disturbances, the police and parks officials said.
LEAD: A $159.4 million tax-exempt bond issue by Minneapolis and the Housing and Redevelopment Authority of St. Paul was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
LEAD: It is spring and the Hudson River is bursting with striped bass, a species once prized in New York by sportsmen and chefs. But for one band of fishermen, this is bad news.

LEAD: David G. Fernald, a former treasurer of Rockefeller Family and Associates, died of complications of leukemia on Monday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Montclair.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: Just in time for summer, the Cola Wars sizzled again yesterday, as Burger King announced it was switching to Coke from Pepsi as its soft-drink supplier.
LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday priced a $150 million note issue through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

LEAD: Two months ago the Home Dish Satellite Corporation was a flourishing New York City company, beaming hard-core sex films to 30,000 subscribers around the country and soft-core ones to 1.2 million customers.

LEAD: As the ''2 plus 4'' talks on Germany's future approach, the proposal that a united Germany remain a member of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact is gaining momentum. However ingenious, the proposal is ill-advised both for American interests and European peace.
LEAD: ''The blunt fact is that both the Democratic budget and the President's budget are hopelessly obsolete.'' - Representative Bill Frenzel, Republican of Minnesota. [A19:1.]

LEAD: Spurred by sales of its anemia drug, Amgen Inc. today reported substantial sales and earnings. Sold under the name Epogen, erythropoeitin is Amgen's first product approved for sale by the Food and Drug Administration.

LEAD: Chevron U.S.A. Inc. agreed to sell certain Gulf of Mexico oil reserves for about $150 million to a New Orleans-based partnership. Chevron U.S.A., the domestic oil and gas subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation, said it was selling its Main Pass 299 shallow oil reserves.
LEAD: Barbara Staples, who teaches seventh grade at Conway Middle School here, returned from summer vacation several years ago to find her professional world turned upside down.

LEAD: The farmers hitched their horses to trees near the little brick schoolhouse on a prairie rich in golden grain. Under a canvas in kaleidoscopic colors, strung on poles for shade, they assembled for a town meeting.
LEAD: A chart on the Media Business page on Monday headed ''Magazine Growth, Gains and Losses'' referred incorrectly to the growth in the number of general interest magazines.

LEAD: Husband-and-wife partnerships tend to be difficult, and particularly tricky for newlyweds: Even a raised eyebrow has been known to cause trouble. A careful safety-play was devised last Thursday by Amy Shavick Treitel, who was playing with David Treitel for the first time in their eight-day marriage.

LEAD: AND now, monsieur and madame, here are today's specials: One neon-blue catfish. One half of a cow. Blackened pork chops, frozen. Fake caviar, 150 gallons of it. A platter of ham bones: no ham; just the bones. Eyeballs on baked potatoes. Nine all-white entrees on all-white plates in an all-white restaurant.

LEAD: Removing a longtime irritant in its relations with South Korea, Japan has agreed to abolish fingerprinting requirements and enhance the legal status for the youngest descendants of Koreans forcibly brought to this country to do hard labor before World War II.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY L. William Seidman came under public pressure to step down as head of the Government agency that is managing the Federal savings and loan bailout. The pressure on Mr. Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, comes at a time when the agency is gearing up to spend almost $1 billion a day over the next two months to cover losses on the insolvent savings and loan associations it is trying to sell.

LEAD: Human remains unearthed in a wooded area here were identified on Monday as those of Joan Webster, a Harvard graduate student from Glen Ridge, N.J., missing since 1981, the Essex County District Attorney said.
LEAD: All but 20 of the Jewish settlers at a four-building complex in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem's walled Old City left the building by noon today, when an eviction order took effect.

LEAD: Purchasers in the biggest savings and loan bailout of 1988 are enjoying millions of dollars of risk-free profits and regulators should renegotiate the deal, Senator Howard Metzenbaum said today.
LEAD: The Metro Matters column on April 19, about a dentist facing sentencing for burglary, referred to her incorrectly. She is Marsha Cohen.

LEAD: After celebrating the release of the second hostage in two weeks, President Bush is turning his attention to the delicate diplomatic task of obtaining the freedom of more American captives without breaking his pledge not to negotiate with Iran.
LEAD: The new chief executive of the Campbell Soup Company yesterday cut nearly 19 percent, or 364 jobs, from its headquarters staff in Camden, N.J.

LEAD: The Emerson Electric Company pleaded guilty today to making inflated cost estimates for electronic equipment it sold the Pentagon and agreed to pay a $40,000 fine and a $14 million civil settlement, the Justice Department said.
LEAD: Martin Shwartz, a theater press agent for more than 40 years, died of heart failure on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 66 years old.

LEAD: The historic Painted Church was propped on timbers to be moved today. Barbara Allen returned one last time to the small house she had built in a coconut grove to rescue Grayson, her cat. Fidelie Sweezey sniffled as she watched the house in which she was born 65 years ago and raised six children start to smolder.

LEAD: Michael Golden was named publisher of McCall's magazine yesterday by William T. Kerr, president of The New York Times Magazine Group, which owns the publication. Mr. Golden had been general manager of Child magazine, also a member of the group, since January 1988.

LEAD: OPEC needs to cut oil production by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day to help crude prices recover from their recent slide, OPEC's president said today as the organization's ministers arrived for an emergency meeting.
LEAD: Yields on some certificates of deposit were slightly up, while those offered on money market accounts were unchanged in the week ended yesterday.
LEAD: Many of the 40 million deaths caused by disease around the world each year could be prevented by a small shifting of resources to health care, the World Health Organization says.
LEAD: The Phoenix Cardinals have granted free-agent status to their retired fullback Earl Ferrell, who is 32 years old and wants to play in the Canadian Football League.

LEAD: After an 11-month decline, the nation's manufacturing economy expanded in April, stimulated by strong levels of new orders, particularly from foreign customers, the nation's purchasing managers reported yesterday.

LEAD: The Rev. Henry C. Gregory 3d, for 17 years senior minister of Shiloh Baptist Church, Washington's historic activist church, died of cancer on Sunday at the Greenbriar, a resort in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., where he was resting. He was 54 years old. Mr. Gregory's sermons at Shiloh, nationally known for its program of pursuing social and political causes, were taped and broadcast on radio every

LEAD: THE highway runs down from Santiago toward Punta Arenas and, yes, the South Pole, but we weren't going that far, my leathery-faced driver and I. We were turning right near San Fernando, about three hours south of the capital, and heading into the Colchagua Valley to Peralillo. It was the fourth day of a weeklong trip through what is probably the most exciting wine region in the world right now.
LEAD: IN a city where bigger often translates as better, four brothers operating a development company in Queens say they have found that smaller commercial projects sometimes make more sense.

LEAD: Fairleigh Dickinson University's hurricane-ravaged West Indies Laboratory for Underwater Research in St. Croix, V.I., has canceled classes for the 1990-91 academic year, on the recommendation of a special committee of the trustees.

LEAD: The 15th season of music at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., is to begin on July 7 at 8:30 P.M. with a performance by the Festival Orchestra, conducted by Gerard Schwarz. The program includes David Diamond's Symphony No. 3, Mussorgsky's ''Night on Bald Mountain'' and Rachmaninoff's Concerto No.

LEAD: As a wounded police officer was bleeding to death from a bullet wound that severed an artery in his neck, doctors at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn inserted a tube in his leg yesterday, guided it to the torn artery and released a coil at the tip of the tube to stop the bleeding.

LEAD: The reason for George Steinbrenner's $40,000 payment to Howard Spira in January might be in dispute, but telephone records leave no doubt that an ongoing relationship between the two existed for three years, primarily through Steinbrenner's chief aide.

LEAD: The Irish Government outlawed smoking in theaters and buses today and ordered segregated smoking areas to be set up in Government buildings, trains, schools, libraries, hospitals, airports, supermarkets, restaurants and art galleries.
LEAD: The Carter Organization, a leading proxy solicitation firm, told its employees yesterday that about 25 of them, including the company's president, Art Ross, would be let go to trim costs.

LEAD: A veteran police officer was shot in the neck and critically wounded early yesterday by a man he had stopped for driving a stolen car the wrong way on a one-way street in Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD: THERE have been vines in Volnay, in Burgundy, for a thousand years. Many of the vineyards in Volnay, which lies just two miles south of the city of Beaune, have had the same names for at least 700 years. Les Caillerets, one of the most famous of the Volnay vineyards today, was partly owned by the Knights of
LEAD: New York's Chief Judge today declined to force private lawyers to donate free legal services to the poor immediately but warned that he would impose such a program in two years.
LEAD: Executive Shifts
LEAD: Edwina Dumm, a syndicated newspaper cartoonist, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96 years old.

LEAD: IT has never been much fun at the bottom of the third world's economic pecking order, and for millions in Latin America, Africa and the backwaters of Asia, it is grimmer than ever. Cut off by private lenders in the 1980's, most poor countries have been forced to make ends meet without much help from the industrialized economies.

LEAD: Uli Edel's ''Last Exit to Brooklyn'' is a good, dark, uncommonly evocative screen adaptation of Hubert Selby Jr.'s teeming novel, published in 1964, about life on the edge in the Red Hook section in the early 1950's.
LEAD: A 17-year-old boy died of a gunshot wound to the head today, becoming the third student at the high school here to commit suicide in the last two days and the fourth in the last month.

LEAD: A court-imposed deadline for revision of the way Texas finances public education passed today without action by the state, but a judge gave Gov. William P. Clements Jr. and the Legislature 30 days more to arrive at a plan.

LEAD: Michael O. Sanderson, a former chief of Merrill Lynch-Canada, has been named president and chief executive of the Instinet Corporation, an electronic equities trading operation owned by Reuters Holdings P.L.C. of London.

LEAD: IRVING BERLIN wrote the words and music to ''Call Me Madam,'' the musical based on President HARRY S. TRUMAN'S appointment of PERLE MESTA as Ambassador to Luxembourg, in his five-story town house at 17 Beekman Place in Manhattan. Forty years ago, ''Call Me Madam'' opened on Broadway. Yesterday, the Government of Luxembourg bought the building, where the composer died on Sept.

LEAD: An abatement of political violence appears crucial to the ultimate success of talks scheduled to begin here on Wednesday between the Government and its leading anti-apartheid opponent, the African National Congress.

LEAD: In the hills of Geauga County, 22 miles east of Cleveland, a tiny rest home is doing research that may help the nation's four million Alzheimer's patients, and the families and nursing homes that care for them, get through the daily crises of memory loss, disorientation, wandering and incontinence that mark their decline into dementia.
LEAD: Things hummed along at the Gay and Lesbian Switchboard.

LEAD: The world's largest hospital supply company, Baxter International Inc., denied today that it had sold a plant in Israel and agreed to build one in Syria to get off the Arab League's blacklist of companies doing business with the Jewish state.

LEAD: Interest rates rose yesterday for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, following the general rise in rates for most debt securities in the same period.

LEAD: The House today narrowly approved the Democratic majority's $1.2 trillion budget for 1991, calling for $24 billion less for the military than President Bush proposed and $5.6 billion more for domestic programs.

LEAD: An ethics panel for the nation's largest organization of doctors says that blacks get less frequent, less aggressive medical care than whites in the United States and that the disparities are unacceptable.

LEAD: Dr. Lockhart B. McGuire, a cardiologist and professor of medicine at the University of Virginia School of Medicine, died of colon cancer on Sunday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 55 years old.

LEAD: John Emil List was sentenced today to five consecutive life terms for the murders of his wife, mother and three children 18 years ago, and as he was led away, the packed courtroom burst into applause.

LEAD: ''Voyage of Terror: The Achille Lauro Affair'' is the second television movie based on the 1985 hijacking by four Palestinians of an Italian cruise ship in the Mediterranean. This one, starring Burt Lancaster and Eva-Marie Saint as the American passengers Leon and Marilyn Klinghoffer, makes its own special claims to authenticity.

LEAD: RESTAURANTS around the country are taking liberties with the traditional salade nicoise, adding anything from sun-dried tomatoes to sliced potatoes and beets. Dishes that are called ''nicoise'' usually include Provencal products like garlic, olives, anchovies, tomatoes and green beans; salade nicoise usually contains tuna, too.

LEAD: A real estate broker who stole $2 million in Government housing money and used it to buy sports cars, furs and jewelry was sentenced by a Federal district judge today to six years in prison and ordered to pay $4 million in fines and restitution.

LEAD: The CBS television network affiliate in Los Angeles, KCBS, announced yesterday that it had agreed to broadcast a debate between the contenders for the Democratic nomination for governor of California, Dianne Feinstein and John K. Van de Kamp, on Sunday afternoon, May 20.

LEAD: A Federal district judge here is considering a novel extension of First Amendment rights to a religion based primarily on ''absolution'' through sex and ''sacrifice'' through a payment of money.

LEAD: THERE are always questions and comments from readers that are of general interest. It is not possible to answer those questions individually, so from time to time they are gathered together to produce a column.

LEAD: THE National Enquirer has started a new push to get more national consumer-product advertisers to follow its success with Procter & Gamble. The Enquirer's owner, the G. P. Group Inc., recently acquired the rival Star in March, which will aid the effort. The company plans to offer a combination advertising package in the tabloids that it says will deliver more than 30 million readers a week to advertisers.
LEAD: A report in the Science Watch column of Science Times yesterday about research on latex gloves misstated a finding about leakage. Eighteen percent of 2,900 gloves leaked water, not viruses.

LEAD: While the auto-industry sales slump eroded the Chrysler Corporation's overall market share and profitability, the company's Jeep line remained a trusty and profitable product. Jeeps, along with mini-vans, now account for nearly all of the company's automotive profits, some analysts say.

LEAD: Isiah Thomas scored 23 points and Bill Laimbeer had 12 points and 19 rebounds tonight to lead the Detroit Pistons over the Indiana Pacers, 108-96, for a three-game sweep in the first round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Actel Corporation said today that they would cooperate in developing and manufacturing a new family of computer chips.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds sagged in thin trading yesterday, pushed down by a report from the National Association of Purchasing Managers that the economy's manufacturing sector had improved in April.

LEAD: American avant-gardists have always found West German radio open to experimental works, and over the last 10 years several composers have forged strong links to the Westdeutscher Rundfunk, or the West German Broadcasting Network.

LEAD: Peggy Walsh, the San Francisco bureau chief of The Associated Press for the last four years, will become executive editor of The New York Times News Service on June 1. She will be in charge of the news, photo and graphics operations for the news service, which transmits breaking news and feature stories, photographs and graphics to more than 650 newspapers and other clients in more than 50 countries.

LEAD: Walter J. Kendall Jr., a retired chief of personnel in the New York City Police Department, died of congestive heart failure on Sunday at Suburban General Hospital in Norristown, Pa. He was 75 years old and lived in Ridge, L.I.

LEAD: Rich and poor countries reached agreement today on a declaration setting out new priorities for speeding up economic growth in the developing world in the 1990's after a difficult debate that ran longer than expected.

LEAD: Representative Sidney R. Yates, the Chicago Democrat who has been a vigorous champion of the arts, chided the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts today for his decision to require recipients of endowment grants to sign a pledge that the funds will not be used to produce obscene works of art.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The personal computer and the facsimile machine are converging in a number of ways visible in products now reaching the market. But how the two technologies will ultimately be combined is anything but certain.
LEAD: The judge in the Bensonhurst murder case blocked the lawyer for Joseph Fama yesterday from introducing evidence considered important by the defense.
LEAD: Budget Director Richard G. Darman said tonight that the United States should not abandon its market economy and economic growth to clean up the environment.
LEAD: Jeffrey R. Korman, a Democrat, easily won a special election yesterday in the Bronx for the State Senate seat of Abraham Bernstein, a Democrat, who died in March.

LEAD: IN the three years since it opened its doors, the tiny Twelve Pine takeout store has become increasingly crowded with patrons hungry for the mix of Greek, Asian, Italian, Mexican, French and American dishes crammed into display cases and onto counters.
LEAD: IN his backyard overlooking Indian Creek, Norman Braman walks down the steps of his empty swimming pool, opens the watertight door, and descends into his kidney-shaped wine cellar.

LEAD: The Sharp Corporation of Japan says it will soon introduce a desktop machine for full-color facsimiles in that country, but has not decided whether to sell the device in the United States because of concerns that American business will find it too expensive and lack needed high-quality telephone lines.

LEAD: As they struggle to finish the state's overdue budget, New York's legislators threaten in one stroke both to distort the already flawed system of financing local school districts and to compound the state's financial woes.

LEAD: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Placed Nick Esasky, first baseman, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to April 22. DETROIT (AL) - Returned Johnny Paredes, infielder, to Montreal. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Optioned Bill Pecota, infielder, and Gary Thurman, outfielder, to Omaha of the American Association.
LEAD: Renee Fleming, a soprano, is the recipient of this year's Richard Tucker Award. The $25,000 cash prize is the largest cash award in United States music competitions. There were 38 applicants.

LEAD: The savings and loan bailout is already a mess. Why does the Bush Administration seem so determined to make the cleanup even slower? Now it is not so subtly nudging out the man who is managing the bailout. That comes hard on the heels of Congressional hearings showing Administration stinginess in prosecuting S &

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins named directors of homosexual, veteran and Asian-American affairs yesterday, the last of his ''constituency'' office appointments.

LEAD: ''I think I shredded most of that. Did I get them all?'' Oliver North asked the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra scandal in 1987. He needn't have worried. The committees were letting damning documents and other evidence slip through their fingers.

LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation announced yesterday that it had won its largest contract ever, a five-year, $375 million agreement to provide long-distance services for pay phones at United States Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard sites.
LEAD: An article yesterday about a study issued by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching misstated the title. The study is ''Campus Life: In Search of Community.''

LEAD: A quarter of a century ago, a house that Frank Lloyd Wright designed in the 1940's as part of an experiment in affordable middle-class living, was moved, board by board, to a new site near here to save it from bulldozers that were clearing ground for a superhighway. Now the house is threatened again.

LEAD: Henry Tillman beat Mike Tyson twice when they were amateurs, victories that led to Tillman winning a spot on the 1984 United States Olympic team. But as a professional, Tillman saw his career go south while Tyson's star, and financial worth, ascended.

LEAD: As castanet players go, Lucero Tena is a consummate virtuoso. Of that, her concert with the Andres Segovia Quintet at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening left no doubt. Effortlessly, it seems, she can play with blinding speed or evenly measured slowness, shattering intensity or delicate stillness; she can achieve any gradation between, and progress smoothly from one to another.

LEAD: A performance of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' on June 12 on the Great Lawn of Central Park is to open the Metropolitan Opera's 24th season of free outdoor performances. The opera will alternate with another Verdi work, ''La Traviata,'' during the three-week series, which is sponsored by Chemical Bank.

LEAD: The outspoken head of the Federal savings and loan bailout came under White House pressure today, with the President's chief spokesman saying that ''we are interested in getting new leadership'' in the rescue effort.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the sentencing of John Emil List for the murder of his wife, mother and three children by Judge William L'E. Wertheimer in Superior Court.

LEAD: The Bush Administration today granted a three-month extension of a Presidential order that voided the sale of a company based in Seattle to a Chinese Government agency with ties to the military, officials said.
LEAD: The lava flows besieging Hawaii's coastal community of Kalapana are far more damaging than some earlier eruptions of the Kilauea volcano because the lava is moving continuously.

LEAD: THE warm greetings, big hugs and kisses, souvenirs and, when appropriate, birthday candles on the biscuits are Eunice Merrell's special brand of Alabama hospitality. And it all happens over breakfast.
LEAD: In many cities, what comes to mind when people think of a police dog is the kind of animal that becomes the canine equivalent of the business end of a .357 magnum when it bares its teeth.
LEAD: Auditors who visited two New York City school districts could not trace thousands of dollars worth of computer equipment, the City Comptroller's office said yesterday.
LEAD: A memorial service for the artist Keith Haring is to be held on Friday at 2 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at West 112th Street.

LEAD: EVOLUTION On this beautiful spring night Let us go, Dear, To the mall parking lot To hear the cars sing. Robins are old hat - The same every year! But there's a new Ford, I hear, Whose whistle will Knock your socks off. So let us go to the mall parking lot, My dear, To hear the cars sing.
LEAD: Gerald Wilkins says, ''We need to play better defense.''
LEAD: Northeast Utilities has appointed a team of senior managers to take over the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the operator of the long-delayed Seabrook nuclear power plant.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Clang. It is a sound unlike any other sound: Not just metal on metal, but the definitive sequence of locks and bolts settling into place. Even a reporter on assignment cannot escape shuddering when the prison doors go clang.
LEAD: It took Sam Nunn three months of research to pronounce the Bush Administration's 1991 military budget irrelevant. His series of carefully timed speeches on the Senate floor was front-page news.

LEAD: The first of three reactors that are the nation's only source of a gas needed to make nuclear weapons will not be restarted until December, but the plant that is the only source of plutonium triggers may be ready to resume production by July, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today.
LEAD: The Church and Order of St. Matthew called its members friars who took a vow of poverty, but a Federal grand jury said yesterday that they were tax cheats.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: Charging that New York City's homeless shelters have deteriorated under Mayor David N. Dinkins and ''are in absolute chaos,'' the Coalition for the Homeless said yesterday that it would ask a state judge to close all shelters in state armories.

LEAD: For all the television specials, movies and ice shows Brian Boitano has appeared in since winning the men's skating title at the Calgary Olympics two years ago, the opportunity he wanted most was a chance to compete in the Olympics again. Now, he can't. Representatives of the International Skating Union, the world governing body for figure and speed skating, adopted proposals yesterday in Christchurch, New

LEAD: Solving the problem of financing long-term health care for the elderly is a pressing national priority. Connecticut has taken steps to address that problem, and is awaiting action by Congress that would help put its plan into action.

LEAD: Two Mohawk Indians were killed today by snipers' bullets in separate shootings on the Canadian side of the St. Regis Indian Reservation. They were the first known fatalities in the bitter confrontation there over casino gambling.

LEAD: Government forces killed at least two people in an attack on members of a leading dissident group at a political rally Monday evening, less than a week after President Mobutu Sese Seko promised to lift a ban on opposition parties, diplomats and witnesses said today.

LEAD: It was distressing on Sunday, ugly on Monday and depressing tonight. The Mets, who have found imaginative ways to lose in the last few days, discovered another one against the lowly Braves this evening.

LEAD: THE Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the irradiation of poultry to control salmonella and other bacteria that are responsible for an increase in food-borne illnesses in this country.

LEAD: Engineers have successfully completed tests of the Hubble Space Telescope's two high-power antennas and both are expected to provide a steady if somewhat restricted flow of communications, the space agency said yesterday.
LEAD: Two debenture issues by the Federal National Mortgage Association were priced yesterday through a nationwide group of securities dealers.

LEAD: Antoine Vitez, an actor, director and teacher who capped a distinguished theatrical career by becoming chief administrator of the Comedie Francaise, died of a brain hemorrhage on Monday. He was 59 years old.

LEAD: Sim Son, who was in charge of civilian affairs for the Khmer Rouge, was killed April 25 when a tree fell on him near the Thai border in Cambodia during a storm, Khmer Rouge officials said today. His age was not disclosed.
LEAD: Foie Gras Shortage
LEAD: The United States airline industry offered today to pay up to $1 million for information about terrorist attacks against American airliners.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit declined 79.8 percent, reflecting an industrywide sales slowdown and the high cost of discount programs.
LEAD: Only four months ago, Thirty Six Red was a candidate for racing's unkindest cut.

LEAD: TENNIS Chang Stunned by Korda Third-seeded Michael Chang was upset by Peter Korda of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 7-5, 7-6, yesterday in the first round of the BMW Open in Munich, West Germany. Chang, playing on European clay for the first time since winning the French Open last June, was not able to come up with the winning shots on the crucial points in the 2-hour-50-minute match.

LEAD: Dr. Elias H. Gerchick, a former chief of psychiatry at White Plains Hospital and a specialist in the treatment of children, died of heart failure at Montefiore Hospital on Saturday. He was 74 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: The countries of Eastern Europe yesterday marked the first May Day since they emerged from Communist rule without public parades and with few speeches, concentrating largely on private pursuits like picnics and shopping.
LEAD: For the last half-century, Philadelphia has had only one major downtown performing-arts center, the venerable Academy of Music, but now the city is struggling over the fate of two others.

LEAD: The first volunteers in an unusual educational experiment have just landed in this tiny Appalachian town - an eager, slightly bewildered group of 183 Japanese students who represent the first full-fledged merger between an American and Japanese college.

LEAD: A year after Hungary opened the gates and set off an East German stampede to the West, diplomats face the reality of German unification. But the talks that begin Saturday among the U.S., the Soviet Union, France and Britain - the four - plus the two Germanys concern the Soviet Union's future in Europe as much as the future of Germany.
LEAD: The latest campus of the City University of New York sits on a mountaintop in Japan. The branch opened this month in Chiyoda, a suburb about 25 miles southwest of Hiroshima.

LEAD: Jean Marie Gee, a dance teacher and ballerina who created the title role in Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Pomona,'' died on April 18 at the M. B. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. She was 87 years old.

LEAD: President Bush will meet with the Lithuanian Prime Minister on Thursday, the White House announced today. It will be the first time that an American President has met with a leader of the Baltic republic since it was forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940.
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Kremlin leadership were jeered today by throngs of protesters who were allowed to march through Red Square at the end of the annual May Day parade.

LEAD: The May Day parade in Red Square today was opened to public participation for the first time. Here is a sampling of the official May Day slogans, approved by the Communist Party, and the unofficial slogans shouted by the unofficial demonstrators or appearing on their signs: Official Slogans
LEAD: It's now getting so that the Yankees do not know what to fix first.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: A former Houston police officer has been sentenced to seven years in prison for shooting a black woman to death along a Houston freeway last October.

LEAD: Frank Herbert Reed, released from three and a half years of captivity in Beirut, arrived at the United States Air Force hospital here today for a reunion with his wife and son and a big, medium-rare steak.

LEAD: For about 40 years, off and on, America has been treated to a new Richard Nixon, a newer Richard Nixon, the newest Richard Nixon. This marvel of recycling is back again this week, on NBC's ''Today'' show, the occasion being his latest account of his triumphs and his troubles, ''In the Arena: A Memoir of Victory, Defeat and Renewal,'' recently published by Simon & Schuster.

LEAD: Yosuke Yamashita, a pianist, devoted most of his first set on Wednesday night at Sweet Basil to adaptations of Japanese folk tunes. But if he hadn't said so, listeners might never have guessed, because he recast the melodies with the spiky harmonies and assertive rhythms of 1960's jazz.
LEAD: Stock prices rose yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 12.16 points, to 2,668.92.

LEAD: WITH names like kriek, framboise, gueuze and trappiste, it's hardly surprising that these highly unusual beers produced by Belgium's 100 active breweries incite equal measures of excitement and confusion among beer lovers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: As Senate races shape up around the country, officials in both parties say Republicans are bucking the usual trend in midterm elections: they are in good position to pick up several seats this fall and narrow the gap with Democrats.

LEAD: Student academic achievement has continued a fall that started three years ago, and fewer seniors are graduating from high school, the Education Department said today in releasing its annual state-by-state performance chart.

LEAD: Thomas DeRogatis, a former Chase Manhattan Corporation executive, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of Bonwit Teller.

LEAD: Unusual complications in predicting oil supply and demand - including uncertainty about the economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and the effects of the environmental movement - are making producers reluctant to invest in new wells and pipelines, experts at an international conference here say.
