LEAD: Mats Wilander of Sweden, the former No. 1 men's singles player in the world, said yesterday at a news conference in Stockholm he would pass up this month's French Open, which he has won three times, and probably not play this summer at Wimbledon. Wilander, who has dropped out of the top 10 ranking, has not played competitively since March and will not be in condition to compete in Paris at the end of the month.

LEAD: Bob Engel, the National League umpire suspended indefinitely after being accused of stealing baseball cards from a Target store in Bakersfield, Calif., on April 21, faces a new charge of trying to shoplift cards from another store in Bakersfield, his hometown. The umpire pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to misdemeanor counts of stealing seven boxes containing 4,180 Score baseball cards from the Target store and of attempting to steal 50 packs of baseball cards from Costco in January.

LEAD: With plans to create a single trading market already well advanced, the 12 nations of the European Community have set themselves the task of achieving still greater economic and political unity by Jan. 1, 1993.

LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union are exploring a new approach to ending the Afghan conflict, under which Moscow would accept elections to choose a new government and Washington would let the current leader, Najibullah, run for president if he first surrendered power.
LEAD: To broaden their children's entertainment and educational interests, parents can now find more than 125 publications in a new national directory called Magazines for Children.

LEAD: Rampant theft from the New York City Transit Authority now exceeds $2 million a year, with power tools, bus engines and even a new tractor-trailer cab disappearing from warehouses, transit authorities said yesterday.

LEAD: Soviet Jews have been anxious for months about rumors of a pogrom, but the Jews of Odessa are debating another fear: just how thorough and heartbreaking their exodus from this effervescent crossroads city will prove to be.

LEAD: The unflagging influence of Mary Lou Williams through five decades of jazz, from the 1930's until her death in 1981, was summarized brilliantly by the American Jazz Orchestra in a concert at Cooper Union on Friday evening. LEAD: President Bush is set to announce an arms control initiative that would accelerate talks on short-range nuclear weapons in Europe and remove at least some nuclear artillery from the continent, Administration officials said yesterday. LEAD: At the start of ''Silence Equals Death,'' one of two new documentaries by Rosa von Praunheim about the range of responses to the AIDS plague, a man tells the camera he has tested HIV positive for the AIDS virus. LEAD: Residents of Kent and the surrounding community flocked to the Kent State University campus today to see a new memorial that is to be dedicated on Friday, the 20th anniversary of the slaying of four students by Ohio National Guardsmen. Speakers at the dedication of the abstract memorial - four granite slabs flanked by a walkway - will include Florence Schroeder, whose son was among those slain, and Dean Kahler, now an Athens County Commissioner, who was among the nine wounded by the guardsmen's gunfire.

LEAD: Deutsch's first major campaign for Ikea, the Swedish furniture maker, tries to show what is wrong with the other stores. The agency constructed a series of television commercials out of bites of film shot at the other furniture retailers. As edited by Deutsch, other stores look silly: they specialize to a fault, bore kids to death, always run ''sales'' and hire goofy salesmen and inept truckers.

LEAD: Ignore for a moment the vexed question of how best to free the 16 remaining Western hostages in Lebanon. What sears the conscience is the drawn face and the unselfish anger of Frank Herbert Reed after three and a half years of captivity.
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has upheld the state's death penalty law, opening the way for Illinois's first execution in 28 years.

LEAD: The European Community Executive Commission said on Wednesday that it planned to spend $363 million to improve and expand natural gas and electricity systems. The projects in the three-year plan include introducing natural gas in Portugal and Greece, connecting gas networks in Ireland and Britain, and linking electricity networks in Italy and Greece.

LEAD: A jury decided today that The Philadelphia Inquirer had recklessly defamed one of the city's most prominent lawyers and must pay him $34 million. Experts said the award was the largest ever handed up by a jury in a libel case against an American news organization.

LEAD: A second suspect was arrested yesterday in the killing of a gypsy-cab driver in the Bronx two weeks ago, the police said. The cabby, Mian Mohammed Salim, 48 years old, was the sixth gypsy-cab driver slain in the Bronx in seven weeks. He was shot in the head, apparently in a robbery. The suspect, Orlando Hernandez, 22, of 1197 Grand Concourse in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, turned himself in to the police in Miami.He is charged with second-degree murder.

LEAD: America's first astronauts were men in their 30's. By the late 1960's men in their 40's were making space voyages and with the joint American-Soviet space rendezvous in 1975, the first astronaut in his 50's went into space. Now the 60-year-old age barrier is on the verge of falling. On Wednesday, VANCE BRAND will be 59 years old; one week later, he is to command the space shuttle Columbia for a 9- or 10-day space trip during which he and other astronauts will put into orbit telescopes to retrieve scientific data on the universe as part of the $100 million Astro program.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Interest rates plunged yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities soared in response to news of an unexpectedly small increase in nonfarm employment in April. ''Tales From the Darkside'' is subtitled ''The Movie'' because tales like these are so familiar in other forms: as campfire stories, horror comics, television shows (with less gruesome special effects) and novels by Stephen King, one of whose stories is the basis for an episode here. So nothing about ''Tales From the Darkside'' is likely to give anyone much of a scare. But thanks to casting that is savvier than the horror norm, and to direction by John Harrison that is workmanlike and sometimes even witty, at least it's fun. Spite plays an important role here, especially for the mummy in the film's first episode (''Lot 249,'' adapted from a story by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle) who tries out certain embalming techniques on a spoiled, modern-day college boy. Christian Slater and Steve Buscemi play fellow students engaged in a battle of wits, with the mummy as a dangerously lively pawn. Spite also matters to the black cat in the film's middle installment, who is intent on killing the pharmaceuticals tycoon (William Hickey) who has developed a special drug with the help of 5,000 feline victims.

The agreement is still subject to the approval of the bankruptcy court and creditors.

LEAD: ''CHESTER is not chic; that's why I like it,'' said Morley Safer, correspondent and co-editor of television's ''60 Minutes,'' who spends weekends at his home in Chester. ''It really is in so many ways rural America. My greatest fear is of seeing a candle shop open.''

LEAD: An office building under construction here is the first of a dozen Federal projects throughout the United States that will use a development method that involves long-term leases rather than outright purchases of new buildings the Government commissions for its own occupancy.

LEAD: Amid the Earth Day festivities in New York's Central Park, some of the most ingenious recycling took place in the music on stage. Many of the performers made the effort to do something more than flog their latest hits; they gave at least a passing thought to the cause.

LEAD: As Italy prepares for nationwide local elections this weekend, the death toll among politicians has reached grim dimensions in the troubled South, where organized-crime clans are intent on asserting their primacy.

LEAD: For Donald J. Trump embarrassing revelations keep coming, and they no longer have to do solely with Ivana. First came the report in Forbes magazine demoting him from a billionaire to a half billionaire and estimating that because of debt payments he might actually have a shortfall of almost $40 million a year.

LEAD: At the Presbyterian Church in Morristown, N.J., Alexandra Beach Pierson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Pierson of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to David Thomas Mead, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Mead of Morristown. The Rev. Thomas C. Sheffield performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A FEW FACTS ABOUTJU Kemal Amen Kasem: As the voice behind the pop music countdown radio show ''Casey's Top Forty,'' he may be the most-listened-to person on radio except for the commentator Paul Harvey. He is of Lebanese Druse parentage, the son of a grocer, born and raised in Detroit. His first radio job was playing Scoop Ryan, Cub Reporter.

LEAD: Vyacheslav Bobrik, a 19-year-old member of the Soviet amateur team, won the third stage of the Tour de Trump bicycle race today after a bold move. The victory made him the overall leader in the 11-day stage race. After 27 miles of the 87.7-mile road race from Fredericksburg to Richmond, three riders broke away from the 129 others.

LEAD: THE planting season is in full swing. Everything is going into the ground: shrubs, perennials, wildflowers and annuals. But there are important exceptions, the most tender plants like tomatoes and impatiens. Wait another week or so before putting them in, because killing frosts may still occur in this region.

LEAD: The flush of excitement with which most of the world has greeted political change in Eastern Europe obscures the reality about artistic life in cities like this: If improvements are to come here, they are far off and will be hard earned.

LEAD: Tennis Sanchez Vicario Beats Navratilova: Martina Navratilova will have to wait for another shot at Steffi Graf. While Graf, the top-ranked women's player, pounded out a 6-4, 6-2 semifinal victory yesterday over Judith Wiesner of Austria in 70 minutes, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario of Spain upset second-ranked Navratilova, 6-1, 6-7, 6-2, at the Citizen Cup tournament in Hamburg, West Germany.
LEAD: SEPTEMBER By Rosamunde Pilcher. 536 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/ St. Martin's Press. $22.95.

LEAD: A supply of Uzi machine guns and other weapons, approved by the Israeli Government last year for shipment to the eastern Caribbean island of Antigua, wound up instead in the hands of one of Colombia's most notorious drug traffickers.

LEAD: JUST in case Congress had any doubt that cutting billions of dollars from the Pentagon budget might be easier in theory than reality, some imaginative defense contractors left a little reminder at the foot of the Capitol a few weeks ago: a gleaming white aircraft, not quite plane and not quite helicopter, known as the V-22
LEAD: Twenty-two resplendent yachts, ready for racing after a three-and-a-half week layover in balmy Florida, set off for England today in the last leg of the Whitbred Round the World Race.

LEAD: Nina Hyde, the fashion editor of The Washington Post and a pacesetter in the fields of style and fashion, died Friday night after a long bout with breast cancer at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. She was 57 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: Leading off with the Kentucky Derby, an elite group of 3-year-olds are asked to go a mile and a quarter, longer than any distance they have ever run. The Derby usually attracts 15-20 horses and the post positions and traffic problems experienced on the Churchill Downs oval can play a big role in the outcome.

LEAD: One of the main problems in assessing film documentaries can be found in the French word for the camera lens: l'objectif. With its implications of objectivity, it crystallizes what most viewers assume about a documentary - that it is more ''real'' than a fiction film.

LEAD: When John A. Marino, the state Democratic chairman, accepted an invitation last January from Dennis Mehiel, the new Westchester Democratic leader, to ''energize the troops'' at the party's yearly victory breakfast, he did not realize that his job would be only half done.

LEAD: As devotees of ''L.A. Law'' are aware, there's been a change at the top at McKenzie, Brackman, Chaney, Kuzak & Becker. Leland McKenzie (played by Richard Dysart), the firm's guiding eminence grise and the show's moral weathervane, stunned his colleagues by stepping down earlier this season as senior partner.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II is scheduled to arrive here Sunday to begin a weeklong visit to a country whose people are overwhelmingly Roman Catholic but whose Government maintains no diplomatic relations with the Vatican and has a tense relationship with the local church.

LEAD: The middle-aged men stood along the first-base line on Opening Day, soon after the parade that led all the children to the start of the 1990 Little League season at Michael Yatsko Field. Beyond the center-field fence, the electronic scoreboard had been set to the moment that connected the lives of those men and this town three decades before; the home team winning, 5-0, in the final inning of the championship game of the 14th Little League World Series.

LEAD: HOW can a building be preserved? By landmark designation? By careful, expensive restoration? By finding appropriate new uses?

LEAD: Representative Bob Walker has a worthy pet cause. The Pennsylvania Republican wants to restore the integrity of the Congressional Record, the official chronicle of both houses' proceedings. Last month he saw anew why reform is needed. It occurred when Mr. Walker tried to offer an amendment to a G.O.P.

LEAD: When Craig McCaw's father died in 1969, the McCaw children and their mother discovered that the elder McCaw had so buried his media business in debt that only a single cable-television system remained when all the creditors had been paid off. John Elroy McCaw had had big dreams about building a media empire and he had taken big risks.

LEAD: A pink granite fountain, New York City's first large monument honoring a woman, sits in regal if dusty disrepair at the western end of Bryant Park. It needs extensive restoration and new plumbing and electrical equipment that will cost about $175,000.

LEAD: A few years back, investors were flocking to a new medical technology involving microscopic bubbles called liposomes. Composed of molecules of fatty acids, liposomes promised a way to administer drugs that ordinarily are too toxic to take in heavy doses.

LEAD: White. It's the most basic of colors, yet the most complex. Indeed, the very word conjures up a host of contrasts. White connotes purity and cleanliness, simplicity and elegance. It also represents the harsh, crisp lines of modern architecture as well as the almost chalk-like quality of rustic rooms.

LEAD: ''EACH cabin comes equipped with fresh linens, towels, an ice chest, propane stove, pots, pans, necessary utensils and two lizards. If any of these items are missing when you leave, we won't refund your $30 deposit.'' These were among the first instructions we received as we checked into the Maho Bay Campground in the Caribbean late one night in midwinter.

LEAD: BETTING on the power of extraordinary views to sell housing, the DeMatteis Organization of Elmont, L.I., has begun putting up a 52-story residential building in an unlikely location in lower Manhattan.

LEAD: Neil T. Maffeo, a television producer, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 55 years old.

LEAD: Concordia was founded as a school in 1861, then in 1865 was transformed into a liberal arts college that has since developed a reputation for music education. Its red and white brick building makes an imposing landmark at 171 White Plains Post Road and, the Tudor facade with its leaded windows and the quadrangle behind speak of Old England, roast beef and all.

LEAD: An article on April 22 about the Childrenswear Center in A. & S. Plaza misidentified its architect. It was Carol Groh & Associates.

LEAD: Summer is coming to Sind. The dry earth and stones are baked by a white sun that fires temperatures up to 120 degrees. In the farming villages along the Indus River, the political base of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, it should be the start of an outdoor season, a time to stray from small mudbrick houses to search the dark evenings for a less suffocating place to rest.

LEAD: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York Deborah Lee Thielsch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Helmut Thielsch of Cranston, R.I., was married yesterday to Robert Sol Slotpole, the son of Sonja Fox of Tavares, Fla., and the late Sol Slotpole. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Donald MacArthur, a former treasurer of Sears, Roebuck & Company, died Thursday of heart failure at the Lansing Holiday Inn, outside Chicago, while traveling to Wisconsin. He was 88 years old and a resident of Sarasota, Fla., and Antigo, Wis.
LEAD: A four-day-old fire that had already charred 25,000 acres of the Everglades and threatened a Federal wildlife preserve was brought under control late Friday with the help of scattered showers.
LEAD: Smith College has ended its system of admitting students without regard to their ability to pay.

LEAD: LIKE a man running to catch a train that is accelerating out of the station, President Bush keeps falling behind the breathtaking pace of events in Europe. To catch up, he has had to keep altering his ideas on the future of that continent, and the role the United States can play there in the decades to come.

LEAD: Tom Telemark, the globe-trotting photojournalist, appeared at my door last week all excited. ''Guess what I got!'' he asked. ''Rollerblades?'' I guessed, wrongly. ''No, a new camera outfit,'' he said.
LEAD: The first of 200 political detainees participating in an experimental parole project of the Immigration and Naturalization Service was released on Friday.

LEAD: Three new construction projects that will use $15 million in state funds to build 182 apartments in Manhattan have been approved by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal as part of its $128 million program for fast-track housing for low-income and homeless people. The program was started last year as an effort to cut red tape and accelerate the development of new apartment projects in areas lacking affordable housing.

LEAD: THE BUDDHA OF SUBURBIA By Hanif Kureishi. 284 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.
LEAD: Marta Renzi and the Project Company mixed choreographic pleasures with theatrical blunders on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

LEAD: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement. This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system. The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak. Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help. Any suggestions?

LEAD: The engagement of Caroline Cornelius Clayton to Christopher R. Tufts, a son of Margaret Baker Tufts of Marblehead, Mass., and the late Robert Rider Tufts, has been announced by the mother of the future bride, Dr. Loretta Cornelius of Virginia Beach, Va. A December wedding is planned.

LEAD: A Federal jury has acquitted a businessman of charges that he lied to a judge two years ago when he said Reagan-Bush campaign officials asked Iran in October 1980 not to free 52 American hostages until after the Presidential election.

LEAD: FROM the ground up - indeed, from beneath the ground up - 17 State Street has proved at almost every turn to be troubled. But there are new signs of life at the largely empty 42-story tower overlooking the Battery, which will soon be distinguished by one of the more unusual examples of a developer's ''penance'' for running afoul of New York City land-use procedure.

LEAD: Why is the Triple Crown won so rarely? It's because few horses can hit for both power and average. JAMES ACKROYD Teaneck, N.J.

LEAD: AT the end of a tortuous odyssey to reclaim his soul and realize his black identity, Tod, the very model of establishment success - white establishment success - reaches an epiphanic moment. It sounds all too obvious, contrived and even ambiguous, but the message of solidarity he arrives at has the intimations of idealism and a hint of inspiration.
LEAD: The United States national soccer team had a pleasant enough afternoon today in its first of four games before it departs for Europe and the World Cup finals in Italy.

LEAD: Make no mistake, rare wine is money, as Frank J. Prial indicates in his wine column ''What Price Glory?: Too High'' (March 25). I know of people who have gone broke and been saved by their wine collections. Recently, a young stockbroker lost his job. He was also divorced. All he had was a nifty cellar that had cost him $100,000 in the late 1970's.

LEAD: WILD AT HEART: The Story of Sailor and Lula. By Barry Gifford. (Grove Weidenfeld, $15.95.) Barry Gifford's fourth novel (which David Lynch, the director of ''Blue Velvet,'' is bringing to the screen) is made up mostly of conversations in cars, Southern variety. In ''Wild at Heart,'' Sailor Ripley, fresh from two years in a North Carolina prison farm, breaks parole and hits the road for dream-bright California.

LEAD: Elizabeth Cooke Johnson and David Christopher Nixon, 1982 graduates of Princeton University, are planning a September wedding, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Hallett Johnson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced. Mr. Nixon is a son of James T. Nixon of Kansas City, Mo., and Dorothy Jane Nixon of Prairie Village, Kan.

LEAD: Recently two letter writers opposed giving grades in an attempt to improve pupils' self-esteem. Do they really think children can be kept from knowing how well or poorly they are doing? Children know. The absence of marks, if anything, would make achievement less important in their eyes. Also, promoting an unprepared child would quickly destroy what was left of his self-confidence.

LEAD: Gail Lyn May and Alfred Benjamin Engelberg were married last evening at the Plaza in New York by Rabbi Helene Ferris. Mrs. Engelberg is the daughter of Carol May of Sausalito, Calif., and the late William L. May. Her husband is the son of Gusti Engleberg of Atlantic City.

LEAD: The Intel Corporation's strategic staffing manager, Alexis DiFirenzi-Swale, is filling 19 jobs through University Pronet, an electronic data base of graduates from several universities that is headquartered at Stanford University in California, because it offers ''a focused shot into the precise groups we wish to hire from.

LEAD: Lending himself to a host of needs, generous in his willingness to do what's wanted of him, Hamlet is the supremely adaptable dramatic character. Though the occasion of his crisis is the need to avenge his father's murder, something far less specific is involved: a universality of dilemma and anguish; a noble soul forced to act ignobly, an honest one forced to lie.
LEAD: Mike Morgan pitched a six-hitter for his second shutout of the season as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Philadelphia Phillies today, 3-0.
LEAD: When is a 54 percent cut in profits good news? When it's from General Motors.

LEAD: ''Hospitals Grapple With Ethical Issues'' (March 4) stated that Long Island Jewish and Albert Einstein Hospitals are discussing forming a regional ethics committee network to help train ethics committee members and act as a clearinghouse on hospital policies. The Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre has already done this for its hospitals in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

LEAD: IN the United States, practically every fairground, boardwalk and carnival has a cotton candy stand; until not so long ago similar places in the Netherlands had a poffertjes pavilion. LEAD: The harsh plains of North Dakota, with their sparse population and conservative sensibilities, have always presented a hostile landscape for women seeking abortions.

LEAD: Led by a supervising electrician in the Department of Correction who was paid more than the Mayor, New York City employees made $426 million in overtime last year, a city report says.

LEAD: As owner of one of the world's largest fleets, P. N. Tsakos, the president of a Greek shipping line that bears his name, should be relishing his industry's recovery from a decade-long depression in shipping and shipbuilding. Instead, he frets about whether to place large new orders for ships. If he hesitates, prices may rise and shipyards may be booked for years, keeping him from expanding.

LEAD: Hugh Richmond gives no midterms or final exams in his ''Shakespeare in the Theater'' class at the University of California at Berkeley. For this English professor's students, all the world's a stage, and his students are the players.

LEAD: Cruising the Amazon Q. We would like to take a cruise up the Amazon River to Manaus. What is the best season and which cruise lines make the trip? -Doris Schuller, Rego Park, Queens A. Several cruise ships offer itineraries to or from Manaus, about 1,000 miles up the Amazon. Naturalists who point out the flora and fauna and lecturers in the history, anthropology and ecology of the region are often on board.

LEAD: Ten days into the Likud Party's effort to form a new Government, the interim Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, is finding that he must deal with many of the same problems that caused the Labor Party's coalition negotiations to fail.

LEAD: No one knows for sure yet, but rentals for movies at the video store - now in the $2.50 to $3 range - could take a jump in the next few months. Rent is connected to price, both retail and wholesale. Blaming higher costs and a soft rental market, four major studios - Warner, Paramount, MCA/Universal and RCA/Columbia - are raising the retail list prices of rental ''A titles'' (the best-known movies) from the $89.95 level prevalent since 1986 to $92.95 or thereabouts.

LEAD: Patricia Elin Brenner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Brenner of New York, was married last evening at the Metropolitan Club to Mark Frederick Jackson, a son of Mrs. John Jackson Jr. of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Jackson. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Homeless families are often baffled by New York City's maze of services. Now 11 women from midtown Manhattan welfare hotels offer help: ''The Survival Manual (Useful Information for People Who Have to Live in the Hotels for Displaced Families).''
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

When state governments redraw the boundaries of Congressional and state legislative districts next year, changes in Federal law will virtually obligate them to create districts with predominantly black or

LEAD: Heinrich Schiff is a cellist of reassuring solidity. There is no part of his technique not firmly in place. Intonation, color, steadiness of bow - all gave Wednesday's audience at the 92d Street Y the feeling that no matter how trying the technical problems, how exhausting the demands of concentration, the music would emerge whole and satisfying.

LEAD: I TAPED a big road map of Italy to our kitchen wall. Each day I asked our children to point out the spots where we would be staying. Roma, Gubbio, Sicilia. Friends warned us that the kids were a little young for a backpacking adventure - Rhodes, just 3, and Metthea, 5. But Ali and I were eager to get back to the country that had intoxicated us on an earlier, childless trip.
LEAD: LODZ GHETTO Inside a Community Under Siege. Edited by Alan Adelson and Robert Lapides. Illustrated. 526 pp. New York: Viking. $29.95.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: A review on April 22 about the exhibition ''Theater on Paper'' at the Drawing Center misstated the closing date. It is July 21.

LEAD: The major combatants of World War II opened formal talks on German reunification today with the Soviet Union emphasizing that it did not intend to let a united Germany slide easily into the Western orbit.

LEAD: A map on April 15 with an article about San Cristobal de las Casas, Mexico, omitted the identity of the country bounded by Mexico and Guatemala. It is Belize.
LEAD: The original version of this menu was created after this year's first purchase of local asparagus, scallions and what the vendor called black fish.

LEAD: In May of a thoroughbred's third year, the horse has not yet fully matured physically. With the Triple Crown races running close together, it is difficult for a young horse to run three strong races consecutively. Also, the Triple Crown closes with the Belmont Stakes at a mile and a half. This grueling distance often proves too much for even the best of horses.

Say, Disney needs some office space in New York City.
LEAD: When people get bruised, cut or fatigued, their nervous systems send signals of pain and soreness that effectively warn them to address the problem before it leads to more serious damage.

LEAD: The California Supreme Court has ruled that reporters can be required to testify in a criminal case they know about from their reporting if their testimony would help the defense.

LEAD: ''Today we engage in an act of reconciliation, of a people too long separated, of a continent too long divided.'' - Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. [1:6.]

LEAD: AS the crowd filed into the assembly room of the Harwinton Town Hall on a recent Tuesday evening, Lawrence Connors anxiously scanned their faces. He was relieved, he said, to see many of those who supported the establishment of the town's first historic districts. But he also saw many neighbors who he thought were opposed to the plan.
LEAD: The graves of Bertolt Brecht and his wife have been vandalized and smeared with anti-Semitic slogans, the official East German press agency said today.

LEAD: Benjamin Ellis Tenzer, a metallurgical engineer who was involved in reform Democratic politics in Brooklyn, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis at his home in Brooklyn last Wednesday. He was 54 years old.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has condemned Latvia's declaration of independence as a ''violation of constitutional norms'' and held out the possibility of economic or political retaliation, the official press agency Tass said early today.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

LEAD: Frances A. Genter received her marching orders this winter in Florida. Or rather her flying orders. Carl Nafzger, the man who trains her race horses, gave her this ultimatum: ''We will get you a box with a television, but you are going to the Kentucky Derby,'' with the emphasis on the ''are.''

LEAD: Amy Treadwell Richardson and Joseph Thomas Spinelli were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston by the Rev. David P. Curry. Mrs. Spinelli, 26 years old, is a daughter of Ellen L. Richardson of Brookline, Mass., and Ralph E. Richardson of New York. A graduate of Wesleyan University, she is an officer in the specialized finance group at the Bank of Boston.
LEAD: A picture caption on the television page last Sunday about the series ''Cheers'' misidentified the character played by Kirstie Alley. She is the manager of the bar, not a waitress.

LEAD: The return of Chief Inspector Morse in the latest offering from ''Mystery!,'' which began Thursday on PBS, also means the return of his indulgent, intelligent, uninspired, unflappable sidekick, Sergeant Lewis. The second banana is a staple of the detective story in its classic British form, for very practical reasons.

LEAD: It's not really important. In fact, it probably ranks somewhere near the bottom of any list of things that need to be or should be seriously considered. Nevertheless, unimportant things can often be irritating, frustrating or embarrassing and sometimes all three.

LEAD: George H. Davis, a geology professor and administrator at the University of Arizona, has been named president of the University of Vermont, the school's trustees announced yesterday. Dr. Davis, who is 47 years old, succeeds Lattie F. Coor, who left the school last December to become president of Arizona State University.

LEAD: ''I've had an amazing year, absolutely,'' Michael Blakemore said enthusiastically, as he sipped coffee one recent morning on the top floor of the renovated north London almshouse where he lives. The 61-year-old Australian director is currently represented on Broadway by two hits - ''City of Angels'' at the Virginia Theater and ''Lettice and Lovage'' at the Ethel Barrymore - and if he seemed exultant, who could blame him?
LEAD: A rural area south of Dallas was swept today by what the National Weather Service described as ''an extraordinary, record-breaking flood.''

LEAD: In his 20's he was known as D. D. Dominick, designing sweaters and colorful sportswear for his contemporaries and selling them in his own New York boutique, first on East 51st Street then on 60th Street. Now he is 45 years old and using his full name, Dominick Avellino, for a line of light-hearted sportswear that he is designing for the company Worlds
LEAD: Sidney Kalikow, a Queens real-estate developer, died on Friday in Long Island Jewish Hospital after a 36-year battle with Parkinson's disease. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: A couple of decades ago an Italian designer named Emilio Pucci slipcovered the fashion world with wild and colorful patterns that looked as if they had just floated up from the bottom of the sea. So guess what's bobbed back up? Pucci's dazzling designs. They are with us once more, on silk and cotton shirts, dresses, scarfs, handbags, and on something that wasn't around in the 50's and 60's - Lycra stretch tights.

LEAD: Terry Van Tell and Gilbert R. Gabriel Jr. were married yesterday at their home in New York by the Rev. Richard L. Leonard, a Unitarian minister. The bride, who will keep her name, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Vantella of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The bride, who took the last name of Van Tell when she was a radio and television actress, attended Vassar College and the Juilliard School.

LEAD: Striking Greyhound drivers and the bus line resumed negotiations today, their first contract talks since mid-March. The action came a day after the company reported a $56 million loss for the first three months this year.

LEAD: NEW YORK STATE is not a nation, but at times last week on this Mohawk reservation it seemed as though Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was conducting foreign policy of a most precarious nature. Ten months of increasingly bitter tensions among armed Mohawk factions over the issue of allowing casino gambling spilled over into violence, leaving two

LEAD: Twenty years later, it's remembered for Willis Reed trying not to limp when he finally walked onto the court to a roar that shook Madison Square Garden. It's remembered for the 6-foot-9-inch center hitting his first two shots, detonating other roars that shook the Lakers. And it's remembered for the Knicks sweeping to a 113-99 victory for the 1970 National Basketball
LEAD: THE GOLDEN ORANGE By Joseph Wambaugh. 317 pp. New York: Perigord Press/ William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: The United States Ambassador has found himself in the middle of a fierce political debate about whether this East African nation and ally of Washington should replace its one-party state with a multiparty system.

Murchison Jr., a son of Donna Murchison of Melbourne, Fla., and Dick K. Murchison Sr. of Danbury, Conn. The Rev. Walter H. Everett performed the ceremony at the Stamford (Conn.) Marriott

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Ira F. Ehrenkranz have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Meg Ehrenkranz, and David S. Eiten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myles Eiten of Great Neck, L.I. Miss Ehrenkranz, 26 years old, graduated from Syracuse University and is the office manager at Harmat Homes, a building company in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

LEAD: FOR generations, dairy has been synonomous with ''pure,'' beef with ''strong.'' And cattle have ranged over the soul of America, a symbol of wide-open spaces, broncobuster spirit and the bucolic life on the family farm.

LEAD: Pamela Jennifer Macleod and James Leon Daigle 4th were married yesterday at Mountain Lakes House in Princeton, N.J. John J. Flood, the mayor of West Windsor Township, N.J., performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a review on April 8 about recordings of English music misstated the relationship between Ralph Vaughan Williams and Hubert Parry and misattributed the composition ''Toward the Unknown Region.'' Parry was Vaughan Williams's teacher, not the reverse. The composition is by Vaughan Williams.

LEAD: Any cap on mutual fund fees should be good news for investors. But the recent proposal by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which aims to save investors money by revamping rules for how funds finance their sales operations, may not work that way.

LEAD: It's apple blossom time in the Hudson Valley - more than a week earlier than usual because of a heat wave late last month. Many of the area's apple trees are burgeoning with white blossoms, a harbinger of a good apple crop, if they are not hit by a cold spell this week or next.

LEAD: Jack Clark, the San Diego Padres first baseman, has received permission from the National League to change his uniform number for the fifth time in his 14-year major league career. He will now wear 00.

LEAD: Robert Parish, his pride evidently still stinging, brusquely left practice here today, waving away reporters in what seemed part of a larger attempt to erase all reminders of the debacle the Celtics had endured less than 24 hours earlier at the hands of the Knicks.

LEAD: THESE POLITICIANS want Bush to lay down a marker for all the world to see,'' wrote the columnists Evans and Novak in their muscular style, ''no matter how much discomfort it brings Gorbachev and his trading pals in Bonn.''

LEAD: The Knicks and the Boston Celtics are even at two games each in their three-of-five-game opening-round playoff series. The deciding game will be played today in the ancient Boston Garden, where 16 Celtic championship banners hang from the dusty rafters.

LEAD: The senior vice president rested a hand on my shoulder. ''You sure don't look like a Girl Scout,'' he said. ''We're changing with the times,'' I answered. ''Now, are you going to order or not?''
LEAD: Frank Cannonito is a 63-year-old math professor at the University of California at Irvine, and he has not published much lately. But he is not about to let his career perish either.

LEAD: Belmar $125,000 407 Wildwood Place 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 64-year-old ranch; porch, full basement, 2-car garage, patio; taxes $1,800. Howell $169,500 5 Heritage Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; c/a, 2-car garage, w/w carpeting; taxes $3,362.

LEAD: Headlines last Sunday with an article about politics in Afghanistan referred incorrectly in some copies to the anniversary being observed there. It was the 12th anniversary of the coup that brought a Communist Government to power.

LEAD: One of the most debated ideas that the United Nations has ever put forward - its call for a ''new world information and communications order,'' which would sanction government control of news organizations - is slowly fading away.

LEAD: HE has six names and once played for the master baseball showman Bill Veeck, so it should come as no real surprise that at the age of 67, Saturnino Orestes Arrieta Armas (Minnie) Minoso will be called out of retirement for the third time to extend his claim on major league history by playing in his sixth decade as a major leaguer.

LEAD: Because of a plan change by the publishers, a review of ''Landscapes of a New Land: Fiction by Latin American Women'' last Sunday misstated the book's format. It is available from White Pine Press in paperback only.
LEAD: Lava from Kilauea Volcano cut the last road out of this coastal town today and nearly encircled a church and the town's store in the heart of the village.
LEAD: Exuberant accessories that celebrate themselves will be turning up at the water's edge this summer.

LEAD: Their roots may spring from Marilyn Monroe, Jayne Mansfield and Jean Harlow, but the new generation of blondes is not breathless and bawdy. They are the brainy blondes, and their hair color has no relation to their I.Q.'s.

LEAD: One difficult factor in winning the Triple Crown is that unlike other tournaments, new participants may enter during later rounds. But during the Triple Crown, a fresh contender may enter the Belmont only. That horse is in a much better position to win the final jewel than a horse that has raced and moved twice before the last leg.
LEAD: PLACIDO CRUZ MARTIN does not remember much of the night of Jan. 25, when the Avianca passenger jet crashed in Cove Neck.

LEAD: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement. This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system. The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak. Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help. Any suggestions?

LEAD: Crime Threatens Bhutto Increasing lawlessness seems to be weakening support for Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan, who promised a new era of social change when she took office. Page 18. New Hope in South Africa The successful talks between the Government and the African National Congress are raising hopes that the old enemies could hasten the demise of apartheid.
LEAD: About 15 University of Kansas students gathered last week to roast hot dogs and to honor several graduating seniors for their hard work, determination and drive. Especially their drive.

LEAD: IF President Bush goes back to his ancestral roots he will find himself in a rustic corner of England, where many things remain as they were when his Puritan forefather, Reynold Bush, set sail for America in 1631, settling in Cambridge, Mass.

LEAD: REMEMBER the late 70's, when designs for solar systems like rooftop collectors, greenhouses and heat pumps were pouring off the drawing boards as fast as fuel prices rose? Fuel shortages were predicted and tax credits for renewable-energy installations tempted homeowners.

LEAD: For the last nine months, Oregon residents from all walks of life have been working to rank medical procedures so that government health insurance could benefit the greatest number of people, knowing their decisions might contribute to somebody's death or cause prolonged suffering.

LEAD: Canada is an opportunity waiting to happen. The opportunities center on commodities stocks, from copper to paper products, which play a major role in the economy and are expected to benefit from both an expected rebound in the Canadian economy and the recent rise in commodities prices.

LEAD: For years coaches have used high-speed motion pictures as training aids. Now, video technology has been combined with computers and tiny sensors that monitor muscle movements to give a far more detailed analysis of human motion. According to Gary L. Scheirman, manager of biomechanics at Peak Performance Technologies Inc.
LEAD: A report in the Long Island Journal column last Sunday about an AIDS essay contest misstated the rules. Only high schools that submit winning entries will receive $250 grants.

LEAD: AN unlikely, almost unbelievable adobe hacienda, complete with views of the water, has taken root in Island Park. Coyote Grill is unbelievable in another respect: its food is almost too good to be true.

LEAD: Tess Leopold and Gerald Allen were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York by the Rev. Alfred Gately. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Robert W. Sweet of New York and A. Frederic Leopold of Los Angeles. Mr. Allen is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Allen of Great Kills, S

LEAD: Judging from your cover photograph (five white women), and the article's straight, white, New York orientation, one could draw the mistaken conclusion that feminism has not had an impact on public consciousness about homophobia, ageism, class, racism.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

LEAD: The marriage of Laura Mok, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yuen Mok of New York, to Dr. Mark Richard Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Anderson of Katonah, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Stonehenge Inn in Ridgefield, Conn. Deborah O. Stiewing, a justice of the peace of Newtown, Conn., officiated.

LEAD: Since 1986, a popular class, ''Black and White,'' at Southern Methodist University has tried to teach a new philosophy of race relations: simply put, it is not that blacks need to change but that whites must accept them socially.

LEAD: With the humbling of Vietnam in Cambodia, political and ideological tensions in Southeast Asia have been significantly reduced. But an arms race in the Asian and Pacific region is eating up the potential benefits from peace.

LEAD: Our involvement in Vietnam must be a subject in every school and college [''What Should Schools Teach About Vietnam?'' March 25] . However, I would suggest that the instructor begin and end the course on Vietnam with the fact that our Government and people were abysmally ignorant of the subject when the decision was made to get involved.

LEAD: An office building under construction here is the first of a dozen Federal projects throughout the United States that will use a development method that involves long-term leases rather than outright purchases of new buildings the Government commissions for its own occupancy.

LEAD: A few Friday nights ago, Erik La Prade climbed three flights of stairs to the West 30th Street loft that is both home and theater for Doloris Holmes. For a contribution ($6 was suggested), he and some four dozen others saw ''Fish Joy and the Goddess of Red Mud,'' a play written by, directed by and starring Miss Holmes.

LEAD: AFTER spending 11 months in a prison cell convicted of insider trading, Robert Chestman was a free man last week, his sentence cut short by a Federal appeals court that threw out his conviction. In its decision, the court reached several surprising conclusions, but one seemed to stand out: the Government had failed to provide sufficient evidence that Mr.

LEAD: Lawmakers from both parties are calling for a broad expansion of the authority of the independent prosecutor appointed to investigate Ronald Reagan's Housing Secretary, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. Responding to what they describe as startling new testimony from an imprisoned former deputy of Mr. Pierce, House members say they are convinced that senior aides to Mr.

LEAD: THE employment numbers for April took the market by surprise on Friday and knocked the dollar lower. The surprise was that the report showed a weaker economy than expected. Rather than declining, the unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.4 percent. After adjusting for an influx of census workers, non-farm payroll jobs declined.

LEAD: Robin Rhys Riggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Riggs Jr. of Providence, R.I., and David Arthur Fish, a son of Mrs. Arthur C. Fish of Holden, Mass., and the late Mr. Fish, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J. Daniel Burke at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Providence.

LEAD: A woman who tried to sell a stolen car radio to people in a Brooklyn restaurant died yesterday morning after a man who was having breakfast there said the radio was his and attacked her with a club, the police said.

LEAD: Peter Applebome nearly touches an important truth about the New South (''Is It True What He Says About Dixie?'' April 8). As he observes, Lewis Grizzard is selling ''the South as nostalgia,'' a land of charm and gentility. But many of the people who pine most deeply for the Old South have spent their adult lives escaping it.

LEAD: My thanks to Vivian Gornick for her splendid article. I have been taking two steps forward and one back as a feminist, along with the movement, for the last 30 years. Having been forced into marriage by an unplanned pregnancy at the age of 18 and after spending years on welfare, working at sundry low-paying jobs, raising my son by myself, I have managed to get a B.A., M.F.A.

LEAD: Frank Miller looks forward to dinner every night, but Saturdays are special. On a recent Saturday, Mr. Miller dined on duck stew prepared by the chef at Livanos restaurant at 200 Central Avenue in White Plains. But Mr. Miller was not a patron of the restaurant. He and 76 other homeless people ate their gourmet meal at the shelter for the homeless at the Westchester County

LEAD: I read in earnest Pete Dunne's March 18 column, ''In the Natural State,'' in which he reflects on the recent developments in Eastern Europe. He goes on to concede his embarrassment because he admits that he never gave the people of Eastern Europe the respect for self-determination they have proved to deserve.

LEAD: For Shelley Hirsch, the past is less a story told than a pastiche of surviving impressions. Her one-woman show, ''O Little Town of East New York,'' may begin in the neighborhood of her childhood and end with the wreckage it is today, but in between is a rich jumble of friends, family, scenes and situations remembered.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Paradise regained? Anyone who thinks - as many do - that American Ballet Theater misplaced its soul during the decade that Mikhail Baryshnikov was its artistic director will now be closely watching a new regime determined to redefine the company's identity. Tomorrow's opening of the troupe's 50th-anniversary season in New York at the Metropolitan Opera House begins an era in which Jane Hermann and Oliver Smith, the recently named co-directors, promise to restore certain names and policies identified with Ballet Theater's past.

LEAD: Something had to give. After years of living with brown lipstick, taupe eyeshadow, imperceptible blusher and transparent mascara, a little visible makeup comes as a relief. Pale, powdery pink, faint peach, light banana and - would you believe it - light blue are being revived in fashion and in makeup.

LEAD: Drugstore Cowboy 1989. I.V.E. $89.95. Laser disk, $39.95. 1 hour 44 minutes. R. Gus van Sant Jr.'s glum, absorbing film, set in Portland, Ore., in 1971, offers a cool-eyed vision of young heroin adicts adrift during the twilight of the counterculture. Matt Dillon, Kelly Lynch and friends wander the Northwest looting pharmacies the way Bonnie and Clyde cleaned out banks.
LEAD: The meadow had a lot of flowers and bees. There was a big hill, and you could roll down it and just sit there and look at the flowers. - Rosalina, age 9.

LEAD: Layne Schmidt Ridley and Deane Mann Evans Jr. were married yesterday at the Tabard Inn in Washington. Judith Toth, a leader of the Washington Ethical Society, officiated. Mrs. Evans is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Schmidt of Norman, Okla. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans of Darien, Conn.

LEAD: ''We're getting more inquiries than ever before from patients who don't understand their bills,'' said Maureen Nemeth, the coordinator of credit and collection for inpatient accounts at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco. ''Filing medical insurance claims has become very confusing for the public, especially as benefits keep changing.

LEAD: ''The Belly of an Architect'' was shown as part of the 1987 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 1, 1987. The film opened on Friday at the Bleecker Street Cinema, at La Guardia Place.

LEAD: Steve Lacy, the expatriate American saxophonist, is a master of stasis. Where most jazz musicians bull their way through tunes, leaving notes as a motorboat leaves a wake, Mr. Lacy mulls each phrase over and over. He will play an idea, then repeat it, bending the last note. Or he will add a few notes, or drop some.

LEAD: COMING upon the island of Patmos in darkness, the presence of the church is merely a whisper in the traveler's ear. There is something different about Patmos, even in the evening hours. No loud throbbing beat of American pop greets you at the dock, no desperate hotel representatives shove photographs of their accommodations in your face.

LEAD: How to increase public participation in tagging programs involving various marine species of game and food fish was a concern of those who attended a recent two-day workshop at the Woods Hole (Mass.) Oceanographic Institution.

LEAD: An elderly black woman stood outside the airport terminal this morning, awaiting the arrival of Albie Sachs, a veteran of the African National Congress who was returning home after 24 years in exile.

LEAD: Keep it simple, and keep it short. That's the way to go for spring and summer parties. Unless it's a white-tie affair, a long dress simply looks old this year. Short dresses look young and modern, especially when they bare the arms and shoulders.

LEAD: Amy Susan Rood, a daughter of Joanna M. Goddard of Burlington, Vt., and George M. Rood of New York, was married yesterday to T. Mark Brokering, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Herbert F. Brokering of Minneapolis. The bridegroom's father, a Lutheran minister, and the Rev. Richard P. Fowler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Victor Goldsmith of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Diane J. Goldsmith, and Carleton J. Schade, a son of Capt. Calvin Schade, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Schade of Ozark, Ala.
LEAD: FOREIGN STUDIES By Shusaku Endo. Translated by Mark Williams. 232 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

LEAD: The All About column last Sunday, about the home video-game business, misstated a sales estimate for the industry this year. According to Nintendo of America Inc., total sales are expected to reach $5.1 billion, of which Nintendo would account for $4.1 billion.

LEAD: For Hersey Hawkins, who scored a career-high 39 points, the playoff victory today was the highlight of his young career. For Charles Barkley, the victory represented another inspirational performance when his team needed it. And for the Philadelphia 76ers, the victory clinched a spot in the Eastern Conference semifinals, the farthest they have advanced in the National Basketball
LEAD: THE HAND Or, The Confession of an Executioner. By Yuz Aleshkovsky. Translated by Susan Brownsberger. 261 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95
LEAD: IS Britain really a democracy?

LEAD: As a rookie firefighter in Brooklyn in the 1950's, Ceaser William Sansevero had no idea what his first top-to-bottom firehouse inspection would lead to: a lifelong hobby collecting firefighting equipment.

LEAD: For a time it appeared that the long New York-New Jersey milk war was over, settled by a Federal court ruling that set aside New Jersey's protectionist milk regulations. But new rules quickly imposed by New Jersey are bringing the dispute back into court.

LEAD: The scene in Cape Town last week was as astonishing as anything in Eastern Europe: F. W. de Klerk, South Africa's President, and Nelson Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, sat at the same table and talked about a new constitutional order for their nation.

LEAD: THERE are limits to travel. You cannot sail up and down the River Styx with Charon, the boatman who took the dead to Hades in Greek myth, as your tour guide. Whatever your prospects for permanent residence there in the future, you cannot buy round-trip tickets to the place that the Greeks knew as Tartarus and we sometimes call Hell.

LEAD: FOR 10 years Albert Green, one of New Jersey's best-known potters, has been trying to solve an ancient puzzle. How did the Chinese potters of the Sung dynasty (A.D. 960-1280) create that greenish-blue celadon glaze they called Kuan? There are no books that explain 1,000-year-old glaze formulas.

LEAD: CONNECTICUT communities are joining a nationwide effort to bring elm trees back to their streets and parks. Most of the American elms that once graced the greens of the state's towns were wiped out decades ago by Dutch elm disease. But now, a nonprofit institute, led by a former Connecticut resident, is distributing disease-resistant elm saplings that can grow to provide beauty and shade in decades to come.

LEAD: Betty Ring's exquisitely stitched 18th- and 19th-century American samplers and embroideries abound with aphorisms and images copied from engravings. Mrs. Ring began collecting in 1960 and owns more than 400 pieces of needlework.
LEAD: IN ''Run for Your Wife,'' the English farce by Ray Cooney now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, John Smith, a taxi driver, is having a very, very bad morning.

LEAD: Dr. Shephard Stone, who had distinguished careers in journalism, diplomacy and philanthropy, died of a heart attack on Friday while driving from his home in South Newfane, Vt., to a conference at Dartmouth College. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: As a child in New York, Vima de Marchi Micheli learned classic Italian stitchery from her mother, grandmother and three aunts. ''I always considered needlework an art form, never a craft,'' she said.

LEAD: A would-be biochemistry major has moved the debate over frog dissection from its familiar high-school forum to the university. Jennifer Routh, a sophomore at the State University of New York at Stony Brook who is considering a career in medicine, is suing the school over the frog dissection requirement in an introductory biology course.

LEAD: I am troubled by Vivan Gornick's assumption that young women today are unwilling to be labeled ''feminist.'' This implies that they are not grateful or even aware of the sacrifices and gains made by pioneer feminists. I am a 26-year-old professional woman and I proudly call myself a feminist. I recognize the relative privilege of my position compared to women of the past, and I am grateful for the women's movement and the opportunities it has created for me.

LEAD: Crime against foreigners in the Soviet Union has dramatically increased in the last year, as outsiders, long isolated from Soviet society, find that their new ability to move freely has exposed them to greater danger.

LEAD: In its current economic mess, New York City can learn a lesson from the corner bodega owner. He will tell you: ''You need cash? The worst thing to do is raise prices and cut services. The best thing to do is trim inventory.'' The city should heed that advice and sell two major city-owned assets: John F.

LEAD: Bert Jay DeLeeuw, an organic farmer who was a former official of the National Welfare Rights Organization, died of a gunshot wound on Wednesday at J. C. Blair Hospital in Huntingdon, Pa. He was 44 years old and lived in Walker Township, Pa. The police arrested a neighbor and charged him with homicide.

LEAD: FOR now, life in Cape May is redolent of that in a small town, not a tourist haven. Streets aren't clogged with cars, and parking is as easy to find as solitude on an oceanfront jog. Best sellers still sit on shelves at the library, and there's no waiting anywhere, not at the Ugly Mug bar and restaurant, not at the Lobster House in Cape May
LEAD: In 1987, as part of the lingering celebration of their championship, the Mets adorned Shea Stadium with a sign that read, ''Baseball Like It Oughta Be.''

LEAD: THE HOLLOW DOLL: A Little box of Japanese Shocks. by William Bohnaker. (Available/Ballantine, Paper, $8.95.) It comes as no surprise to a reader of William Bohnaker's lively and gracefully written book that he is a student of Zen. He peppers ''The Hollow Doll'' with pronouncements that resemble Zen Koans, or parables, that he clearly knows so well - alternately insightful, maddening, profound and simplistic.

LEAD: Apparently, Vivian Gornick has been living in an ivory tower for so long that she considers conversations with fellow academics to represent the public at large (''Who Says We Haven't Made a Revolution?'' April 15). Even comments about the tribulations of welfare mothers come (secondhand) from doctoral students at Harvard.

Siphron of New York and Quogue, L.I. The Rev. John MacInnis, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Memorial Church in Cambridge,

LEAD: It's midnight, after the police roadblocks designed to thwart roving bands of robbers have gone up on the national highway. Several miles down a dirt road in the high jungle of Nigeria's northern plateau, within the snug confines of an old-fashioned general store, a raucous party is going on. A tightly packed group of people in tribal costume dance and sway to hypnotically rhythmic music, played by a small group on strange-looking instruments.

LEAD: Tears of sorrow have turned to shouts of defiance at Mills College, where students have vowed to shut the school until the trustees reverse their decision to end the institution's 138-year tradition as a women's college.

LEAD: For This Week: In colder regions it is still too early to plant tomatoes, eggplants, seed of any beans particularly limas, or squash, seedlings of impatiens and begonias; wait for another week or two because the soil and nights must be warm. Snap old flowers from pansy plants to keep them blooming.

LEAD: FROM childhood, I have loved walking and reading, ideally in close conjunction. A loaf of bread, a jug of wine? For me, a book and a backpack are enough. Especially if I can walk in the footsteps of one of my favorite authors.
LEAD: The idea hit Joseph Forlivio of Yonkers on a lonely return trip from his son's house in Brewster, where he had driven to pick up his 9-month-old grandson for a weekend visit.

LEAD: The stock market responded in predictable fashion to the news of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Country's latest effort to stem the flow of oil onto the world market. It bid up the price of some major oil companies a bit, anticipating that the pact might produce stronger earnings.
LEAD: In the aftermath of a brutal primary campaign, Ann Richards smoothly combines the roles of victim and victor.

LEAD: After living in the county all my life I have developed an inferiority complex. Although I can brag to people from Maine or Ohio that I am from New York (which is enough to impress someone from Maine or Ohio), whenever I meet people from Manhattan they treat me as if I am a country bumpkin.

LEAD: Rondi Charleston's concert on Monday night at Weill Recital Hall was not an ordinary song recital. It was the culmination of a new American Art Song Vocal Competition sponsored by the New York chapter of the National Association of Teachers of Singing. And it was preceded by an hour's worth of mini-recitals by the two runners-up.

LEAD: Catherine Williams Betts and Michael Wayne Woolaway were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Portola Valley, Calif. The bride's father, the Venerable Darby W. Betts, a retired Archdeacon of the Diocese of California, performed the ceremony.

''My wife, Ruth, born in Israel, became a naturalized citizen in 1962, in as short a period after our marriage as possible,'' Harry J. Hartz writes. LEAD: Recent regulations restrict the sale of ivory in hopes of saving the elephants. Wildlife biologists raise black-footed ferrets in an attempt to restore an almost extinct species. But what of the plight of wild plants?

LEAD: The recent more frequent emergence of sour-faced sweating grownups from IRT tunnels signals only one thing: summer is coming, and New York children share a goal with their over-heated parents - migrating out of town, quickly.

LEAD: Sometimes he directs. Sometimes he produces. Sometimes he makes comedies. Sometimes he makes musicals, and sometimes he makes dramas. But mostly he makes movies that people remember. He is Norman Jewison, the Canadian-born film maker who has been practicing his trade for close to 30 years.

LEAD: The victory was surgical in its precision, thorough in all its aspects, perfect to the extent that it was untarnished by so much as a single blemish on the scoreboard. And so it was hard not to sense, amid the smoky haze, acrid warmth and general euphoria of Boston Garden, the air of inevitability.

LEAD: One month after the Army said that it had charged a paratrooper with premeditated murder in Panama, the service has disclosed that it has filed murder charges against two other soldiers who took part in the invasion.

Reston of Washington. The Rev. William E. Basom, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the weekend home of the bridegroom's family.

After three days of talks in Mr. Rhodes's elegant dining room, the South African Government and the African National

LEAD: Mergers are surging in the European Community in anticipation of a more unified market in 1992. But the regulatory path is not an easy one. Parties must weave through a thicket of overlapping antitrust laws, filing requirements and waiting periods. American acquisitions in Europe have been blocked for protectionist reasons.

LEAD: Nicaraguan rebels today agreed with the new Government to begin disarming next week, and President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro pledged to start reducing the size of the Sandinista-controlled army. If carried out, the agreement will mean an end to a decade-old civil war between thousands of United States-backed contra rebels and the leftist Sandinista

LEAD: Through a complex series of transactions involving two brothers of the deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, the United States paid more than $40 million to Romania for Soviet military technology over a 10-year period, The Washington Post reported today.

LEAD: Two New York City Department of Correction officers were arrested yesterday in the March shooting and wounding of a man trying to repossess the car of one of the correction officers in the Bronx, the police said.

LEAD: Gail Susan Jeffee and Gerry Cohen were married last evening in the Pegasus Suite at the Rainbow Room in New York. Rabbi Tom Weiner and Cantor Richard Botton officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Jeffee of New York. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Cohen of Lido Beach, L

LEAD: THE COMBINATION IS AS CLASSIC AND familiar as hot fudge sauce thickening on a scoop of ice cream, or cool sour cream melting in a bowl of steaming borscht. There is the simple cup of hot cocoa dabbed with cold whipped cream, and the flamboyant baked Alaska - ice cream and cake wrapped in meringue and flambeed.

LEAD: MARBLED paper with glints of gold, a pop-up book revealing bright colors under patterned cutouts, a restored missal from 1502 and a little triangular book with a triangular leather slipcase are among the 70 works in ''Book Arts Exhibition 1990,'' at the Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Susan Rothenberg is back. With her blood-red heads stuck at both ends of a jump-rope-length bone, so that the two-headed figure becomes a gigantic baby rattle; with her dancers, gymnasts and acrobats so elastic that they can curve their bodies into O's and U's and put their feet behind their heads without bending their backs, and with her horses' heads as long as snakes and as rubbery as hoses, this 45-year-old painter has re-established herself as one of the most compelling artists of her generation.

LEAD: As one who saw Citation win the Triple Crown and who waited 25 years to see Secretariat complete the next Triple Crown, I would suggest that immature, injury-prone 3-year-olds (equivalent in age to a human teen-ager), competing on three different and widely differing race tracks within a short span of time, face a daunting challenge.
LEAD: To the Editor: I've found your Travel Watch section a useful guide for the business traveler, but I would like to point out an error in the $1 Equals . . . section.

LEAD: Betsey Vernizzi, an orthopedic nurse at St. Anthony Medical Center here, recalled a course she took nearly 20 years ago in nursing school. ''It was called ethics,'' she said. ''I was taught to say 'Yes, sir, no sir.' If a doctor walked into the nurse's station, you gave him your chair. I called them 'Doctor.

LEAD: MANY Americans are taking a kind of patriotic pride in submitting to roadblocks and airport questioning aimed at snaring drug smugglers; few are raising objections to the proliferation of urine testing and recent Supreme Court rulings that permit the police to hover over backyards in helicopters and poke into garbage cans without the old requirement of at least a glimmer of suspicion.

LEAD: Amanda Mandeville Mullally and Matthew Bouvy Drake were married yesterday at Trinity St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I. The Rev. Earle W. Pratt Jr. and the Rev. Edyth Baker officiated.

LEAD: Nine demonstrators were arrested yesterday in the Stapleton section of Staten Island during an otherwise peaceful protest by about 125 people against the construction of a Navy home port there, the police said.

LEAD: FOR A WHILE NOW, I'VE been thinking about planting a tree - a real tree. It's not that I haven't planted trees before, but all of these have been minor ones, lightweights really, the kind of trees you can justify in the short term: white pines to screen the road, dwarf fruit trees, a crab apple or two, a tree hydrangea and a pair of Salix babylonica, the Tree of Immediate Gratification, otherwise known as the weeping willow.

LEAD: While NATO ministers meeting in Europe this week have tried to maintain a business-as-usual demeanor toward Moscow, they are privately whispering about the possibilty that the Soviet Union could collapse into political turmoil before new arms-control deals are completed.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your special music festivals issue (Travel, April 29) was extremely interesting, but your readers should know that last year in Salzburg, so well known for its festival, when my husband and I attended a Palace Concert (at the Residenz) - an event billed as a chamber orchestra playing Haydn, Mozart and Dvorak - the orchestra turned out to be a group of young people (teen-agers, early 20's), who, while showing promise, were in no way professional musicians.

LEAD: Sarah Gatewood West, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Harrell West Jr. of Richmond, and Alexander Garden Reeves Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Reeves of Hanover, N.H., were married yesterday. The Rev. William Sachs officiated at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

LEAD: Fusion - of rhythms, ethnic groups and cultures - has vitalized Caribbean music for hundreds of years. A generation ago, the musical import-export trade proceeded at a steady but gradual pace. A Haitian group would tour Cuba and return with Latin songs in their set. Cuban records trickled down to Trinidad, influencing the horn arrangements of the calypsos.

LEAD: A SOPHISTICATED breed of householder who can oversee the building of a home without general contractors or architects is evolving through a fusion of do-it-yourself, building materials supermarkets and a tightened economy.
LEAD: IN Yale University's Sterling Memorial Library, 76 boxes of legal transcripts, letters, and rally posters recall the deaths of four students 20 years ago at Kent State University in Ohio.

LEAD: With the flood of new issues from new countries in recent years, many hobbyists have drifted away from the old routine of collecting one copy of every stamp as it comes out. LEAD: A report by the Iowa State Auditor's office has charged former University of Iowa student senators with spending university funds on ''extravagant'' expenses and sharply criticized the university's internal investigation of the student senate.

LEAD: One was the first man to clear 7 feet in the high jump. The other was the first to run an indoor mile in less than four minutes. The high-jumping Charles Dumas and the speedy Jim Beatty are among 10 candidates for a minimum of 3 places in the National Track and Field Hall of Fame in Indianapolis.

LEAD: THERESA AMMIRATI tells of the woman who applied for a job as a tutor at the Writing Center at Connecticut College in New London. The woman was startled when she was asked if she could work with learning-disabled students.

LEAD: The name of the play, ''New York 1937,'' sets the scene for Jose Yglesias's recollective piece being staged at the Jewish Repertory Theater.

LEAD: BEN NEILL SAYS THE MUSIC HE makes has the qualities of a conversation, not a new idea in ensemble playing, which Neill, 32, who was trained as a classical trumpet player, does a fair amount of. But he is speaking of solo work, talking with himself, as it were, which was the inspiration for the instrument he designed and built and is shown playing above.

LEAD: It may be a government of laws and not men, but New York's interest in the sentencing of Marsha Cohen had almost everything to do with who she is. Marsha Cohen is a dentist who treats AIDS patients and who, in a detour from middle-class life, slept on rooftops and helped break into apartments to support her heroin habit.

LEAD: The marriage of Charlene Denise Corbett and Victor Steven Tosi took place yesterday at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church on Gun Hill Road in the Bronx. The Rev. Robert Grix performed the ceremony.

LEAD: SCENE 1: THE OVAL OFFICE - A foreign leader is about to arrive at the White House. The flags of the visiting nation ripple down Pennsylvania Avenue. The Secretary of State hurries in to brief the President.

LEAD: American democracy is being undermined by citizens who are so indifferent to national elections that an ''astonishing'' number of them did not even know who the candidates for Vice President were in 1988, a commission said today after a two-year study of Presidential politics.
LEAD: You have seen the word: Fahrvergnugen.

LEAD: A combination of injury and illness brought new singers to two of the principal roles for the season's final performance of Wagner's ''Walkure'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday evening, in the last of three complete ''Ring'' cycles.

That was when rehearsals began for ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' and now the well-known theatrical names connected with the show have become familiar figures on the campus here.
LEAD: ''STAR WARS'' is still playing in some of the biggest halls in Connecticut. Concert halls, that is. And so are ''Lawrence of Arabia,'' ''Psycho'' and ''Platoon.''

LEAD: Traffic conditions on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway interchange adjacent to their village may be dangerous, but last winter nearly 250 Mamaroneck residents and village officials filled the Emelin Theater to demand that state highway officials solve their own problems without adding to the already heavy burden on local roads or without taking private property.

LEAD: In the first few minutes after the game, Dave Righetti seemed like a solitary figure sitting in front of his locker. He was slumped over, his elbows resting on his knees, his hands clasped tightly, his head down, his eyes still lost in the events of the night.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo moved today to force action on a new state budget that is already five weeks late by refusing to approve emergency legislation authorizing paychecks for 150,000 state workers.

LEAD: The New York State Urban Development Corporation is going to spend $65,000 to study the feasibility of moving Manhattan's century-old flower district to the Bronx. Vincent Tese, the corporation's chairman, said ''as the Bronx continues to show signs of economic vitality, U.D.C. is pleased to assist with studies to help industries to relocate there.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: CARL COCHRANE was introduced to the hard realities of today's sagging real estate market when he decided to sell his town house in Edison, N.J., and take a new job in Dallas.
LEAD: Unbridled soared past Summer Squall through the stretch to score a surprising 3 1/2-length victory today in the 116th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

LEAD: Trumpeted as Hollywood on the Hudson and organized by Robert De Niro, a former coffee warehouse in lower Manhattan opened this year as the TriBeCa Film Center, with production centers on seven floors and a stylish restaurant on the ground floor. Yet for all the attention people in the neighborhood are paying to it, it might still be the warehouse.

LEAD: Doctors have found lung scarring consistent with exposure to asbestos in more than a quarter of the veteran school custodians examined for a Board of Education study, indicating that the workers are at a high risk of developing cancer and other asbestos-related diseases.
LEAD: AMERICA'S ECONOMIC RESURGENCE A Bold New Strategy. By Richard Rosecrance. 230 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. D. Bret Carlson of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Carlson, to Timothy John Berners-Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Conway Berners-Lee of London. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: Somehow, despite the chaos, life in Athens makes sense. For those who can't unplug completely even when they've escaped to an island retreat, Athens is a crash course in relaxation without the deprivation of city amenities. Here, people don't ask what you do for a living until well into the conversation, sometimes never at all.
LEAD: I AM EN ROUTE TO VISIT my parents. They live, like so many other parents, in Florida - the recent configurations of my generation's lives are strikingly similar.

LEAD: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement. This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system. The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak. Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help. Any suggestions?

LEAD: He was the National Hockey League's most valuable player in 9 of the 10 previous seasons, and he led the league in scoring again this season, so there should be no surprise if Wayne Gretzky took his 10th Hart Trophy as the 1989-90 most valuable player. Except for one thing. Gretzky, who scored 40 goals and had 102 assists for a league-leading 142 points, is not among the three finalists nominated for the award.

LEAD: RECENTLY I found myself fondling a dollar bill of such limp antiquity that it called the entire concept of cash into question. This tattered, pale greenback had been in circulation since the late 60's, but were it not for its privileged isolation on the island of Cuba, it would long ago have been incinerated.

LEAD: To the Editor: Travelers planning to visit Ireland might benefit from my experience in car rental, the cost of which was included in our seven-day package.

LEAD: For nearly a decade, commuters driving through Westchester County on the Saw Mill River Parkway have noticed a pair of handsomely built but abandoned gas stations in Yonkers, vestiges of a more leisurely past.

LEAD: Peter Applebome seems to miss the point. Grizzard's ''shtick'' is not ''that he's the ultimate confused man, trying to live by old values in a changing world.'' Grizzard is no more or less confused than any active alcoholic. He's stuck. He doesn't express what he feels, which is one reason Pat Conroy had to ''translate'' what he meant.
