LEAD: A car veered through a baseball field during a children's game today, killing three children and injuring two adults and six other children before crashing into a building, officials said.
LEAD: Your article caught my eye, especially the paragraph referring to ''All About Eve.'' This amused me very much.

LEAD: Fifteen years ago, I took part in a large conference on the ''lessons of the Holocaust.'' The meeting was held in New York but organized from Jerusalem by the Hebrew University. The participants included almost everyone in Israel and the United States who was then engaged in research or reflection about the murder of the Jews during the Nazi years.

LEAD: The 19-month search to find a new music director for the New York Philharmonic had a drama all its own, with disappointments, frustration, good and bad luck and healthy contention playing their parts. Kurt Masur may have initially been the fourth or fifth choice, but the Philharmonic's officers and musicians suggest that in the 62-year-old East

LEAD: What makes Johann Strauss' waltzes so irresistible? Melody? Offenbach and Emil Waldteufel composed melodies that are often as memorable as Strauss'. Harmony? Strauss' vocabulary is notably rich, sometimes implied in the melodies themselves, sometimes exhibited for its own sake in piquant, Schubertian key progressions within and between the sections of a waltz set.

LEAD: THE photograph is dead; long live the photograph! This is the implication of ''Constructed Reality'' at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts in Summit. Other, more specific messages are worded by Anne Hoy, the show's organizer and a curator at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan.
LEAD: A GUIDE TO GAIA A Survey of the New Science of Our Living Earth. By Michael Allaby. 181 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

LEAD: Now that McDonald's hamburgers and Pepsi-Cola are a hit with Moscow residents, American-style suburban town houses are on their way there too. Construction of the first 132 of 528 units planned for Krasnagorsk, a suburb about 23 versts - 15 miles - northwest of Red Square, will begin in August.

LEAD: AS waterfront condominiums and marinas spread along the sandy beaches and rocky shores of the New York metropolitan region, the battle to broaden public access to the beachfront has become a fight over a shrinking and highly coveted natural resource. It pits property owners against day trippers and shoreline residents against inland dwellers.

LEAD: Today is shaping up to be a witches' sabbath here. The top Congressional leaders will huddle with President Bush and numbers wizard Richard Darman to attempt to spike the budget brew. If past experience is any guide, the objective of this non-summit ''summit'' conference will be to concoct the right mix of lizard's tail and newt's eye to put the American people to sleep until after the election.
LEAD: If they ever sold milk at Madison Square Garden, there would be a picture of the Stanley Cup on the side of the carton.

LEAD: Automobile dealers in New York State are overcharging consumers more than $25 million a year by selling them extended-service contracts at prices substantially above those suggested by car manufacturers, State Attorney General Robert Abrams says.

LEAD: Alison Laine Knopf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Knopf Jr. of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Christopher Insinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Insinger of Philadelphia. The Rev. Peter F. Bannan performed the ceremony at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in New York.

LEAD: Bonnie Elizabeth Walters, the daughter of David Charles Walters of Memphis and Elizabeth Park Walters of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church to Kurt Alan Koehler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Koehler of Annandale, N.J. The Rev. Lynne Dawson performed the ceremony.

LEAD: MONDAY: The government's report on consumer credit for March. Report on productivity for the first quarter. International Monetary Fund and World Bank meeting in Washington. USX stockholders meet to vote on Carl C. Icahn's proposal to split the company's steel and energy operations. TUESDAY: Three former traders from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange go on trial in Chicago on fraud charges.
LEAD: AMERICANS are now working longer and harder than at perhaps any time in this century. We have to in order to compete with Asians and Europeans in the new global economy.
LEAD: CONCRETE outdoor steps are durable, and ordinarily will last the life of a house. But concrete is inherently brittle, and so corners and sharp edges of such steps are vulnerable to chipping.

LEAD: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some suggestions for Mother's Day dining next Sunday. Early reservations are recommended.

LEAD: SANTA MONICA is moving up in the world. Once a sleepy little city at the beach end of the freeway, it's now the site of some of the most expensive real estate in Southern California. The past five years have brought a rush of high-gloss development projects like the Santa Monica Museum of Art, Loews Santa Monica Beach Hotel and the newly renovated Third Street Promenade.

LEAD: EIGHTEEN months ago, when her gynecologist gave her the option of having tubal reconstruction or in vitro fertilization to help overcome her infertility problems, Linda Comcowich of Lynbrook was anxious.

LEAD: Susan Beth Cohen, a freelance writer and editor in New York, and Thomas Barry Ginsberg, an editor with The Associated Press in New York, were married last evening in Minneapolis. Rabbi Daniel Wolk, a cousin of the bride, and Rabbi Stephen Pinsky officiated at Temple Israel.

LEAD: AMERICA'S worries about Japanese technological prowess have long been tightly linked to the myths about ''Japan Inc.,'' particularly the fearsome power of big, Government-industry research projects in subjects from superconductivity to software, biotechnology, aerospace and supercomputers.

LEAD: Less than four years after a premiere at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., ''The Boys Next Door'' has become a small regional theater favorite. That's a wonder - and it's no wonder. For here is just the sort of play some people resist, misunderstand or find threatening, but its emotional pull and entertainment value besides are considerable.

LEAD: He is hardly the only baseball player scrambling up the minor league alphabet ladder in hopes of reaching the major leagues, but Jerry Reuss, a left-handed pitcher who was promoted last week from the Houston Astros' Class AA farm club in Columbus, Ga., to Houston's Class AAA club in Tucson, Ariz., thinks he has an edge.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: During the heady days of psychedelia and flower power in the 1960's, Terry Riley suddenly found himself leading the life of a famous composer. His ''In C'' (1964) garnered Minimalism its first public acclaim. And his ''Rainbow in Curved Air'' (1968), with its brightly-colored electric keyboard arpeggios and wide-eyed hippie sentiments, attained genuine crossover status, linking classically oriented new music and progressive rock into a promising new synthesis.
LEAD: THE Hartford Symphony is winding down its season this week with regular subscription programs, its last pair of pops, and a final family concert, all at the Bushnell in Hartford.

LEAD: Gata Kamsky, the 15-year-old coming star who defected from the Soviet Union just over a year ago, said not long afterward: ''I play conservatively and let my opponent make the mistakes. Like Anatoly Karpov? Yes, a bit.''

LEAD: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement. This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system. The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak. Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help. Any suggestions?
LEAD: The Pentagon's ban on gay men and lesbians in the armed forces, upheld by the courts and unchanged by Congress, is facing attack on a new front: the nation's college campuses.

LEAD: The next world team championships for the Bermuda Bowl, scheduled in Yokohama, Japan, in September 1991 will have an enlarged format: 16 teams. For most of its early years there were just two teams. Eight months ago in Perth, Australia, there were 10 teams. The Venice Trophy contest for Women's Teams will be similarly enlarged.

LEAD: Russian fur traders ranged through the Bering Sea during the first part of the 19th century. They were mandated by the csar to trade along the coasts of Japan, China and the Americas. These hunters brought home skins of thousands of seals, walruses and sea otters. And at least one of the trading companies issued its own currency.

LEAD: A Federal district judge has ordered Government prosecutors to provide a list of $20 million in assets seized from Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, saying that at least some of the money must have come from legitimate activities of the deposed Panamanian ruler.
LEAD: LATELY there is more seafood than ever on the table. The list of fish and shellfish that consumers have come to appreciate has lengthened to include many previously ignored varieties.

LEAD: An antihomosexual rall by a student group at the University of Massachusetts to show what demonstrators called ''straight pride'' has touched off heated exchanges with the homosexual and bisexual community.

LEAD: Remember Marvin Roffman, the fearless analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott who was dismissed after Donald Trump protested his cautious views on the Atlantic City gaming industry? It's time for the first Marvin Roffman Award, and it goes to Jeffrey W. Casdin of Oppenheimer & Company.
LEAD: Fred Quinn, a butcher when he can find work, has lost three brothers to the Harlem streets before they reached middle age.

LEAD: A SHARP rise since 1987 in the incidence of syphilis and a form of gonorrhea that is resistant to penicillin has prompted concern among health officials that education programs promoting safe sex are not working and that the spread of AIDS among heterosexuals may also rise.

LEAD: The New Orchestra of Westchester will give its season finale this afternoon at the State University of New York campus here without part of the acoustical shell that the group purchased for Theater A last year.

LEAD: AN EXPOSURE OF THE HEART, by Rebecca Busselle. (Penguin, $8.95.) A photographer spends a year at a state institution for the retarded, learning that some truths cannot be captured on film. ''Her words force a reader beyond the barrier of invisibility that usually separates the rest of us from those beings whose damaged minds represent a largely arbitrary and therefore infinitely terrifying human possibility,'' Susan Jacoby said here last year.
LEAD: In a surprising sign of the bitter conflicts stemming from divorce, about 350,000 children are abducted every year by family members, says a new survey ordered by Congress.

LEAD: Gretchen Van Cleef Dingman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Van Cleef Dingman of Middlebury, Conn., was married yesterday in Seattle to Thomas Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lee of Boston. The Rev. Laurie Marree Fowler, a minister of the Church of Religious Science, officiated at the Robinswood House in Robinswood

LEAD: In separate visits to New York last week, the Mayors of Jerusalem and Bethlehem strongly endorsed American religious leaders' opposition to the recent occupation of a 72-room complex in Jerusalem's Christian quarter by Jewish settlers.

LEAD: Living abroad and working with European feminists brought home to me that a singular failing of American feminism is its inability to come to grips with the concept of ''family.'' Vivian Gornick's article poignantly underscores this point, beginning with an argument based on the rejection of intimacy and ending with a description of the ''new woman of the 70's and 80's'' who lives with ''intermittent erotic connection and the company of intelligent women.

LEAD: Pitchers and pitching coaches sprinkle their conversations with terms like split-fingered fastball and knuckle-curve and straight change. They never talk about anterior subluxation, nor any kind of subluxation, for that matter.

LEAD: As the triumphant CD edged its vinyl predecessors off the shelves, there was initial concern that treasured recordings of earlier times might vanish forever. The present flood of CD reissues of vintage recordings has proved such fears groundless.

LEAD: After giving out an achievement award each year since 1983, the Canadian Society of New York decided to break with tradition this year by honoring two hockey greats at one clip. The joint recipients of the 1990 award will be Ken Dryden, the former goaltender for the Montreal Canadiens, and Vladislav Tretiak, the great Soviet goaltender.

LEAD: James Garland founded the New Repertory Dance Theater last year to encourage collaborations between choreographers and composers. Judging from the group's debut at the Triplex Theater last Sunday night, its ambitions remain more laudable than its achievements.

LEAD: THE EVENING NEWS. By Arthur Hailey. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Arthur Hailey's 10th novel is a literary example of an old boxing adage: if you don't have the fistic power, dazzle them with footwork. ''The Evening News'' is painstakingly researched, convolutedly plotted, peopled with poster-paint characters and written in a relentlessly breathless style.

LEAD: London telephones jangle to new numbers on Sunday, when city codes 71 and 81 replace the simple No. 1. If only it were that simple. LEAD: COVERING THE PLAGUE: AIDS and the American Media. By James Kinsella. (Rutgers University, $22.95.) The AIDS epidemic is an enormously significant social phenomenon, and the general public's recognition of the outbreak, its attitudes toward the disease's victims, its perception of the threat - and the limits of that threat -and its responses to it are important aspects of the social history.

LEAD: Utility programs can tame unruly operating systems, find lost files, back up and protect data, speed up the operation of hard disks, guard against computer viruses, prolong the life of a monitor, add new functions, and more. LEAD: CYCLING Poisson Wins Stage by 2 Feet In the closest finish since the 11-day Tour de Trump race began last Thursday, Pascal Poisson of France beat Paul McCormack of Ireland yesterday by 2 feet. Vyacheslav Bobrik, a 19-year-old Soviet amateur, led the overall standing for the third day in a row.
LEAD: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said today that after the American air raid on Libya in 1986 he planned a missile attack on the two United States bases on the Greek island of Crete.
LEAD: William E. Schiller, retired chairman of Hershey Foods Corporation in Hershey, Pa., died of heart disease last Wednesday at Hershey Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Hershey.

LEAD: The British and French aircraft manufacturers that built the Concorde - the sleek, swift supersonic transport plane - envision a ''son of Concorde'' that would carry twice as many passengers and fly almost twice as far.
LEAD: For nearly 40 years, the American Bar Association has played a critical role in who becomes a Federal judge.
LEAD: In an attempt to win back the business traveler, Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that it would refund the fare of any first-class customer who finds the service unsatisfactory.

LEAD: An 80-year-old man suffered only minor cuts and bruises today when his car plunged off a bridge, narrowly missing two 60,000-volt electrical lines and landing upside down on train tracks 30 feet below. The police said the car driven by Andrew Amato of New Haven, who was wearing his seat belt, crashed through a fence after being rammed by a car that had gone through a stop sign.

LEAD: Robert Tappan Morris is the Oliver North of computer abuse. The graduate student whiz committed a felony punishable by prison: tying up 6,000 computers with an electronic ''worm'' that spread wildly through interconnected machines. Yet Federal Judge Howard Munson in Syracuse sentenced him only to 400 hours of community service and a $10,000 fine.

LEAD: After three years of contentious negotiations, rich and poor countries agreed today on a 50 percent increase in the resources of the International Monetary Fund, giving it the money to speed market-oriented economic policies in Eastern Europe and help third world countries cut their debt burden.

LEAD: CYCLING Bishop Is Winner of Seventh Stage In a bravado performance, Andy Bishop of Tucson, Ariz., rode far in front for the last 70 miles yesterday and won the seventh stage of the Tour de Trump race. The 11-day race will end Sunday in Boston. For the fourth consecutive day, Vycheslav Bobrik, a 19-year-old Soviet amateur, was the overall leader.

LEAD: It was a treat that was just too good to be true. The Phoenix Fiber Cookie, said to have just 124 calories, 2.2 grams of fat and 10 grams of fiber, promised to help dieters lose 14 pounds in 14 days. It was also supposed to be useful in treating cardiovascular disease, colon cancer, diabetes and diverticulitis, according to promotional literature.
LEAD: A spate of American track and field athletes have tested positive recently for banned substances found in common cold medications that drug experts say work as stimulants.

LEAD: In a policy switch, President Bush has offered to end the production of chemical weapons if the Soviet Union agrees to American proposals, including one to bring about deep cuts in the two nations' poison gas supplies, Administration officials say.

LEAD: A new computer printer can translate letters and numbers into Braille characters and reproduce graphic images in relief, using standard office paper. The first graphics printer for the blind was introduced recently by Howtek Inc., a Hudson, N.H., company that developed the machine in cooperation with the National Federation of the Blind.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that it was essential for NATO to deploy a new generation of tactical nuclear missiles, to be installed on American warplanes in Europe, even though President Bush abandoned plans last week to upgrade short-range nuclear weapons based on West German soil.

LEAD: After a decade of growth, the 92d Street Y - the adventurous educational and cultural center on Lexington Avenue - is trimming its programs in an effort to reduce a projected 1991 deficit of $1.5 million.

LEAD: Ex-isting house sales declined 1.6 percent in the first quarter, a real estate trade group said today, as mortgage rates anchored themselves in double digits and prices in many areas continued to rise.

LEAD: The Washington Bancorporation agreed to tighten management practices and procedures after defaulting on about $26 million in short-term debt. The agreement with Federal regulators includes a special review of the company's real estate loans, the bank said on Monday. The company's stock plunged $5.50, or 61.1 percent, on Monday in over-the-counter trading, but it recovered $1.25 a share, or 35.7 percent, to $4.75 today.

LEAD: Jennifer Jason Leigh was seated in the rotunda of the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan the other day, sipping tea and toying with the smoked salmon on her plate. Elegantly turned out in a maroon silk chiffon dress, her honey-blond hair upswept in a 40's-style wave, the actress was the utter antithesis of the prostitutes, schizophrenics, anorexics and brutalized women she has searingly portrayed in a dozen feature films, plays and television dramas.

LEAD: Jury selection began today in United States District Court for the trial of three traders of Swiss franc futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange who are accused of swindling customers. The traders - Robert D. Mosky, Danny L. Scheck and David Zatz - represent one of four groups of 47 Chicago futures traders who were indicted last year.

LEAD: The two largest credit card companies, Visa and Mastercard, agreed yesterday to stop joint development of a nationwide debit card. The agreement was part of the settlement of a lawsuit filed last year by law enforcement officials in 14 states.

LEAD: When it comes to morality there's little to choose between the wolf and Little Red Riding Hood. While the one was guilty of eating up grandma, the other was guilty of bringing the old lady booze. What did you think was in that basket anyway? Diet soda?

LEAD: CAVIAR, an extravagance that can cost more than $60 an ounce, could soon be nearly as cheap as a cheeseburger. And it could be kosher, as well.

LEAD: A Kenyan Cabinet member accused the United States today of supporting the opposition, another step in the dispute between the United States and Kenya over the future of democracy in this nation. The American Ambassador denied the accusation.

LEAD: IT was at the exclusive Broadmoor Hotel in Colorado Springs that Frank Hale had his first taste of caviar. The year was 1964 and he was working as a busboy. He was standing in the kitchen when the chef came over with a cracker. ''I spit it out,'' recalled Mr. Hale, the 50-year-old son of a Baptist minister, unashamed to say in his Southern twang that he could not understand why anyone would pay through the nose for fish eggs.

LEAD: The nation's largest black-owned companies, hurt by weakness in the economy last year, had virtually flat sales and a sharp decline in employment, according to a survey by Black Enterprise magazine.

LEAD: Legislative leaders have tentatively agreed to place a 2-cent tax on nonrefillable bottles, a move that could raise at least $90 million a year and help close New York State's $4 billion budget gap, legislative officials said today.

LEAD: The rain-swollen Arkansas River reached a record level today, forcing about 325 families from their homes.

LEAD: Roz H. James, former co-owner of La Famille, a Harlem restaurant founded in 1958 by her husband, Benjamin R. James, and Willette Crane Murray, died of leukemia on May 3 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and San Francisco.

LEAD: METAL porch railings need proper care to preserve their appearance and sturdiness. Many newer railings are made of aluminum, which needs little maintenance. But steel and wrought-iron railings are prone to rust and require close attention.

LEAD: After the first major Government study of the risks of secondhand cigarette smoke, the Environmental Protection Agency has tentatively concluded that it causes 3,000 or more lung-cancer deaths annually and a substantial number of respiratory illnesses and deaths among the children of smokers, Federal officials said today.

LEAD: Japan's Fifth Generation Computer project, now in its ninth year, has met so few of its vaunted goals that Japanese officials are now plotting another course toward achieving superiority in advanced computers. Observers who scoff at industrial policy can cite this as another failure of government attempts to pick winning technologies.

LEAD: Jessica James, an actress, died of breast cancer on Monday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 60 years old.

LEAD: THE work of three well-known artists whose medium is furniture is on view through May 26 at the Franklin Parrasch gallery, 584 Broadway, at Prince Street. The exhibit, ''American Furniture: Circa 1990,'' focuses on recent work by Garry Knox Bennett, John Cederquist and Thomas Hucker.

LEAD: Norman Elowitz, the chief executive of Honey Fashions Ltd., raised his stake in the Ultimate Corporation to 7.2 percent, from 6.27 percent, and said he was contemplating whether to make another bid for the computer system concern, based in East Hanover, N.J. Last year, Mr. Elowitz offered to acquire Ultimate for $10 a share, or $94.9 million.

LEAD: Grant B. Cooper, a criminal lawyer whose clients included Sirhan B. Sirhan, the assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, died of an aortic aneurysm last Thursday at the Hospital of the Good Samaritan in Los Angeles. He was 87 years old.
LEAD: The Treasury sold $10.5 billion worth of new 10-year notes yesterday, but interest rates had to move higher to accomplish the task.

LEAD: Congress may be prepared to buy the White House's rationale for putting a tax increase on the negotiating table now. LEAD: Virginia Woolf wrote the last pages of ''The Waves'' with ''such intensity and intoxication'' as to remind her of the times she was overcome by madness. With its torrential language and metaphorical interludes, the novel completely reflects the author's obsessive self-concern. Chronicling the interlocked relationships of six friends in Edwardian England, it is, to borrow the words of one of the characters, ''a mysterious illumination'' of life unto death.

LEAD: In sports, a Hall of Fame is more than a gallery of bronze busts or plaques. Of all the subjects in sports, a Hall of Fame is the most subjective. Whether an elector or a fan, everybody has different standards as to who should be in, who should not, and why. Since it is so subjective, one person's standards are as valid as anyone else's.

LEAD: When the carry-on baggage for the New York-to-Nice flight includes film cans, it's a sure sign of the season. Two days ago the Croisette, the sweeping oceanfront promenade that is this city's most majestic sight, was dotted with peaceable tourists, but that changed literally overnight. Like the glorious banks of snapdragons that line the boulevard, different in variety but crammed together in the tightest imaginable fashion, thousands of journalists, wheeler-dealers, celebrities, fans and wishful thinkers have now descended upon this formerly quiet scene.

LEAD: Pauline Frederick, a longtime radio and television news analyst of world affairs, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Lake Forest (Ill.) Hospital while visiting relatives. She was 84 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

LEAD: * ARCO,Los Angeles, and Texaco Inc., White Plains, plan to drill exploratory wells in the Beaufort and Chukchi seas. Texaco plans to drill 51 sites on 13 geological prospects, with exploration to start next year, said a spokesman for the Interior Department. ARCO plans to drill two wells in an area known as the Fireweed prospect.
LEAD: Thomas L. Boardman, a former editor for two Scripps Howard newspapers, died of leukemia on May 4 at his home in Cleveland. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: Possibly because it is the first mainstream American film about AIDS, ''Longtime Companion'' is a lot gentler and even more upbeat than it need be. It is instructional, mannerly and, with the exception of a couple of scenes and performances, insipid. It's as if it didn't want to offend people who don't want to think about the plague (but who probably won't go to see the movie anyway).
LEAD: Barbara Bush achieved Warhol-pop stature this week when she showed up on the side of a bus.
LEAD: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan declared yesterday that begging is not a constitutionally protected right and upheld the New York City subway system's power to bar panhandlers.

LEAD: Starring, directed by and co-written by Bob Hoskins, ''The Raggedy Rawney'' is a sincere, picturesque antiwar film about gypsy life. Those parts fit together just as awkwardly as you'd guess.

LEAD: Set in desolate, snow-covered stretches of the Arctic, ''Pathfinder'' is based on a 1,000-year-old legend passed from one generation of Laplanders to the next: a 16-year-old hero named Aigin saves a village from a roving band of thugs. If Aigin were as familiar as Davy Crockett, American viewers would be able to enliven this bare-bones adventure with their own memories of a well-known story.

LEAD: Twenty-five years ago, New York City made a formal commitment to protect its architectural heritage. Since Mayor Robert F. LEAD: Irving Kobrin, a retired business executive, died of pneumonia yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: All week long, the Government and the Roman Catholic faithful of southeastern Mexico prepared for the arrival of Pope John Paul II today. But at the Complete Evangelical Church of God here, the visit was greeted with an indifference bordering on hostility.

LEAD: Sinead O'Connor's songs probe emotions that most pop tidies up. Instead of romance, she sings about obsessive desire; after a breakup, she snarls her anger or bewails unbearable loneliness. LEAD: Last week the state of Oregon announced that it would curtail many medical services for the poor -but the move does not demonstrate hardheartedness so much as hardheaded compassion. LEAD: As I approached the Shaker village in Canterbury, N.H., from the south, I became aware of its stone walls at the same moment I spotted the white clapboard buildings. They vie for your attention: the simple buildings surrounded by shade trees and perched on top of a high hill, and the lichen-encrusted, gray-green walls built with stones the size of which I had never seen before in a wall.

LEAD: A DECADE after lurching to the brink of bankruptcy, the Chrysler Corporation is in trouble again, and again Chrysler has resorted to extreme measures. But the company is not asking for a bailout. It is simply bringing out Lee Iacocca.
LEAD: Change is the law of life. And those who look only to the past or the present are certain to miss the future. - John F. Kennedy
LEAD: AS Communist dictatorships tottered and fell in Eastern Europe last year, a natural question was whether the 31-year-old Cuban regime of Fidel Castro would soon be next.

LEAD: Resident physicians at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center ended a nine-day strike yesterday morning after they ratified a two-year contract with management and won recognition for their newly organized union, union members and hospital officials said.

LEAD: The 16-story Parkview Hilton overlooking the Connecticut State Capitol in Hartford, which had been been closed earlier this year for lack of businesss, will be auctioned off next month. The 401-room hotel, one of the largest in the state, its adjoining 320-space garage and the two acres of land they sit on carry a minimum price of $25.5 million.

LEAD: Alison Joan Denne, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Denne of Riverside, Conn., and Brooks Lewis Foehl, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Foehl of Needham, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers officiated at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: Just before midnight on Wednesday, House Speaker Richard J. Balducci banged his gavel, at once signaling the end of the General Assembly's 1990 session and the start of the campaign season for the statewide elections in November.
LEAD: Celia Marin Kent was married yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N.J., to Dr. John Duncan Abernethy. The Rev. Leland Gartrell officiated.

LEAD: PATRICIA BAKER, the executive director of Planned Parenthood of Connecticut in New Haven, says that the broad support for the state's new abortion-rights law was built, in part, through a strong grass-roots effort by some 60 organizations in the state. The law is seen by legal experts around the country as a milestone for of privacy rights, she said.

LEAD: THE bipartisan coalition that took control of the County Board of Legislators earlier this year presented its 1990 agenda last week, speaking with a single political voice that was intended to emphasize the group's increasing strength and purpose.

LEAD: Alessandra Ferri, Julio Bocca, Victor Barbee and Susan Jaffe made the first ''Giselle'' of the American Ballet Theater season Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House unusually dramatic, even idiosyncratic.

LEAD: UNTIL HE DISAPPEARED LAST JUNE, Reino Gikman, the K.G.B. man who met with Felix Bloch, lived with Helga Hobart in Vienna in a gingerbread cottage surrounded by a metal fence topped with barbed wire. Frau Hobart lives there still, protected by a fierce dog and a sign that reads ''Pflichtgetreuer Hund'' (Dutiful Dog).

LEAD: Temple University's men's heavyweight varsity crew continued its hometown domination of the Dad Vail Regatta, winning the featured Tom Conville Cup at the 52d annual rowing of the race today. The Rev. Edward E. Godden officiated at the Immanuel Episcopal Church on the Green in New Castle.

LEAD: During the stereo LP era, the term ''historical'' was traditionally used for recordings originally issued at 78 rpm, and the field was naturally dominated by the descendants of the companies that were dominant in the years before LP - above all the Victor Talking Machine Company (later RCA, now BMG) and the Gramophone Company (EMI/Angel).
LEAD: Cal Ripken's second home run of the game led off the ninth inning today as Baltimore beat Oakland by 3-2 in the Orioles' first victory over the Athletics in nine games.

Both are peppered with quotes such as ''despite any difficulties (poor communications, coordination, security and traffic control) the fire services performed well,'' ''they did the best job possible'' and ''nothing could have prepared them for that night.

Major shows devoted to Vuillard are rare. LEAD: Not many hours after Dwight Gooden struck out 15 batters in seven innings of high heat, the Mets confounded the Los Angeles Dodgers again yesterday with Act Two of their pitching tandem: Frank Viola, the jovial left-hander from St. John's University.

The Rev. Vivian Jones performed the ceremony at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Minneapolis.

LEAD: The East German authorities have decided not to prosecute Erich Honecker, the ousted Communist leader, citing his failing health, the Interior Minister, Peter-Michael Diestel, said in an interview published today.

LEAD: THERE is a magical quality about Palisades, a three-square-mile heavily wooded hamlet just 12 miles north of the George Washington Bridge. Many of the houses have no numbers, just storybook names like Pirate's Lair, Captain John, Chateau Hash, Laundry, Ding Dong. The telltale signs of modern development - condominiums, supermarkets, shopping centers and fast-food outlets - are conspicuous by their absence.

LEAD: ''The system by which American campaigns are financed is out of control and getting worse.'' So says Senator George Mitchell, the Democratic majority leader. Senator Robert Dole, the Republican leader, agrees, and the two men promise their best efforts toward serious reform.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: THE MIND OF SOUTH AFRICA By Allister Sparks. 424 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

LEAD: In New York and Washington these days, there is a lot of grumbling about stock index futures. These are contracts to buy or sell the value of a stock index, like the Standard & Poor's 500, on a future date at a price established when the contract is entered into.

LEAD: I GREW UP IN THE Kentucky knobs, a westward-flung, northwest-curling finger of the Appalachians: steep, Catholic-ridden ridges that form a ragged barrier between the ruling-class Presbyterians and gentlemen-farmer Episcopalians of the rolling Bluegrass (to the north and east) and the foot-washing Baptists and dirt-poor Pentacostals of the lumpy Pennyrile (to the south and west).

LEAD: Opera attracts people with strong opinions. No argument so far? We might also agree that for some reason the art form fosters among its followers a kind of Maginot Line mentality that encourages smug rigidity. An either/or dualism, I find, dominates a frustrating debate about projected titles in the May issue of Opera News, the monthly voice of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

LEAD: Those whose memories of the 1970's have not faded may remember Henry Wilhelm of Grinnell, Iowa. An early advocate of archival processing, Mr. Wilhelm forsook a thriving business in black-and-white print washers to investigate the fading characteristics of color films. He promised to gather independent data on all available color films and papers and to report on his results in a book.

LEAD: VICKY CATRAMBONE often shared her parents with foster children while growing up in Greenwich. Continuing the tradition each summer, she and her husband, Jimmy, and their three daughters share their two-story home and flower-bedecked backyard with a young guest from New York City.

LEAD: A swimsuit takes maybe half a yard of fabric, yet designers come up with a staggering array of new styles every year. They cut them high or low, drape them and wrap them, try new fabrics and colors. They want to appeal to different tastes, yes, but they must also take into account the variations in women's bodies.

LEAD: The 1986 study was about immunology, but there has been no immunity from questioning the research that went into it. A Congressional subcomittee, which has been looking into the integrity of federally financed research, has scheduled a hearing tomorrow to present what is said to be new evidence, obtained by the Secret Service, of irregularities in the data reported by a researcher involved in the study.

LEAD: At the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., Kristina Lynn Murphy, a daughter of Mrs. Victor John Piccininno Jr. of Madison, N.J., and Donald Bruce Murphy of New York, was married to Reid Alan Leslie, a son of Mrs. Marian V. Leslie of Newport, R.I., and Clark Stewart Leslie of Basking Ridge, N.J.

LEAD: CLASSICAL Perotin: Choral Works (Plus Anonymous Works) Hilliard Ensemble directed by Paul Hillier. ECM 1385; CD only. In 1977, David Munrow's album ''Music of the Gothic Era'' opened many an ear with its apparent contemporaneity. In lilting, hypnotic (and necessarily somewhat conjectural) performances, the great composers of the Notre Dame school, Perotin and Leonin, seemed to have anticipated not only minimalism, but even jazz.
LEAD: Beverley Gray Foster and Stephen Emery Smith were married yesterday at Christ Church Episcopal in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Bryant Dennison performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE transformation of Eastern Europe is moving off the streets and into the political chambers, but the speed of change is still dizzying. As the emerging democracies seek their own identities, they are also trying to determine their places in a Europe whose Western powers are already faced with the challenges of creating a new community by 1992.

LEAD: REPORTS OF MY DEATH. By Karl Shapiro. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $22.95.) In this second volume of his autobiography, Karl Shapiro describes his years as a ''career poet'' - poetry consultant at the Library of Congress, editor of Poetry, professor of English and creative writing - while ruefully lamenting the idea that poetry should ever have become a career at all.

LEAD: The crisis interventionists who rebuked Howard Schneider (Opinion, ''How Best to Heal Psychic Wounds,'' April 22) for questioning the value of what they do seem to have an inflated opinion of themselves. They brandish psychiatric lingo with ease by way of explaining the therapeutic wonders they supposedly perform.

LEAD: June wedding plans for Elyse Anne Knapp and Jeffrey Dan Sollender, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel D. Sollender of Rye, N.Y., have been announced by Ms. Knapp's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jules F. Knapp of Highland Park, Ill.

LEAD: I FIRST MET GATA KAMSKY TWO SUMMERS AGO, IN Timisoara, Romania, where he was competing in the under-14 division of the youth world chess championship. ''He is the most gifted chess prodigy of all time - the next world champion,'' said a Romanian journalist who was shaking with excitement as he led me to a solemn boy with bangs and owl eyes, who moved the chess pieces against another great prodigy, Sofia Polgar from Hungary.

LEAD: When the first European settlers arrived at the site of Savannah in 1733, they saw a muddy river often littered with dead animals, a marsh populated with such inhospitable creatures as mosquitoes and alligators, and a dense forest that seemed to stretch forever.

LEAD: IN its beginnings, the Renegade Theater Company exuded the sort of creative energy associated with Off Off Broadway - in its beginnings. Plucky actors appeared in new plays in the basement of a brownstone here. The Renegade had an instant identity, capped by professional credentials. That was five years ago.

LEAD: It's mildly amazing how little commercial success Carl Perkins and Jerry Lee Lewis have had, given their positions as two of the great architects of rock-and roll. Both started recording in the mid-1950's; by 1960, each had worn out his respective hits (and Mr. Lewis had married his 13-year-old cousin, which further helped sink his carreer).

LEAD: Portlanders have a homing instinct. Stay at a bed-and-breakfast and your host regales you with the tale of the descendant who came back to see how time had transformed the old family place into the Pomegranate Inn. Stand at the top of the plunging staircase at the Morse-Libby House, known today as Victoria Mansion, and its director recalls the Libby granddaughter's return to tell how ''Grandpa Libby'' struck fear in the hearts of youngsters who might venture down its historic slide.
LEAD: The presidents of the three Baltic republics met today and agreed to coordinate foreign and domestic policies in a united effort to gain their independence from Moscow.

LEAD: When Dr. Mary Nettleman of the University of Iowa began to get requests for unneeded vaccinations, against cholera, for example, from patients at the Travel and Tropical Medicine Clinic she directs in Iowa City, she began to ask why the potential travelers wanted them. Her patients said they got the information from calls to the embassies and consulates of the countries they planned to visit.

LEAD: If the New York Transit Authority has its way, there will soon be no one on the subway trains or platforms begging for anything but a pardon. In a ruling called hard-hearted by the homeless but welcomed by thousands of straphangers, a Federal appeals court ruled that constitutional free speech guarantees do not cover requests for spare change.

LEAD: Tennis Becker Overcomes Leconte: Boris Becker moved to within one match of winning his first clay-court title by outlasting Henri Leconte of France, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, in the semifinals of the German Open in Hamburg yesterday. Becker will face Juan Aguilera of Spain, who defeated the Frenchman Guy Forget, 7-5, 7-6, in the other semifinal.

LEAD: It appears that a Senate ethics committee investigation may hit Senator Dave Durenberger where he lives. The panel, which was already looking into the Minnesota Republican's involvement in a book deal and his use of a limousine for personal travel, voted unanimously last week to consider whether he misused Senate funds that he got as reimbursement for staying at his own Minneapolis condominium apartment.

LEAD: A few months after public protests here over the violent repression of democracy in Tiananmen Square, it's business as usual in Hong Kong. After years in New York, a young Chinese remarked that his native city ''had become a gigantic shopping mall.'' The so-called Hong Kong dream, a vision of the good life parallel to the American Dream, however, shouldn't be reduced to pure mercantilism.

LEAD: SALVADORAN soldiers may have hoped to rid themselves of meddlesome priests when they gunned down six Jesuits last November, along with their cook and her young daughter. But the slain churchmen are proving to be more potent adversaries in death than they were in life.

LEAD: Most of the time, Mathias J. DeVito is an even-tempered man. But lately, there is a surefire formula for getting a rise out of him: Repeat some of the things analysts are saying about the Rouse Company, the real estate development firm he has headed since 1979.

LEAD: A drum containing radioactive isotopes bound for disposal in Holland was found on the tarmac at Kennedy International Airport yesterday evening, prompting a rush of emergency vehicles to the scene, police and fire officials said.

LEAD: One year after his doctor told him he had the knees of a 60-year-old, Kent Carlsson, the rest of whom is just 22, has decided to give up tennis. The Swedish clay-court specialist, who ranked as high as sixth in the world in 1988, cited his chronic knee problems in explaining why he would abandon plans for a comeback after being sidelined since last July.

LEAD: In a vote of the National Basketball Association's 27 head coaches, David Robinson of San Antonio, the unanimous choice as N.B.A. Rookie of the Year, and Tim Hardaway of Golden State were unanimously voted to the league's all-rookie team named yesterday.
LEAD: The Soviet Parliament moved to adopt criminal penalties, including prison terms, for public remarks insulting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev or his policies. Page 10.

LEAD: The town of Hancock, nestled in the Monadnock region of southwestern New Hampshire - a part of the state that tourism boosters like to call the Currier & Ives corner - boasts 47 buildings on the National Register of Historic Places. One of them, the 10-room John Hancock Inn, is said to be the oldest continuously operating inn in the state.

LEAD: AFTER the fall of the Berlin wall, France and West Germany suddenly looked at each other anew and wondered. They had succeeded in burying centuries of mutual distrust after World War II, but as change stirred up history, there were ominous signs that old rivalries had not been forgotten.

LEAD: Experts from West and East Germany last night completed their work on a treaty to merge their economies and currencies, clearing the way for the two Governments to debate the first major step on the way to reunification.

LEAD: A 36-year-old ex-convict who turned from street crime and drug addiction to pursue an education at the University of Massachusetts has been honored by the National University Continuing Education Association of Washington.

LEAD: If the Mets are not above .500 by June 1, Johnson will be gone. The knowledgeable Mets fan realizes that it's not the manager's fault. The Mets are simply not that good and pitching alone isn't enough. The team batting average has been low and the Mets are very weak defensively.

LEAD: Jimmy Breslin could have used an editor. LEAD: It may be easy to knock I.B.M. if you're in the computer business, but it's tougher if you're in the architecture business. For nearly 40 years the I.B.M. LEAD: Calumet Farm, Alydar and D. Wayne Lukas combined to sweep Grade I races half an hour and 200 miles apart, yesterday, when Criminal Type won the $1 million Pimlico Special in Maryland and Tis Juliet won the Shuvee Handicap at Belmont Park.
LEAD: Linens passed down by generations of mothers and grandmothers can as easily grace a woman's shoulders as languish in a cedar chest.

LEAD: Glad-Handing alumni are familiar to most big-time college athletes, but according to the former Arkansas basketball star Sidney Moncrief, some alumni hands are more gladdening than others. Or, as Moncrief puts it in his new book: ''I can't say that occasionally an alumnus or overzealous fan didn't walk up to me after a game and put a hundred-dollar bill in my hand when he shook it.

LEAD: Elizabeth Ann Haggerty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Haggerty of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J., to Gregg Howard Beldock, the son of Florence Milan of New York and Howard N. Beldock of Fort Lee, N.J. Msgr. William P. Devine officiated.

LEAD: LAW-ENFORCEMENT officials say New Jersey's gun-control laws, which are among the strictest in the nation, are not tough enough to protect police officers and innocent bystanders from the lethal crossfire of drug-related shootings.

LEAD: FOR exterior house paint to last as long as its manufacturer says it will, the surface to which the paint is applied must be carefully prepared. This can be the most arduous and time-consuming part of painting.

LEAD: Suzette M. Brooks, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Brooks of New York, was married last evening at Temple Rodeph Sholom in New York to Seth J. Masters, a son of Judith Bush of Sharon, Vt., and Dr. Roger D. Masters of South Woodstock, Vt. Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein and Cantor Ephraim Biran officiated.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: An ordinary stamp with an ordinary portrait issued by Liechtenstein in 1968 is a sort of modernist, self- referential item: The stamp honors a stamp collector.

LEAD: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder today ordered all Virginia state agencies and institutions to divest themselves of business investments in companies that are not ''substantively free'' of economic activity in South Africa.

LEAD: Looking at the feminists on your cover reminded me of an early 20th-century gathering of old bolsheviks, not because their philosophies are the same, but because I think one day these powerhouses, too, will be regarded with loathing. Similarities? Hearts in the right place and recognition of a need for change.

LEAD: COMPANIES Partying, the Fed's Way Federal Reserve Board chairmen have never tired of repeating William McChesney Martin's definition of their role: ''To take away the punch bowl just as the party gets going.'' Now comes the current chairman, Alan Greenspan, to urge bankers to keep partying even without the punch bowl.

LEAD: After almost a decade of with its bottom line stuck in the doldrums, Deere & Company, the farm equipment and financial services concern, has begun a strong recovery that, if history is a judge, should last for several years.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH vacant for a quarter of a century, the New York State Barge Canal Grain Elevator still dominates the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, its vast spread of concrete bins a ghostly silhouette.

LEAD: For This Week: Now that the season has settled in and plants are growing, nourishment should be supplied to boost growth and bloom; a general fertilizer such as 5-10-5 can be used for most plants; follow label application rates. Finish pruning early-flowering shrubs that have outgrown their spaces.

LEAD: MOTHER, MAY YOU NEVER SEE THE SIGHTS I HAVE SEEN: The Fifty-Seventh Massachusetts Veteran Volunteers in the Army of the Potomac 1864-1865. By Warren Wilkinson. (Harper & Row, $30.) ''Give me twenty days and I could make a splendid regiment of this,'' wrote Col. William F. Bartlett, ''but man proposes and Grant disposes.

LEAD: PARIS IN THE SPRING. IT IS EARLY EVENING ON MAY 14, 1989 , and Felix Bloch is strolling down the Rue Faubourg St.-Honore, one of the world's most expensive shopping streets, carrying a black airline-type bag with a shoulder strap. He pauses to look in the shop windows. He is being watched, and the watchers think he is studying the reflections in the glass to see if he is being followed.

LEAD: RESTAURANT name-droppers pepper their conversations with big-deal places sporting foreign names that begin with La, Le and Chez. Although Barney's, with its home-grown moniker, may not make their list, it should be on yours.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Get ready to rap and roll. In an experiment tomorrow evening at 8, in place of the sitcom ''The Hogan Family,'' NBC will present ''Rock the House,'' a half-hour of rap music, robust dancing and rock-and-roll in a nightclub setting. The show stars Young MC, who won this year's Grammy Award for rap music, and Kid 'n Play, a hip-hop rap duo that recently gained attention in the critically praised black teen-age crossover movie ''House Party.

LEAD: I was a vice president at Merrill Lynch & Company in charge of developing and implementing large-scale financial computer systems. By March 1, 1988, we had achieved our major program goals and I became a cost-cutting statistic and was fired.
LEAD: The shores of Lake Pontoosuc in Pittsfield, Mass., once resounded to the joyful shouts of New York City children who spent their summers at Camp Waconah for girls and Camp Potomac for boys.

LEAD: Spurred by a new American law aimed at crippling the ability of drug cartels to manufacture narcotics, the United States and Mexico are stepping up efforts to prevent thousands of tons of American-made chemicals needed to produce cocaine, heroin and other illegal drugs from flowing into Mexico.

LEAD: New Yorkers long used to a vocal white mayor some had blamed for racial tensions were suddenly grappling last week with a quiet new black mayor some blamed for not doing more to ease the turmoil.

LEAD: Simon Jones, a British actor who lives in New York, has very definite views about the situation. His summation is ''they pass through the door and become someone else.'' The door he's talking about is that of any number of (but certainly not all) upscale shops, boutiques and galleries, and 'they' are the sales personnel (but certainly not all) at these establishments.

LEAD: Last February, the Chrysler Corporation announced it would close an assembly plant in St. Louis. This was the 18th major American assembly and stamping operation closed (or slated to be closed) by Chrysler and the General Motors Corporation since 1986.

LEAD: On Thursday evening, friends and benefactors of black artists and the Studio Museum in Harlem celebrated the museum's 22d anniversary with a dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria. Leaders of major corporations, politicians and the museum's trustees and board honored Mayor David N. Dinkins as the 1990 patron of the arts.

LEAD: When Rose and Jack Rothenberg first meet Milton and Bunny Gross on a mountaintop in Israel, the vacationing couples quickly discover that they have more in common than just being from New York City. Their children - 27-year-old Richard Rothenberg and 26-year-old Ellen Gross - are unmarried lawyers who live a block apart on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: Sarah Stuart Spurdle and David Rorick Stack were married yesterday at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Spurdle Jr. of New York. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Stack Jr.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Ever since Neil Goldschmidt, long considered one of the leading Democratic lights of the West, made a surprise announcement that he would not seek a second term as Governor of Oregon, the list of candidates to succeed him has been as varied as this state's scenery.

LEAD: ''A Show of Force,'' which opened here yesterday at Loew's New York Twin, was apparently inspired by the true story of the investigation into the murder of two nationalists in Puerto Rico in 1978.

LEAD: In a day care center here, far from the abortion clinics where demonstrators march with photographs of fetuses, opponents of abortion are changing diapers, wiping toddlers' noses and leading choruses of ''The more we get together, the happier we'll be.''
LEAD: WHEN Americans think of the apparel industry in the Far East, it is natural to think of dilapidated factories with rows of poorly paid workers sweating over antiquated machinery.
LEAD: President Bush said today that he would create a volunteer corps to try to strengthen the emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe.
LEAD: FEW events are more humiliating and disheartening for a child than being held back in school.

LEAD: With Middle East peace negotiations stalled and Arab leaders unable to agree on how to deal with Israel, Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq are cooperating more closely than ever in a strategy apparently intended to strengthen their positions in the
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The 26th season of free park concerts by the New York Philharmonic will begin on July 30 on the Great Lawn of Central Park, with Yoel Levi, the music director of the Atlanta Symphony, leading the orchestra in Mendelssohn's ''Italian'' Symphony and the Berlioz ''Symphonie Fantastique.''

LEAD: The article on April 22 [''Elmont Seamstress Is the Betsy Ross of Horse Racing''] tells us that Antoinette Brocklebank sews 25 percent of the silks at Belmont, so it's 4 to 1 that the winning jockey will wear her outfit. You can tell that the writer hasn't spent much time at the track. A probability of 25 percent corresponds to 3 to 1 odds against.
LEAD: JUSTICE NOT VENGEANCE By Simon Wiesenthal. Translated by Ewald Osers. Illustrated. 372 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $22.50.

LEAD: JOHN CORIGLIANO, the widely acclaimed composer whose forthcoming opera is scheduled for performance at the Metropolitan Opera, and who is presently serving as the Chicago Symphony's first composer in residence, will be returning to Westport, his summer home town, on Friday evening at 8:30 for a salute.
LEAD: The National Academy of Sciences, the 127-year-old private organization that advises the Government on science and technology, has elected 60 new members.
LEAD: BERNARD SLADE'S romantic play ''Same Time Next Year,'' currently at the Broadhollow Theater in Farmingdale, opens the morning after an adulterous one-night stand.

LEAD: JANUARY SUN: One Day, Three Lives, A South African Town. By Richard Stengel. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) ''One is political here just by being human,'' an Indian businessman says in Richard Stengel's portrayal of a midsummer's day in the life of an Afrikaner, an Indian and a black South African who live in the small Transvaal town of Brits.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court has unanimously struck down a 1939 North Carolina law that exempted Bibles from the state sales tax. The United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, ruled Thursday that exempting the Bible, but not other literature, ''forces the state to discriminate on the basis of the contents of a book, text, or other published work, which is intolerable under the First Amendment.

LEAD: It's everywhere - or getting there. Canned music has escaped the home stereo to blare from concert stages. Blame it on musicians' love of convenience, fear of mistakes or urge to modernize; blame it on the fact that audiences hear recorded music far more often than live music, and educate our ears accordingly.

LEAD: A group, Arise of Westbury, has wonderful ideas for an empty property in Freeport (''Proposal for Jobs and Homes Fought,'' April 15). Their plans sound like the perfect answer to a serious social problem. They were certainly widely quoted and much attention was given to their description of a recent meeting.
LEAD: No matter what the situation, never underestimate George Steinbrenner's motives to manipulate it.

LEAD: As he wound down a weeklong visit, Pope John Paul II lectured his Mexican bishops today that they had a duty to speak out on social and ethical issues even if it meant telling political leaders how to act.

LEAD: The King's Singers, like their instrumental counterparts the Canadian Brass, ply the murky waters that lie between the high-minded in music and music that will sell. It is not an easy job. One noticed as much at Alice Tully Hall last Sunday night as these six British vocalists rowed arduously back and forth between Renaissance classics, obscure

LEAD: For quite some time now, a nine-word-question - ''What will become of the Museum of Modern Art?'' - has been rumbling around the art world like a freight train overheard in the dark. Ever since the great first generation of the museum's founders, supporters, curators and miscellaneous adherents began to thin out, that question has been asked.

LEAD: DRASTIC price reductions on condominiums in a converted mill are flushing out buyers for the CDM Development Corporation of Boston, a subsidiary of Camp Dresser & McKee of Boston, an international engineering concern.

LEAD: Though Alexandre Dumas pere is best known for his romantic novels ''The Three Musketeers'' and ''The Count of Monte Cristo,'' he also left a legacy of plays, including ''La Tour de Nesle,'' a bloodthirsty historical melodrama written in 1832. Despite that play's continuing popularity in France, it turns out to be creaky and contrived, not the well-oiled mechanism one would have expected.

LEAD: June wedding plans for Marie Dignam Whelan and Patrick Daniel Dolan, a son of Sally A. Dolan of Bedford Village, N.Y., and Patrick A. Dolan of New York, have been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Jean F. Whelan of Baldwin, L.I.
LEAD: Brightly colored designs on packages of consumer goods help establish brand images and promote sales by catching the eye of consumers as they browse along supermarket aisles.

LEAD: THE dogwood trees are in full bloom. What more glorious sight could spring have? These native trees, which carry their displays in layers, appear as clouds in the woods or as spectacular specimens on home lawns. Travelers drive for miles to see favorite spots where dogwoods grow.
LEAD: GOODBYE WITHOUT LEAVING By Laurie Colwin. 253 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $18.95.
LEAD: LIKE new mothers everywhere, Donna Carter and Angela DuBois like to compare notes about their babies' growth rates, sleeping habits and latest accomplishments.

LEAD: A highly charged issue is looming in relations between the United States and China, and it has Chinese officials and intellectuals concerned over their future, their standard of living and their contacts with the West.

LEAD: Christie, Manson and Woods Ltd. of London will auction a portion of a hoard of coins from the reigns of Henry I, Stephen and Henry II. The 482 coins were discovered in a ditch in Wicklewood, a town near Norwich, Britain in 1989. The hoard consists mainly of pennies, but a third of them are cut farthings and half-pennies.

LEAD: June wedding plans for Juliet B. Karelsen and William F. Roorbach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Roorbach of New Canaan, Conn., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Karelsen 3d of New York.

LEAD: The police detained four neo-Nazi sympathizers today in the desecration of a Jewish cemetery and the mutilation of a corpse, acts that have stirred new fears of anti-Semitism in France. But a police officer who declined to be identified said it was unlikely that neo-Nazis from Avignon were responsible for the desecration of the graves, in nearby Carpentras.

LEAD: ALMOST a year after accepting a special Tony Award for the Hartford Stage Company as outstanding regional theater, Mark Lamos is in the spotlight once more, celebrating 10 years as the theater's artistic director and making his screen debut as an actor.
LEAD: The Knights of Columbus will provide most of the money the nation's Roman Catholic bishops will use for a national campaign against abortion.
LEAD: A MIXED-USE waterfront project that has been plagued with problems for a decade is moving ahead with its final phase, scheduled for completion in 1992.

LEAD: Ken Emerson committed a journalistic impropriety by asking me to comment on a purported statement by Dean Robert Clark, one that was different from the one by Clark that he published. He told me that Clark had said that ordinary people didn't really need lawyers, except for wills and divorces. Clark's actual statement was: ''It might be a sign of ill health in the country if people needed lawyers more.

LEAD: Show time is 10 minutes away and workmen are still swarming the stage of the Palacio de Congresos, Madrid's official fashion theater. The name of Manuel Pina, one of the city's premier designers, appears on a wall at the rear. There, to the staccato of hammering, Pina's logo is being wreathed in a tangle of roses and barbed wire.

LEAD: The house my family has rented and lived in on Nantucket every summer since I was 3 years old was at one time, before the advent of the Coast Guard, a lifesaving station. Weather-beaten, gray-shingled, it sits on a slight rise in the land at the eastern end of the island, the beach and the Atlantic everywhere behind it.

LEAD: Nearly 10 weeks after Hank Gathers, the college basketball star, collapsed during a game and later died, the athlete's family returned today to receive his posthumous bachelor's degree from the college against which the family has filed a $32.5 million negligence suit.

LEAD: Q. We were told recently that the insulation covering the pipes in our basement contains asbestos. Should anything be done to remove this insulation, or is there something we can do ourselves to make sure the asbestos fibers do not contaminate the basement?

LEAD: ATLAS OF HUMAN ANATOMY. By Frank H. Netter. (Ciba-Geigy, 14 Henderson Drive, West Caldwell, N.J. 07006, Cloth, $120; Paper, $49.95.) Commercial art wasn't the career Frank H. Netter's parents wanted for him. Despite his early success as an illustrator in the 1920's, they persuaded him to go to medical school.

LEAD: While I am certainly no Davey Johnson fan, it was not he who stripped a spirited 1986 team of its heart and soul, leaving us with a bland collection of robots, with four third basemen, six starting pitchers, no legitimate center fielder or catcher, no backup shortstop and half the players out of position.

LEAD: For 10 years, since Sony's first Walkman, it has been possible to put music in your pocket. The artistic consequences of this magician's trick are uncertain for the long run, and one wonders what Beethoven would have thought of traipsing about with the ''Eroica.'' As an inveterate hiker, he might even have liked the idea.

LEAD: HUNTING HUMANS: An Encyclopedia of Modern Serial Killers. By Michael Newton. (Loompanics Unlimited, $34.95.) Why an encyclopedia of serial killers? There is probably no satisfactory answer, and perhaps a publisher whose previous efforts include a manual of bodyguarding and a catalogue of poisons (''sold for informational purposes only'') doesn't need one.

LEAD: Women teach at Harvard Law School, too. Currently, there are five tenured women on the faculty - Elizabeth Bartholet, Martha Field, Mary Ann Glendon, Martha Minow and Kathleen Sullivan. The author's failure to include even one reinforces the inferior status afforded female scholars and female lawyers in our society.
LEAD: Bizarre. Poetic. Weird. Gross. Disgusting. Comic. Brilliant. Obnoxious. Stylish. Sadistic. Sorrowful. Puerile. Triumphant. The list goes on.

LEAD: Patricia Gemmell met Brian Dear by replying to a friendly note that appeared on her computer screen one day, a message sent on a computer network linking her machine with many others. She responded with a computer quip of her own and the two, who were programmers at different campuses of the University of Maryland, struck up a friendship that went on electronically for weeks before they finally met.

LEAD: WHEN the Brooklyn pizza joint went up in flames ignited by racial friction in ''Do the Right Thing,'' did this mean movies are telling the world the wrong thing about New York? When Popeye Doyle, pursuing a French connection, just missed the 42d Street shuttle in pursuit of a bad guy, did this mean that crime in New York waits on no man?

LEAD: Subletting in a Co-op Question: I bought my co-op in July 1987 at the peak of the market. At the time, subletting was allowed by the board of directors. It was my plan when I bought the apartment to live in it until I needed more room. Now, I cannot sell without taking a loss, so I want to rent my apartment.
LEAD: In response to Matilda Cuomo's article on breast cancer (Opinion, April 8, ''Taking Aim at a Preventable Tragedy''), I am the perfect example of what she advocates.

LEAD: MONDAY: Report on business inventories for March. The securities fraud trial of John Mulheren, a former abritrager, begins in New York. TUESDAY: Industrial production and capacity utilization for April. The Arizona Biltmore resort and hotel is to be auctioned in Phoenix. Nordstrom annual meeting.

LEAD: In March 1936 the photographer Walker Evans, who was documenting poverty in the South, found himself in Beaufort, S.C., facing an undeniably beautiful 18th-century frame house. The delicate carving around the door frame, the detailed corner moldings and elaborate cornices recalled an era of high style and craftsmanship.
