LEAD: After years of reluctance, a growing number of states have begun recording the names of people who are shown by tests to be infected with the AIDS virus and warning their sex and drug partners.

LEAD: Susan Molinari's recent move up to Congress has generated an unusually lively contest among six active candidates for the City Council seat she relinquished. On Tuesday, voters will, for the first time, fill a Council vacancy. In the past, Council members voted on vacancies, invariably following the dictates of party leaders.
LEAD: A 20th wedding anniversary is an appropriate occasion for reflection and self-evaluation, even if husband and wife are happily living the life styles of the semirich and somewhat famous.

LEAD: There are few things in life more humdrum than the toothbrush. One of them is toothpaste. Yet the unprepossessing goo has for decades occupied the attention of some of the world's largest and savviest manufacturers of consumer products.

LEAD: I have long nursed a secret fantasy of kidnapping Barbara Bush, taking her to a Connecticut hideaway with a perennial border and lots of chintz, and force-feeding her Gatorade until she breaks down and admits that she is pro-choice. This fantasy has nothing to do with Mrs. Bush; it has to do with the role we have been led to believe she plays in the life of her husband.

LEAD: THE woolly adelgids are here - and they are eating Westchester's hemlocks. To combat the creatures, the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation is spraying dormant oil - considered to be safe for the environment, animals and humans - in seven county parks and properties.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: A map on April 22 with an article headed ''What's Doing in Rome'' included several errors, including mislocated or misnamed sites. A corrected map follows.

LEAD: It was a bad week for the dollar. First, on Wednesday, it dropped sharply against the West German mark, the Swiss franc and other European currencies. Then on Friday, the other shoe fell, as the dollar plummeted against the Japanese yen. The dollar has been weak against the mark and most Europen currencies all year but strong against the yen.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in the Business Forum last Sunday about merger regulations in the European Community misstated the Community's rules about when notification of a merger and certain joint ventures must occur. Notification is required when the aggregate worldwide turnover of the companies involved is greater than $6 billion - and two or more of the parties involved have aggregate Community-wide turnover of more than $300 million each.

LEAD: When the cat that disrupted the Athletics-Yankees game in the Oakland Coliseum last Monday night finally made a departure after darting around the outfield and trying to hop the backstop behind home plate, it chose the right exit.

LEAD: When ''Driving Miss Daisy'' topped $100 million at the box office this weekend, that feat underscored something that has become increasingly obvious to movie makers: teen-agers no longer are the prime audience.

LEAD: Recently, on ABC's ''Growing Pains,'' Mike (Kirk Cameron) got what he thought was his big break - a walk-on part in a TV series as a nameless cop dying of gunshot wounds. Mike's sister, Carol (Tracey Gold), recognized the part for the inconsequential bit of body spasm it was and offered only the most measured of congratulations.

LEAD: It was with amusement that I read the comments by Patrick Killian, director of casino economics for the Casino Association, in the article ''Casinos Seek Answers to Scarcity of Employees'' (March 25). Mr. Killian was bemoaning the difficulty of getting people to work in Atlantic City's casinos - particularly older people.

LEAD: Vivian Gornick compares feminism to psychoanalysis, and is saddened that women seem stuck at the level at which insight does not seem to produce real change (''Who Says We Haven't Made A Revolution?'' April 15). I think feminism has achieved more successes, is more popular and has changed women's outlooks more than Gornick recognizes, but in any case her metaphor is misleading.
LEAD: A picture caption in The Times Magazine today with an article about Gata Kamsky, a 15-year-old chess player, describes him incorrectly. He is a candidate for the title of grandmaster.

LEAD: To the Editor: I have traveled to Africa and have been researching the African travel market for six months. One of my research inquiries took me to D. H. Doelker in December after seeing her advertisement in the Travel section.

LEAD: An article yesterday on a speech given by Mayor David N. Dinkins inaccurately described a comment he made about the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins in Brooklyn. The Mayor said he hoped ''those individuals responsible for the death of Yusuf Hawkins will feel the strong arm of the law.''

LEAD: If there were a list of the top 10 artists on college dormitory walls, Lyonel Feininger would surely be on it. His quietly dynamic paintings of new skyscrapers and old churches, old boats and new streets, composed of cubistic planes no thicker than glass or more solid than light but as hard as diamonds and fixed as keystones, have made him a dormitory star.

LEAD: The Pelham Art Center's ''American Cowboy: The Myth and the Reality'' opened a few weeks ago but began months earlier with a publicity campaign. In addition to a blizzard of announcements, this included a search in the New York City area for a live cowboy to star at the opening in return for, among other prizes, lifetime membership in the center.
LEAD: When 253 graduating seniors accept their diplomas on Saturday at Wheaton College, it will be the end of an era that some at the small liberal arts school here say has closed on a sour note.

LEAD: SCAFFOLDING HAS BECOME an integral part of Spain's urban landscape. So have construction crews, churning up clouds of dust and dirt. On almost every major street in cities like Madrid and Barcelona, buildings shrouded in green plastic resemble giant packages waiting to be unwrapped.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Mary Ellen Donovan, a daughter of Daniel J. Donovan of Rye, N.H., and the late Arline Brassil Donovan, was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York to Malcolm Chace Nolen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Nolen of New York. The Rev. Jane P. Henderson officiated.

LEAD: Anne V. Kilcoyne, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Kilcoyne of Bound Brook, N.J., was married there yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church to James F. Slattery 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Slattery Jr. of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. John Coppinger officiated. Mrs. Slattery, a graduate of Rutgers College, received an M.B.A.
LEAD: Drawing on a third-period rally, the Phoenix Suns beat the Los Angeles Lakers by 117-103 today for a two-games-to-one lead in the team's National Basketball Association playoff series.

LEAD: The Seneca Indians called it Gen-nis-he-y, or ''beautiful valley.'' The broad, fertile region spreading westward from New York State's Finger Lakes to the Niagara Frontier also shares its name with America's longest north-flowing river and with a form of malaria (''Genessee fever''), which plagued early pioneers.

LEAD: Q. We were told recently that the insulation covering the pipes in our basement contains asbestos. Should anything be done to remove this insulation, or is there something we can do ourselves to make sure the asbestos fibers do not contaminate the basement?

LEAD: ''This kind of economy can't work for man; it can only work for itself. It produces more and more means of production, that is machines, equipment, electricity, fuel, metals in order to again use all this in the next cycle for still more production of nonconsumable goods. That is, things that people can't eat.

LEAD: EVALD GASSTROM, an industrial engineer and the former owner and president of the Eagle Rule Manufacturing Company, a large tool manufacturer, is an unlikely social worker. Yet some years ago, after Mr. Gasstrom sold his company to the Durall Tool Company in Yonkers, he became the director of a vocational-rehabilitation workshop in East Harlem.

LEAD: Nancy P. Gilbert, the daughter of Mrs. Frederick A. Gilbert of Osterville, Mass., and the late Mr. Gilbert, and K. Kimball Holland, a son of Mrs. G. Kenneth Holland of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Dr. Holland, were married yesterday. The Rev. Avery Manchester performed the nondenominational ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich,

LEAD: If extraterrestrials have ever visited our planet and decide to return, one of the best gifts they could bring is a home movie showing us in our infancy, as well as now-extinct animals and pristine landscapes. Until that day, the best we can do is turn to nature writers to provide us with visions of bygone creatures, civilizations lost to history and unsullied landscapes.

LEAD: Companies that are trying to figure out how they will manage the flow of information in the 1990's and beyond might begin their research with a trip to the library - not to take out a book but to study the ways in which libraries are preparing for the 21st century. In the vanguard of information technology, today's librarians are as likely to be experts in work stations, networking, communications protocols, electronic imaging and fiber optics as they are in books and manuscripts.
LEAD: The new era of German ascendance is already beginning.

LEAD: Peter Schickele is making it an annual event to stage a New York showcase of his music each spring. This year, the forum was fancier than usual, presented at Alice Tully Hall by the Composers' Showcase organization, which in turn is presented by Lincoln Center's Great Performers series.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It is not uncommon for a club to arrange a Pro-Am event in which invited experts play with members. But that requires the cooperation of many stars who may not be willing to spare the time. Few clubs appreciate that a special evening can be built around one or two experts who play each board with a different partner.

LEAD: Little things still mean a lot in fashion, especially if there are lots of them. That might account for the attention that's being paid to accessories, pins in particular, which can set an outfit apart from all others.
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Winans of Bedford, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Winans and James Rossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rossman of Cleveland.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A brief article by The Associated Press in some editions last Sunday about anti-Semitic graffiti at Bertolt Brecht's grave in Berlin misstated the playwright's religion. He was reared as a Lutheran; he was not Jewish. The article also misidentified a country where Brecht lived in exile before settling in East Germany.

LEAD: IN A FEW SHORT YEARS, WHEN MY TWO children will be applying to college, the affirmative-action policies by which most universities offer black students some form of preferential treatment will present me with a dilemma. I am a middle-class black, a college professor, far from wealthy, but also well removed from the kind of deprivation that would qualify my children for the label ''disadvantaged.

LEAD: Quiet and largely unnoticed in its red-brick building two blocks from the White House, the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit is having a revolutionary effect on the ground rules under which technology is developed and controlled in the United States.

LEAD: THE most skilled group of political fund raisers anywhere, members of the United States Senate, came forward last week with what they pronounced as their best efforts at improving the way Senate campaigns raise and spend money.

LEAD: Wind, rain and fast greens have made an already difficult golf course miserably demanding, but not coincidently, two of the game's elite were at the top of the leader board today after three rounds of the Memorial Tournament.
LEAD: It used to be said that in baseball a pitcher's second year was the hardest. The hitters had gotten on to his style by then and were all set to take advantage of its weaknesses.

LEAD: Julie Harris stands in a rehearsal hall dangling a book distastefully, as if it were an insect with 3 heads and 14 legs. Affecting a confident Irish lilt, she charges into her lines: '' 'Ulysses.' A book so dirty that in America it drove them into the streets to fornicate. Aah, but that's literature.

LEAD: Q. We were told recently that the insulation covering the pipes in our basement contains asbestos. Should anything be done to remove this insulation, or is there something we can do ourselves to make sure the asbestos fibers do not contaminate the basement?

LEAD: Tensions in Singapore Twenty-five years after independence from Malaysia, Singapore's dominant Chinese are at odds with the Malay minority. Page 14. Prosecutor for Bomb Case The appointment of a prosecutor hints at a break in the case of mail bombings in the South. Page 23.

LEAD: Diana Adams Blankman, a daughter of Mrs. Samuel E. Baker of Boca Raton, Fla., and Howard Blankman of Port Washington, L.I., and David Bruce Ouimet, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Ouimet of Holyoke, Mass., plan to marry in June.

LEAD: When a two-man team from Coca-Cola's Asian operation arrived at the company's abandoned plant near the Soviet Embassy here the other day, a crowd assembled. It continued to gather for days, even after word passed that it would be weeks, maybe months, before the plant could be re-commissioned.

LEAD: ''E'' IS FOR ELVIS: An A-to-Z Illustrated Guide to the King of Rock and Roll. By Caroline Latham and Jeannie Sakol. (NAL, $19.95.) ''E'' is also for enormous: Elvis Presley, a man of enormous talent and enormous excess, has inspired books of enormous ambition (Greil Marcus's ''Mystery Train''), enormous contempt (Albert Goldman's ''Elvis'') and enormous triviality (too many to single out just one).

LEAD: ''About Long Island: Over the River and Through the Woods'' (April 15) presents an extremely inaccurate and damaging introduction to our Nassau-Suffolk Greenbelt Trail. The article constantly refers to difficult and muddy train conditions, waving a macho flag describing the triumph of man and machine over nature's obstacles.

LEAD: Katherine E. Dietze, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Dietze of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York to Jay M. Courage, a son of Elsa J. Courage of Birmingham, Mich., and Jay W. Courage of Greenville, S.C. The Rev. Jane Henderson officiated.

LEAD: A Federal panel overseeing a test that for 20 years has shown how well schoolchildren are doing in the three R's has voted unanimously to set the first national standards to show how well they ought to be doing.

LEAD: The final concerts of the season's Chamber Music at the Y (meaning the 92d Street Y, of course), on Tuesday and Wednesday nights, were of uncommon interest for three reasons. One, excellent performances. Two, excellent and sometimes unusual music. Three, final proof, if proof were needed, that a wildly international assemblage of musicians can be forged into idiomatic exponents of a national style.
LEAD: A front-page caption and a headline with an article on April 8 about Italian gardens misstated the location of Bagnaia. It is in central, not northern, Italy.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For young Joshua Kotrieb, who dreamed of flying a fighter jet over Europe, the place to go was the Air Force Academy. And he made it, just in time to find out that there would probably be fewer fighter jets and fewer officers flying them.

LEAD: Auctions on Cape Cod, a year-round phenomenon, are a cross between shopping, work and dinner theater. In fact, they combine the best of all three: you can shop sitting down, play the commodities market with real commodities that you carry home in the trunk of your car, catch a comedy act without paying a cover charge and eat for under $5.
LEAD: Two months ago, George Steinbrenner sat with a group of reporters and insisted that Mike Witt would never pitch for the Yankees. Not as long as Steinbrenner was owner of the team, he said.

LEAD: Maintaining their risky ritual despite stern warnings against it, the Blackhawks' fans again filled old Chicago Stadium with smoke and light from hundreds of sparklers tonight as a man sang the national anthem before the game against Edmonton.
LEAD: Apartheid has had a disastrous effect on South Africa's environment, an American report says.

LEAD: Donna W. Avrach, a daughter of Joyce Avrach of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to Lee J. Rosen, a son of Lore Rosen and Jerome Rosen, both of Albany. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel officated at the Loft in New York. Mrs. Avrach Rosen, 29 years old and a vice president at Salomon Brothers in New York, has a bachelor's degree and an M.B.A.

LEAD: ''It's like a prizefight,'' said Tyne Daly of her role in the current Broadway revival of ''Gypsy,'' which last week received five Tony Award nominations, including one for Ms. Daly. ''It's like being in training for a prizefight. The way the part is written, it allows no letdown. Especially on two-performance days - we call them double-headers - that tends to feel more like an athletic event than an artistic experience.

LEAD: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova, rushing the net at every opportunity, thwarted Gabriela Sabatini's baseline game and beat the 19-year-old Argentine, 7-6, 7-5, last night to reach the final of the Italian Open.

LEAD: An article in the Campus Life pages on April 29 incorrectly described a tenure revision proposal defeated by the faculty senate of the University of Connecticut at Storrs. It would have given graduate students, once hired, two years to finish their Ph.D. work before the faculty began to evaluate them for tenure, a process that can last up to seven years.
LEAD: DAVID RIVERA, who is 6 years old, knows what he likes best about visiting the Anderson family in Brick Township.

LEAD: Two picture captions on the Evening Hours page last Sunday misidentified two partygoers. The woman embracing Leontyne Price at a dinner-dance benefit for International House was Daisy Soros, not Annaliese Soros. The man kissing Millicent Johnson's hand at a dinner for the American Academy in Rome was Vieri Traxler, the Italian representative at the United Nations, not Peter F.

LEAD: Senate 1. Hatch Act: Vote to kill an amendment that would have excluded agents of the I.R.S., C.I.A., and F.B.I. from provisions of a bill that would remove most current restrictions on political activies by Federal workers. Approved 51 to 46, May 8. 2. Hatch Act: Vote on passage of a bill that would allow Federal workers to participate in many partisan activities from which they have been excluded for 50 years.

LEAD: Researchers at Battelle Memorial Institute's Pacific Northwest Laboratories have come up with what they call a ''promising'' approach to dealing with radioactive and toxic materials contaminating ground at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington state: they electrocute it. Last month, they drove four 30-foot-long graphite and molybdenum electrodes into the ground at the edges of a site, 40 feet in diameter, contaminated with cesium and strontium and hazardous chemicals.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SEVERAL times a month, trucks laden with waste tires leave the Yonkers compacting station on Saw Mill River Road bound for Port Newark, N.J. There, at Integrated Tire, a recycler licensed by the New Jersey Environmental Protection Department, the tires are shredded into two-inch strips and shipped to be used as a supplemental fuel in making cement.

LEAD: The author theorizes proficiently with many philosophical models. But where are strong political models such as Golda Meir and Margaret Thatcher mentioned? For a serious student of feminism, Gornick might serve us better with a discussion of women who use power well, or even those who have abused it, such as Indira Ghandi.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. David Wallach of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lannie Stacey Wallach to Howard Andrew Lipson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Henry Lipson of Harbor Isle, L.I. A February wedding is planned.

LEAD: IN his first 15 months in the White House, amassing his 70 percent popularity rating, President Bush never once suggested that prospects for the economy were anything but rosy, never mentioned that the budget deficit was a problem that would prove painful to solve and never even hinted that his campaign pledge of ''no new taxes'' was other than the guiding beacon of his Administration.

LEAD: The State Department has ruled that a Chinese couple who fled their homeland's family-planning policy qualify for refugee status, clearing the way for them to receive political asylum, their lawyer said on Friday.

LEAD: A new congregation of 150 Jewish families in Woodbury, L.I., has contracted to buy six acres from Roman Catholic nuns as the site for what may be the first Conservative synagogue to be built in Nassau County in many years. The Woodbury Jewish Center will be built on South Woods Road across the street from Our Lady of Mercy Academy, operated by the Order of the Sisters of Mercy.

LEAD: Loryn R. Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold S. Cohen of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester in Rye, N.Y., to Michael L. Kass, a son of Harriet Marcus and Dr. Alfred Kass, both of Columbus, Ohio. Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated. Mrs. Kass, 24 years old and a graduate of Tulane University, is an associate at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Neither New York manager will be around by the All-Star Game break. In Dent's case, it is traditional that the field manager take the blame for the poor cast, spelled mainly, P-I-T-C-H-I-N-G, assembled by Steinbrenner. As for Johnson, he should not have been brought back this year; instead of starting afresh, the Met front office sacrificed two coaches for Johnson's inability to lead this club.
LEAD: Should a university rooted in Roman Catholicism give financial aid to a student organization that supports the right to abortion?

LEAD: Coba Zanoli is 78 years old. Last year, when she became sick, her grandson, Michael, tried to cheer her. He said he would bring her from the Netherlands to the United States this year to watch him race.
LEAD: Now that George Steinbrenner has said he will not interfere with Bucky Dent, rrBucky's gone, unfortunately. Perhaps before this writing.

LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on April 29 misstated United Airlines' policy on exchanging a ticket when a lower fare for the same destination is advertised, based on information provided by the airline. A ticket may be exchanged if the difference between fares is more than $25, the airline says, but all conditions for the new fare, including advance-purchase restrictions, must be met, and space must be available in the new booking class on the same flight.

LEAD: ''Not too many people wear kimonos anymore,'' said Toshio Goma, a textile and kimono designer in Japan who has been trying to introduce the radiant colors of the traditional aristocratic kimono fabrics to American designers. Mr. Goma, who is 45 years old and a descendant of 14 generations of kimono artists, seems to be succeeding.

LEAD: A day after Mayor David N. Dinkins issued a rare televised appeal for racial harmony in New York City, black demonstrators marched through two racially troubled neighborhoods in Brooklyn yesterday, calling even more attention to two highly publicized bias incidents.

LEAD: TO some, it seemed like business as usual: the nation's largest owner and operator of private prisons purchased 40 acres from a group of local officials, including a State Senator who was instrumental in persuading the Legislature to approve a contract with the company to build and operate a women's prison on the site.

LEAD: Serene Fields will tell you, in no uncertain terms, that she wants to be a lawyer when she grows up. Jeremy Singer plans to build supercomputers. After all, he's ''a master'' at Nintendo. And if you look at Hector Conesa's sneakers, you'll know what his ambitions are.

LEAD: THE BFI COMPANION TO THE WESTERN. Edited by Edward Buscombe. (Atheneum, $50.) Remember the western? Edward Buscombe of the British Film Institute does, and he and a legion of contributors have produced a magnificent, lavishly packaged compendium of facts, figures, maps, thumbnail biographies and capsule reviews for the enjoyment and edification of fans of this fast disappearing cultural product.

LEAD: As a 1973 graduate of the Harvard Law School who began her studies there 20 years ago - when the 7 percent admission for women was considered a radical new policy - I was both interested and dismayed by what Ken Emerson reports to be the state of legal education there (''When Legal Titans Clash,'' April 22).
LEAD: Whether Davey or Bucky goes, or should go, is unimportant. Whether it will ever again be a consistent joy to be a baseball fan in New York is at stake.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Reed of Greenwich, Conn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Traci Reed and William Bradner Dippy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Dippy 3d of Old Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: LIKE many of the county's older villages, Tuckahoe had been showing signs of age. When village officials discovered that the rumbling of car and truck traffic over the Main Street bridge had doubled in a decade, they called in state engineers to evaluate the health of the 75-year-old structure - the only western access to the business district.

LEAD: However bad the living conditions for most foreign hostages in Lebanon, Frank Herbert Reed said they were worse for him. Mr. Reed, one of two recently released American hostages, said at news conference last week that he was singled out for harsh treatment by his Shiite fundamentalist abductors and that his 43 months in captivity were punctuated by beatings that at various times left his feet, ribs and nose broken.

LEAD: Your article suggests to me that the Harvard Law School may take itself a bit too seriously. The chief architect of the law in the last decade is a man who never attended Harvard or any other law school, i.e. Ronald Reagan. It is temperament, not intellect, that largely determines legal decisions - a fact well illustrated by the schisms at Harvard itself.

LEAD: Hundreds of people angry over a state report on the future of the Adirondacks clogged Interstate 87 north of Albany on Friday by driving at speeds as low as 5 miles an hour, the state police said.

LEAD: CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA., IS AN IDEAL SITE FORJU the study of American rhythms and continuities. On the famous lawn of the University of Virginia is the cloister where Edgar Allan Poe had his quarters - commemorated today by a plaque reading domus parva magni poetae. On a hill 10 miles away is Monticello, the exquisite home that Thomas Jefferson built for himself, with its slave quarters still visible (even more limited in space and comfort than Poe's), and another touching memorial, a stone obelisk at Jefferson's grave recalling his role as author of the Declaration of Independence and the

LEAD: The Fund for the City of New York was the constructive outcome of a twinge of guilt. In the late 1960's, the Ford Foundation moved into its handsome and lavish headquarters on East 42d Street. Yet because the foundation is a charitable institution, it paid no city taxes on the building.

LEAD: In a rare and dramatic televised speech from City Hall Friday night, Mayor David Dinkins turned from quiet diplomacy to leadership. His ringing personal appeal for racial tolerance and healing deserves the attention and respect of all fair-minded New Yorkers.

LEAD: AN unfamiliar sight on the Queens shore in Astoria has been capturing the attention of viewers from Manhattan and the Triborough Bridge lately. At a bend in the waterfront called Pot Cove stands a broad new building with a pyramid-like roof, recently topped out at its full 23 stories.

LEAD: THE Chinese use fresh ginger in their cooking the way Westerners use salt and pepper. But in recent years it has been showing up more and more in dishes that are not in the least Chinese. Ginger adds a refreshing tartness to fish and chicken, perks up marinades, and is also good with vegetables such as mustard greens or broccoli rabe, adding a slightly sharp spicy taste that counteracts their bitterness.

LEAD: HAVING already played a large role in reshaping the corridor between Times Square and Columbus Circle, with four projects finished or close to completion, the Zeckendorf Company has set its sights even higher, involving itself in three more developments that are now germinating.

LEAD: Ten years ago, John Ford Noonan wrote ''A Coupla White Chicks Sitting Around Talking.'' In his new show, he is once again up to his conversational tricks. This time he is also onstage. In the two-character comedy ''Talking Things Over With Chekhov,'' he plays a playwright drawn to his own dimensions - always amiable and seemingly undisturbed by questions of theatrical form.

LEAD: THE RIDDLE OF THE SPHINX, UPDATED: is it falling down or not? During the replacement of masonry on the paws and flanks in the last decade, speculation has been ongoing about the ultimate fate of the monumental man-lion hybrid at Giza, Egypt. Dating from approximately 2550 B.C., the 66-foot-high Sphinx was fashioned from low-grade limestone that historians believe was the inferior remains of the area quarried for the first pyramid.
LEAD: When Britons think of blacksmithing, they tend to think of horses and horseshoes, or ironwork embellished with ornate curves and flourishes.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Suzanne Gluck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Gluck of New York, was married last evening to Thomas E. Dyja, the son of Margaret Dyja of Chicago and the late Edward Dyja, by Rabbi David M. Posner at the Harmonie Club in New York.

LEAD: The Boston Ballet's new ''Swan Lake,'' staged by Konstantin Sergeyev and Natalya Dudinskaya of the Kirov Ballet and led for three weeks this month by mixed casts that pair Soviet stars with dancers from the Boston company, has inevitably attracted much attention.
LEAD: About 100,000 people rallied in the center of Prague today to demand that ousted Communist leaders be punished for crimes committed during four decades of totalitarian rule.

LEAD: The engagement of Elizabeth Ann O'Neill to James Anthony Mercadante, the son of Dr. and Mrs. James L. Mercadante of Garden City, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. O'Neill of Garden City. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Anita B. Elkind, a daughter of Marilyn B. Elkind of Somers, N.Y., and Victor Elkind of La Jolla, Calif., was married last evening at Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers to Dr. Richard M. Pomerantz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pomerantz of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Klausner officiated. Mrs. Pomerantz, 23 years old and a cum laude graduate of Wellesley College, is the general manager of the Argus Computerized Exchange, an information service in Burlington, Mass.

LEAD: RIVERFRONT communities along the Hudson must cooperate to protect a region so threatened by unplanned development and loss of open space that it could become ''the largest suburb ever built in New York State,'' a state commission reported last week.
LEAD: A NUMBER of Westchester artists are in the concert spotlight this week, with the youngest being a fifth grader from Scarsdale, Daishin Kashimoto.

LEAD: PARSONS' MILL, by Timothy Lewontin. (Plume, $8.95.) Seeking the ennobling virtues of hard work, an overeducated New Englander takes a job at a Vermont sawmill. ''A delightful, surprisingly absorbing account'' of his year as an apprentice sawyer, this book ''approaches the gung-ho participatory journalism that George Plimpton performed in his athletic days,'' Bill Kent said here last year.

LEAD: Kalev Tanner will tell you that ''Gorbachev started it all'' and why, as a result, he believes himself to be ''the first and only'' Soviet citizen to receive an undergraduate degree in the United States.
LEAD: FRUIT TRAMPS A Family of Migrant Farmworkers. By Herman LeRoy Emmet. Illustrated. 58 pp. Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $24.95.

Bober officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Stephen Martyr.

LEAD: Syracuse, the defending national champion and unbeaten in its last 24 games, and Yale, which fell one goal short of its first undefeated season, were seeded first and second yesterday in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I lacrosse tournament.

LEAD: COMPANIES Speculation that Donald J. Trump might be working out a deal involving his three casinos has almost replaced slot machines as the most popular game in Atlantic City. Mr. Trump has encouraged the speculaton by saying publicly that he is interested in raising cash and might consider selling or refinancing some of his properties.
LEAD: Kidney failure was suspected in the death of an elephant whose calf was stillborn in a Caesarean section last month, Burnet Park Zoo officials said today.

LEAD: ''I want to say Happy Mother's Day to my mother and every other mother out there,'' said Andrew Dice Clay at the end of his appearance as host of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live.'' Making mothers and other women happy has never been one of his priorities before, of course. It was the unrelenting misogyny of the comedian's enormously popular stand-up routine that led Nora Dunn, a regular cast member, and Sinead O'Connor, the scheduled musical guest, to boycott Saturday's show.

LEAD: The Solidarity chairman, Lech Walesa, said today that he is ready to do battle with his former allies in the Polish Cabinet, accusing them of being slow in carrying out economic and political reforms.

LEAD: The Joffrey Ballet, in financial and aministrative turmoil since the resignation on May 1 of Gerald Arpino, its artistic director and resident choreographer, distributed dancers' salaries on Saturday afternoon at the Music Center of Los Angeles County, where the company performs through May 27.
LEAD: Jay Tibbs and four relievers combined on a five-hitter as the Baltimore Orioles beat Oakland, 4-1, today and swept their first series against the Athletics since May 1987.

LEAD: Insect Migration Q. Why do some insects migrate? A. The migratory pattern in insects is not well understood in many cases, according to the Xerces Society in Portland, Ore., which is dedicated to the conservation of invertebrates (and is named after an extinct butterfly). ''In a few cases, interesting theories relate to climate, food availability and predation,'' said a spokeswoman, who asked that her name be withheld.

LEAD: Craig Janney, having downshifted and sidestepped his way across the blue line, buried his head and then his shot, the puck clanging off the far post and into the net. An instant later, the post wasn't the only thing ringing.

LEAD: A man who is in prison for a serious crime is found to have a recurrence of cancer. It is a cancer that can be treated if action is taken promptly; otherwise it is almost invariably fatal. The prison authorities delay, for weeks, his getting the necessary treatment.
LEAD: The Government today decreed strikes by public workers illegal, urged thousands of striking state employees to return to work and threatened to fire anyone who did not comply.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in SportsMonday on the Baltimore Orioles' victory over the Oakland A's misstated the results of the weekend series between the teams. The Orioles won two of the three games in the series, not all three. The headline repeated the error.
LEAD: Jurors in the Bensonhurst case asked the judge yesterday whether they could convict Joseph Fama of murder even if they found that he did not fire the fatal shots at Yusuf K. Hawkins.

LEAD: Allen H. Morgan, an environmentalist, died of cancer on Sunday at the Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass. He was 64 years old and lived in Wayland, Mass.

LEAD: Andrei P. Kirilenko, a former member of the Soviet Politburo who was a longtime associate of Leonid I. Brezhnev, has died, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: Like many things in fashion today, stylish hair is going in two directions at once. It's super smart to crop one's hair as short as a boy's. It is equally chic to swoop long tresses up into a pile on the top of the head, with wisps of tendrils trickling down to tickle the face.
LEAD: The Buddha of Suburbia By Hanif Kureishi 284 pages. Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: Robert Wilentz, New Jersey's Chief Justice, is thought to be the enlightened leader of one of the more enlightened state supreme courts. But in recent days he has subjected his glowing reputation to the smoke of a cinematic bonfire.

LEAD: The president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice canceled classes yesterday after students demanding the suspension of three administrators vowed to continue their occupation of one of the school's two main buildings.

LEAD: A Government spokesman expressed concern today about racial and ethnic tensions in New York City involving Korean-Americans, and said it might help if blacks from the United States could visit South Korea ''We're very much aware of this problem and very willing to come out and alleviate these misunderstandings,'' said Park Shin Il, director of the South Korean Overseas Information
LEAD: Dennis Scott, the high-scoring swingman who helped Georgia Tech reach the Final Four this year, is giving up his final year of college eligibility to enter the N.B.A. draft next month.
LEAD: The stage was set yesterday for what is likely to be the only statewide primary this September and the most hotly contested statewide general election in November - both for state comptroller.
LEAD: A desert wind soothes this grove of academe far from Palestinian revolt, and the calm, said Mikhail Zusman, lately of Kharkov in the Ukraine, is to his liking.

LEAD: About 2,000 people gathered in Union Square Park in Manhattan yesterday afternoon to hear writers, actors, politicians and others call for legislation to extend the life of the National Endowment for the Arts without any restrictions on its grant-giving policies.

LEAD: Flour mill employees who have worked with grain pesticides for many years face a risk of cancer that can be nine times the risk faced by other workers in the grain industry, a new study has found.
LEAD: J. Francis Canny, an executive recruiter, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.
LEAD: Four days after they traded him to the California Angels, Dave Winfield arrived at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon prepared to play for the Yankees.

LEAD: Lionel Leisure Inc., the toy retailer, has awarded Ketchum Advertising in Philadelphia the creative portion of the accounts for its Lionel Kiddie City and Lionel Playworld. Ketchum replaces LevLane Advertising, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. Lee Media will continue to do the media buying for the accounts, which have a broadcast budget of $6 million to $8 million.
LEAD: International A2-12

LEAD: IT was time to ante up last week on the latest global deal to save the ozone layer, and the Bush Administration decided not to play: The White House announced it would not share the cost of weaning poor countries from the use of ozone-depleting chemicals before they became truly addicted. Subsidies to encourage the substitution of nonpolluting gases in air-conditioners, refrigerators and plastic insulation, the Administration suggested, would have to come from the existing resources of the World

LEAD: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., New York, a subsidiary of American Express Co., named James M. Li executive vice president and chief quality and credit officer. American Express named Stephen Friedman president of Travel Related Services for Japan and East Asia, and Alberto Modolo president of Travel Related Services for Australia, the South Pacific and South Asia.
LEAD: For the second time in a week of deliberations in the Bensonhurst case, the jury considering the charges against Keith Mondello told the judge that it was deadlocked on some of the charges.

LEAD: New York State's legislative leaders today reached a final accord on a $1.4 billion package of taxes and fees that would raise the price of dozens of goods and services, including liquor, soda, car rentals and parking.

LEAD: The Philippine Government formally told the United States today that the 1947 agreement allowing American military bases here would not be extended when it expires in September 1991. The step was largely symbolic, and both Philippine and American officials said a new treaty could still be negotiated.

LEAD: AN Englishman named Andrew Barr has written one of the most interesting books on wine to come along in some time. It's called ''Wine Snobbery,'' and two years after it was published in England, he is still in a peck of trouble.
LEAD: Backstage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on a recent Saturday night, Garrison Keillor, the humorist, looked somber. It was hard to see why.
LEAD: The Vatican and Romania today re-established diplomatic relations that were broken by the former hard-line Communist Government 40 years ago.

LEAD: Five men were arrested today inside an Atlanta abortion clinic, a day after the United States Supreme Court upheld an injunction that has kept protesters away from the clinics. The five protesters entered the Atlanta Surgicenter early today and locked themselves together with chain-like bicycle locks, officials said.
LEAD: DEAR Diary:

LEAD: President Bush is sending three senior officials to India and Pakistan in an effort to ease tensions between the two countries over the disputed territory of Kashmir, the White House said today.
LEAD: Murders, rapes and robberies in New York City rose in January far above the number for the same month last year, according to police statistics released yesterday.

LEAD: Striking civil servants loyal to the opposition Sandinista Front ignored a Government ultimatum ordering them to return to work by 9 A.M. today, confronting the new and impoverished Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro with its first serious political crisis.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: This year's Cannes International Film Festival has entered its pretty phase, with two outstandingly lovely-looking major selections. Both ''Night Sun,'' which brings the visual style of the brothers Paolo and Vittorio Taviani to bear upon a story by Tolstoy, and ''Daddy Nostalgie,'' Bertrand Tavernier's loving look at the last days spent together by a daughter and her dying father, are elegant and supremely romantic visual achievements.
LEAD: Itineraries for 3 V.I.P.'s Mikhail S. Gorbachev is turning his journey to the summit in Washington into a continent-wide tour. Page A8.

LEAD: If you had any questions about the relationship of the Communist Manifesto, the Bible, the Central Intelligence Agency, a burning American flag and Big Band music to the Bensonhurst murder trial, you could have found someone very glad to enlighten you yesterday outside State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
LEAD: An Asian Winner

LEAD: After three troubled weeks trying to steady a wiggling spacecraft and fix its sights on the heavens, ground controllers said yesterday that the Hubble Space Telescope was responding reliably to commands and was for the first time focusing on guide stars. This apparently clears the way for the telescope to take its first picture on Sunday.

LEAD: Peter R. Knauss, an expert on Africa who was an associate professor of political science at the University of Illinois at Chicago, died of AIDS on Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 52 years old and lived in Evanston. Dr. Knauss's area of expertise was African politics. He joined the faculty in 1968; in 1988 he was promoted to associate professor.

LEAD: K. C. Jones, who played on eight Boston Celtics teams that won National Basketball Association championships and coached two others that captured titles, yesterday was named head coach of the Seattle SuperSonics. Jones, 58 years old, succeeds Bernie Bickerstaff, who will become the team's vice president in charge of operations.
LEAD: Gov. Robert P. Casey's plan to reduce automobile insurance premiums has suffered several legal setbacks, raising a question as to whether consumers will get their promised reductions on July 1.
LEAD: The brazen cry to raise taxes in 1990 has to be the most shameless assault on Americans' pocketbooks in this century.

LEAD: Gene Littler, the 1961 United States Open champion and seven-time Ryder Cup team member, and three others have been elected to the PGA World Golf Hall of Fame in Pinehurst, N.C., and will be inducted on Nov. 3.

LEAD: Harland Clement Forbes, a retired chief executive of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died of pneumonia yesterday at Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 92 years old and had lived in Sarasota since moving there from Manhasset, L.I., in 1965.

LEAD: May 11: The Yankees, in Seattle for a series against the Mariners, announce that Dave Winfield, their 38-year-old outfielder, has been traded to the California Angels for a pitcher, Mike Witt. Winfield, citing a clause in baseball's basic labor agreement that says he can veto the trade, says he won't go.
LEAD: First Arthur Field pleaded ignorance. Then he told the state trooper who had pulled him over that he had taken a wrong turn. ''I'm not sure where I am,'' he said.

LEAD: * Air and Water Technologies Corp., Branchburg, N.J., an environmental treatment and services company, said Compagnie Generale des Eaux, France, would purchase $100 million of Air and Water Class A common stock in a private placement.
LEAD: Peter C. Stocker, a Northern California real estate developer, was killed Saturday in a helicopter crash in Monterey County, Calif. He was 47 years old and lived in Sausalito, Calif.

LEAD: It was a routine week night at Videoplus. Youngsters scanned the racks for ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles.'' High-school girls giggled at a Patrick Swayze poster. And John Schnaubelt, one of a half-dozen adults in the store, strode to the counter with two tapes that will never be reviewed by Siskel and Ebert: ''Ginger's Boy-Girl Hits'' and ''Splash Shots.

LEAD: In his first year in office, President Bush received 83 caps, 66 golf balls, 51 neckties, 36 shirts, 25 books about the Constitution, 13 pairs of cowboy boots, 9 Mickey and Minnie Mouse dolls, 6 fishing rods, 3 tins of caviar and 2 ''We the People'' cufflinks. The Gorbachevs gave him a box of Christmas tree ornaments.
LEAD: Jazzman From Moscow

LEAD: It's hardly a secret that the Central Intelligence Agency helped arrange the 1953 coup in Iran that restored the Shah to his Peacock Throne. When the deed was done, His Imperial Majesty offered this toast to Kermit Roosevelt, then head of the C.I.A.'s Middle East operations: ''I owe my throne to God, my people, my army - and to you!
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc. is offering $150 million in notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 9.95 percent three-year notes are priced at 100, to yield 135 basis points more than Treasuries with a similar maturity. Noncallable by the company, the notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by Standart & Poor's.

LEAD: Kathryn B. McGrath, the director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment management division, announced today that she will resign next month to become a partner in the Washington office of Morgan Lewis & Bockius, a New York-based law firm.

LEAD: Citibank announced yesterday that it would spend $20 million over the next 10 years to improve urban schools in a variety of ways, including the development of new approaches to teaching and the promotion of technology in the classroom.

LEAD: A Soviet athlete who finished second in the women's division of the Los Angeles Marathon on March 4, has tested positive for steroid use and will be suspended from competition in the United States for two years, The Athletics Congress announced yesterday.

LEAD: Amid a growing Justice Department investigation into complaints of mistreatment of aliens at the Krome Detention Center here, additional former detainees at the center are making complaints of sexual harassment and physical abuse.
LEAD: Debt
LEAD: Mary Oppen, an author and artist, died of ovarian cancer on Monday at Alta Bates-Herrick Hospital in Berkeley, Calif. She was 81 years old and lived in Albany, Calif.
LEAD: ONE of my longtime guidelines as a restaurant critic is this: ''The quality of food is in inverse proportion to the altitude of the dining room, with airplanes the extreme example.''

LEAD: Faced with slack sales and competition against its most successful vehicles, the Chrysler Corporation will announce this week that it plans to offer a powerful two-seat sports car late next year. The plans for the car, to be called the Dodge Viper, were confirmed by Chrysler managers today in response to a press report.
LEAD: Southpoint, a regional general interest magazine, will cease publication with its June issue.
LEAD: A map accompanying an article yesterday about plans for the Hudson River waterfront incorrectly located the areas where real estate development would be banned.

LEAD: Minutes before he was to argue that burning the flag is protected by the First Amendment, WILLIAM M. KUNSTLER went before the Supreme Court Justices Monday in a gentler cause. The civil liberties lawyer vouched for KARIN KUNSTLER GOLDMAN, his daughter, as worthy to be admitted to the Supreme Court bar.
LEAD: IN ''Food,'' his highly personal one-volume encyclopedia, the late Waverley Root began the three-page entry on peas with this anecdote:

LEAD: On a night when Don Mattingly hit his 100th home run at Yankee Stadium and the Yankees swept to a decisive 7-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins, the main questions for Manager Bucky Dent after the game had to do with the man who was not there, Dave Winfield, and the one whose own days might be numbered, himself.

LEAD: Michael N. Hammes is moving from the Chrysler Corporation to the Black & Decker Corporation, where he will be executive vice president and president of its power tools group, the No. 2 post in the organization.

LEAD: The nomination of Assistant Treasury Secretary David W. Mullins Jr. to a vacant seat on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board was endorsed today by the Senate Banking Committee. The committee voted, 18 to 0, to forward the nomination to the full Senate, which is expected to approve it. Mr. Mullins, who is 44 years old, is an architect of President Bush's savings and loan industry bailout.

LEAD: Castle & Cooke Inc. said today that it would delay separating its food and real estate businesses because of tax questions and a tightening of credit available to companies in the real estate industry.

LEAD: JUST as thin-crusted pizzas were a hot snack of the '80s, satays - the grilled meat, fish or vegetables so common in Asia - may be a snack of the '90s. At least Rick and Ann Yoder, owners of the Wild Ginger, an Asian restaurant that opened here last July, hope so.
LEAD: The Outdoors column in Sports Pages on Friday, about fly fishing in the Catskills, misidentified a family of fly tiers who own a fly shop in Roscoe, N.Y. They are Walt, Winnie and Mary Dette.

LEAD: Moving to promote United States exports more aggressively, the Bush Administration today announced an initiative aimed at inducing other developed countries, principally Japan and France, to curb their export-aid programs.

LEAD: Sikh militants impersonating Government security troops shot and killed seven Hindus after luring them out of their homes in the northern state of Punjab, the police said today. The killings occurred late Monday in Darrowali, 42 miles north of the Sikh holy city of Amritsar.

LEAD: Tomas Cardinal O Fiaich, Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, was buried today after a Requiem Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Armagh, Northern Ireland, with a call by the senior Bishop of that province for an end to violence between its Protestants and Catholics.
LEAD: Rejecting complaints by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., the White House says President Bush does not want to weaken the nation's primary law protecting endangered animals and plants.

LEAD: THE struggle for control of the Kollmorgen Corporation, which has been going on for more than a year, may come to a conclusion next week as shareholders decide whether to keep current management or vote in directors from the Vernitron Corporation, a rival maker of electric motors. It is a fight that all sides may wish had never begun.

LEAD: An investor group that includes Richard E. Rainwater, the Fort Worth financier, today took what appeared to be a final step toward completing its bid for control of the Penrod Drilling Company by agreeing to acquire 31.3 percent of Penrod's debt and equity held by four banks.

LEAD: It's not every fighter who can win a single boxing match three times, but then not every boxer calls himself the Magician. Dennis Milton does, however, and yesterday, he achieved his third victory in a middleweight bout against Michael (the Silk) Olajide in Albany last Dec. 1.

LEAD: If you believe that one good reason for going to the theater is to escape television sitcoms, you may not be tickled to end up at ''The Cemetery Club,'' the new attraction at the Brooks Atkinson. From its peppy canned theme music to its final-scene sermonizing, this comedy about three Jewish widows in Forest Hills, Queens, is ''Golden Girls'' at four times the length but with at most one-fourth the star wattage.

LEAD: A map accompanying an article yesterday about plans for the Hudson River waterfront incorrectly located the areas where real estate development would be banned. A corrective map appears on page B4.

LEAD: The White House disclosed a public schedule today for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to the United States that made it clear that the Soviet leader has seized control of his itinerary in a manner befitting the master showman of international politics.

LEAD: Fed up with the proliferation of violent toys for children? So is the San Francisco advertising agency Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley and its client Dakin Inc., a maker of heart-melting stuffed animals. Hence the agency's first campaign for Dakin, which contrasts the company's cuddly toys with the competition's war toys and violent video games.

LEAD: In the African context, an unusual event occurred in Botswana last October: national elections were held among eight competing political parties. When some of the results were disputed, the judiciary, not the politicians, interceded.

LEAD: The co-chairmen of the Knight Foundation Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics said today that the 22-member panel would likely press for more liberal allowances for recruits, the abolition of athletic dormitories and an end to off-season tournaments for prep basketball players.

LEAD: Gen. Michel Aoun, who says he is the leader of Lebanon's only legitimate government, has reportedly offered to step aside if asked to do so by the head of his Maronite Catholic Church, newspapers here have reported.

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank System, a network of 12 regional banks that lend money to savings and loan associations, tapped the securities market yesterday with an $875 million offering at par of one-year and two-year bonds through various securities dealers.
LEAD: Interest rates declined yesterday for the second consecutive week at Citicorp's regular auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Judge Wayne E. Scarbrough of Criminal Court in Queens, died of a brain aneurysm on Monday at the Golden Hill Health Care Center in Milford, Conn. He was 43 years old and lived in Rosedale, Queens.

LEAD: In a surprise vote five minutes before a midnight deadline, the New York City Board of Estimate unanimously agreed last night to issue a preliminary denial of Time Warner's applications to renew the two cable television franchises it controls in Manhattan.

LEAD: The REV. BERNICE ALBERTINE KING spent an exhilarating day Monday. More than 20 years after her father, the REV. DR. MARTIN LUTHER KING JR., delivered his last sermon at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, she gave her first.
LEAD: A seasonal sales increase expected by automobile makers and dealers has still not materialized, with sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks falling by 8.7 percent in early May.

LEAD: Washington Barella, a Brazilian oboist, and the Meridian Arts Ensemble, a New York City-based brass quintet, have been named first-prize winners in Concert Artists Guild's 1990 New York competition. The award includes $2,500 in cash, a three-year recording contract on Channel Classics' Winning Artists series, recitals in New York and other cities, and management by Concert Artists

LEAD: Crowds of anti-independence protesters stormed the Parliament buildings in Latvia and neighboring Estonia today in the largest display of physical force since the Baltic republics began their formal withdrawal from the Soviet Union.

LEAD: It was just like old times, except for one small detail. When Gary Carter sliced a double down the right-field line to drive in the deciding run tonight, then thrust his fist into the air, he did not do it for the Mets.

LEAD: The much-heralded Detroit Pistons' defense was just too much for the Knicks tonight.

LEAD: Many of the players who competed in the Cavendish Charity Invitational Pairs over the weekend stayed to compete in the Cavendish Teams, a three-session event that began Monday night. Exactly half of the 12 competing squads consisted largely or wholly of players from other continents.

LEAD: Grace Lee Nute, a historian and educator who was a retired research associate at the Minnesota Historical Society, died May 4 at a nursing home in Menlo Park, Calif. She was 94 years old and lived in Walnut Creek, Calif.

LEAD: Henry P. Hayes, a retired executive of the National Broadcasting Company, died of complications from a series of strokes Monday at Meadow Lakes, a retirement community in Hightstown, N.J., where he lived. He was 83 years old and had been a longtime resident of Manhattan.
LEAD: On a national scale, yields on certificates of deposit were down and money market accounts were up for the week ended yesterday.

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's new interest in moving up German unification seems based largely on the perception that his election chances could be hurt if he waits too long.

LEAD: OF the thousands of creative partnerships in advertising agencies large and small, perhaps none is stronger than the one that bonds Charlie Moss and Stan Dragoti. It has survived Mr. Moss's ascension to agency leadership; he is now the vice chairman and corporate creative director of Wells, Rich, Greene Inc.

LEAD: KEVIN GREENE hates jokes about airline food. And as director of catering services for Pan American World Airways at Kennedy International Airport, he's heard them all.
LEAD: By the end of tonight's game, the Knicks looked like a tired team that needed a vacation.

LEAD: A Federal district judge in Washington has ordered Price Waterhouse, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, to give a partnership to a woman who said she was denied the promotion in 1983 because of negative sexual stereotypes.

LEAD: It was March 1945, the war against Germany dragged on and everything was in short supply. But with France already liberated, Paris found an ingenious way of proclaiming that it was still the world capital of fashion.
LEAD: Opening arguments were held today in a Federal trial resulting from the slaying of the American anti-drug agent Enrique Camarena and three other men in Mexico.

LEAD: With Federal aid for student grants and loans down dramatically from levels of a decade ago, college administrators predict that fewer and fewer colleges will be able to guarantee financial aid to all the students they admit.

LEAD: Two judges supervising hundreds of asbestos-damage cases said yesterday that they might seek to reopen the bankruptcy proceeding of the Manville Corporation and suggested that the multibillion-dollar trust set up by the company to compensate victims of asbestos-related diseases had been mismanaged.

LEAD: In the recent National Football League draft of college players, 18 were juniors taking advantage of the pros' new openness to underclassmen. But 20 other juniors went unchosen. They ended up without contracts and, thanks to an antiquated notion of amateurism, without the option to resume their collegiate playing careers.
LEAD: Plans are afoot for building another beltway around Washington. It would lie outside the present beltway, so, naturally, it is already being called ''the outer beltway.''
LEAD: A $166.5 million bond offering by the New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation was tentatively priced yesterday to yield a maximum of about 7.719 percent for bonds due in 2012.
LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average seesawed throughout the session yesterday, ending with a small gain and breaking through to another high at 2,822.45.
LEAD: A Federal judge today declared mandatory drug tests for lawyers applying to work in the Justice Department's antitrust division to be unconstitutional.

LEAD: Declaring that the system for handling death penalty appeals in the Federal courts ''verges on the chaotic,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist today issued his most direct call for passage of a bill to place strict new limits on appeals by death row prisoners.

LEAD: The President and leaders of Congress have a splendid opportunity this week to enhance their political popularity. If they can agree on a credible plan for eliminating the Federal deficit over the next several years, they can strengthen the economy, restore faith in the democratic process and prove cynics wrong.
LEAD: His birthday was April 20, but the party was last night. Former Mayor ROBERT F. WAGNER was 80 years old and hundreds of friends gathered at the Winter Garden to celebrate.
LEAD: * Guinness Import Company, to Mathieu, Goluskin, Donovan & Clarke, for its Moosehead brand beer, for a summer promotional campaign with a budget of $3 million.
LEAD: PERRIER, long the king of bubbly water, is back on the market. But customers are not flocking to the green pear-shaped bottles like so many subjects to a returning monarch.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in quiet trading yesterday, as dealers took profits after the recent strong rally.
LEAD: A Montana State University student killed two other students with a shotgun early this morning and was then captured almost 100 miles away, the authorities said.
LEAD: * W. Dillaway Ayres Jr. has joined the investment banking firm of Veronis, Suhler & Associates Inc. as senior vice president concentrating on the broadcasting field.

LEAD: Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont told Barnard College's graduating class yesterday that women are, as never before, poised to play a greater role in world politics, the environment and the economy.

LEAD: With its ancient copper mash vats, ponderous oak barrels and age-old beer-making techniques, this city's famed Pilsner Urquell brewery long took a back seat to other enterprises as Communist central planners invested massively in favored industries like machinery and steel.

LEAD: In a long-awaited agreement that will keep a vital semiconductor technology under United States ownership, a California company said yesterday that it would acquire a division of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation that makes the sophisticated machines needed to develop the world's most-advanced computer chips.
LEAD: The number of dropouts who receive high school equivalency degrees has significantly declined, the American Council on Education said today.

LEAD: For nearly 60 years, visitors have made the journey to this remote town in western Michigan, drawn to the big yellow-brick factory suffused with the warm aromas of mashed peas and steamed squash.

LEAD: Under pressure from students occupying a campus building, the president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice said yesterday that he would accede to some of their demands, including granting tenure to a popular Hispanic professor.
LEAD: Warnaco Inc., one of the largest brand name apparel companies, announced yesterday that its management would buy out the company's Activewear division for $85 million.

LEAD: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles said it had acquired Donald E. Whiting Inc., a telephone directory advertising agency based in Deerfield, Ill. Whiting will become a division of D.M.B.& B./Yellow Pages in Chicago. D.M.B.& B./Yellow Pages also promoted Mary MacDonald to the newly created position of chief executive and managing director.
LEAD: Nearly 15 years after New York State determined that PCB sludge in the Hudson River represented a health hazard, it has made almost no progress in cleaning up the toxic mess.

LEAD: The Bush Administration will offer legislation on Wednesday to expand the power of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to deport people convicted of crimes, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: The Washington Talk column on Friday about the emergence of Barbara Bush as a political symbol mistated the positions of two top Bush Administration officials on gun control. Vice President Quayle and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, both oppose gun control.
LEAD: William B. Mullins, a former Peace Corps official who became a foundation executive, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 52 years old.
LEAD: THERE are few meat staples more versatile and inexpensive than chicken legs. What's more, they happen to be the most flavorful part of the bird.
LEAD: The Worst Years of Our Lives Irreverent Notes From a Decade of Greed By Barbara Ehrenreich 275 pages. Pantheon Books. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The term ''pregnancy leave'' is taking on a new meaning here, as shown by a successful Hong Kong Chinese banker who is negotiating an unusual sweetener before he takes a new job. He wants his employer to pay to send his pregnant wife to Canada to give birth, insuring that their child will be born a
LEAD: The red goal light, unlike the others in Boston Garden, worked when it had to, even though it was beginning to appear as if it might never get turned on.

LEAD: Perhaps the most authentic thing about Sunday afternoon's concert by the Amsterdam Baroque Orchestra was its pervasive calmness. Conducted by Ton Koopman and offering a program largely familiar to friends of early-18th-century style, these 16 period-instrument players were able to couch both high energy and reflection in terms of quiet confidence.

LEAD: Graduation at Sarah Lawrence College promises to be a Newman family affair. JOANNE WOODWARD and CLEA NEWMAN will both receive bachelor of arts degrees. And PAUL NEWMAN, the husband and father, is delivering the commencement address.

LEAD: The National Endowment for the Arts faces a fresh challenge from elements of the arts community itself that are apparently allied with leading House Republicans. This comes just as the endowment is facing its worst buffeting ever.

LEAD: Walter Thornton, retired head of the Walter Thornton Agency in Manhattan, once one of the nation's largest modeling agencies, died of a stroke on Monday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Long Beach, Calif. He was 88 years old and lived in Jalisco, Mexico.
LEAD: Dr. Philip Clark, a psychologist and an educational administrator, died of heart failure on Monday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

LEAD: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today to six new drug-related charges, saying afterward that he felt ''fantastic'' despite his many legal and political difficulties and was confident of his defense.

LEAD: After Unbridled worked five furlongs in a nifty 1:00 2/5 seconds yesterday morning at Churchill Downs, Carl Nafzger, the colt's trainer, had some discouraging words for the other horses that will be running in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.
LEAD: We cannot pin this one on George. We have his word on that. This Winfield business was the idea of his Baseball People.

LEAD: Several obstacles remain before wireless telephone systems now in development can replace cellular and wired services. Among them is finding a place on the increasingly busy end of the radio-wave spectrum that these systems plan to exploit.

LEAD: The Phoenix Suns set aside years of franchise-deep frustration tonight, beating the Los Angeles Lakers, 106-103, at the Forum and advancing to the National Basketball Association's Western Conference final.

LEAD: NBC News yesterday moved to restore what its president called ''a sense of family'' to the ''Today'' show by adding three new personalities to the program. The additions follow months of declining ratings for the morning news program since the departure of the co-host, Jane Pauley, in December and her replacement by Deborah

LEAD: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' the most expensive show in Broadway history, is to close Sept. 1 at the Imperial Theater after a run of less than two years and after making back only a little more than half its investment, its producers announced yesterday.

LEAD: Earl Monroe, overlooked three times by the voters, savored his long-awaited induction into the Basketball's Hall of Fame yesterday in Springfield, Mass. Also enshrined were Elvin Hayes, Dave Bing and the late Neil Johnston, the Philadelphia Warriors' hook-shot specialist who won three consecutive scoring titles in the 1950's.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an obituary and a headline yesterday about Andrei P. Kirilenko, a former member of the Soviet Politburo, misstated his age. He was 83.

LEAD: The Presidential commission that investigated the bombing of Pan American Flight 103 called today for far-reaching new measures internationally and at domestic airports to counter such attacks. But it also sharply criticized a costly bomb-detection initiative already undertaken by the Bush Administration.

LEAD: There are unlikely jobs in New York City. This column is about one of them. It is about two mental-health workers who troll high-rise apartments, cheap hotels and park benches to find sick old people and get them to a doctor at the Bellevue Hospital Center.
LEAD: What if the Government gave people who lost their jobs their half-year of unemployment benefits all at once, in one check, to start a business?

LEAD: FOR food fanatics, spring's warmer weather, longer days, cherry blossoms and azaleas are much less important than tender young spinach leaves, slender stalks of rhubarb, strawberries that are red from top to bottom and asparagus at reasonable prices.

LEAD: The ITT Corporation yesterday named Dale R. Comey, an executive at its insurance unit, as an executive vice president of the corporation, and a company official said that he had been identified as ITT's next president.

LEAD: The Air Force said today that it had suspended a missile research and development unit of the Hughes Aircraft Company from receiving new contracts and might bar it for three years for its role in a scandal involving stolen budget documents.
LEAD: The Circle K Corporation, the troubled convenience-store chain, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code last night.

LEAD: Having failed to oust the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul more than a year after Moscow withdrew its troops, Afghan guerrilla groups are resisting proposals that the war be settled in internationally supervised elections.

LEAD: The five plays in Marathon 1990, the 13th annual one-act festival at the Ensemble Studio Theater, deal varyingly with retribution and revenge. This concern is amusingly exemplified by comedies from Bill Bozzone and Frank D. Gilroy. Both are skilled practitioners of the short play form. They know that a one-act should never overstay the audience's interest.

LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. introduced and began shipping a low-priced computer work station today that will compete directly with personal computers. It is in the price range of powerful personal computers and works twice as fast.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: GOLF Westchester PGA Final Set John Reeves, the assistant at Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn., who became a member of the PGA last summer, reached the final of the Westchester PGA championship yesterday with an upset triumph over Rick Vershure, the head pro at Quaker Ridge and the No.

LEAD: Yekaterina Maksimova and Vladimir Vasiliev burst upon New York City in 1959, the greatest of the passionate young dancers who, with Moscow's more established stars, made the Bolshoi Ballet's American debut a total triumph.

LEAD: New Yorkers, their racial sensitivities already heightened, were quick to see the violent clash between black youths and Vietnamese men in Brooklyn early Sunday as an alarming example of bigotry run amok. Too quick, it appears. The police, retreating from earlier accounts, conclude that the melee, though brutal, did not begin as a racially motivated assault.

LEAD: New York City schools spent more than $120 million in the last four years to prevent students from dropping out, but most of the participants did not improve their attendance or their academic work, a major new study says.
LEAD: The judge in the Howard Beach racial-attack case expressed strong doubt yesterday about a prosecution attempt to expand the charges against three defendants who face a retrial.
LEAD: WHEN Tom DeBaggio hung a handpainted sign outside his blue-frame house 16 years ago to advertise his basil, bay leaf and tomato plants, he had few takers.

LEAD: During the march from Selma to Montgomery, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. quoted an old Georgia preacher as saying, ''Them that's going, git on the wagon. Them that ain't, git out of the way.'' Those words from 1965 send a powerful message to President Bush today.
LEAD: ''THANK heavens for the Japanese!'' George Rossi exclaimed. They are making the office leasing numbers look respectable at the World Trade Center.

LEAD: Tracey Ullman said yesterday that she would not return for a fifth season of ''The Tracey Ullman Show'' in the fall. The weekly show, in which the English-born comedian performs in comedy sketches with a resident company and guest stars, was one of the first programs to bring critical acclaim to the fledgling Fox Television network, winning four Emmy

LEAD: COMPANIES A key Perkin-Elmer division will be acquired by a California equipment company. The sale of the division, which makes sophisticated machines needed to develop advanced computer chips, has been closely watched because of fears that loss of the technology would have left the U.S. dependent on Japan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Hawaii tentatively priced $100 million in airport systems revenue bonds yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.50 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

LEAD: President Bush opened budget negotiations with Congress today by refusing a request from the Democratic Congressional leadership that he make a televised address outlining the nation's economic problems and putting forward his own remedy.

LEAD: Administration officials said today that they were considering ways to revise the schedule for the White House visits of President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa and Nelson Mandela because of protests that Mr. de Klerk's visit comes first.
LEAD: A driver was critically injured in Manhattan yesterday when a 70-pound bag of tile mortar was apparently dropped from a construction site, crushing the roof of his car, the police said.
LEAD: Andre Dawson hit two two-run homers and Jeff Pico, just up from the minors, allowed one hit in six shutout innings tonight as the Chicago Cubs routed the Atlanta Braves, 12-2.
LEAD: Staten Island voters elected Alfred C. Cerullo 3d to the City Council yesterday from a field of seven candidates in a special election.

LEAD: The Bush Administration said today that it was seeking to arrange an emergency loan for Nicaragua to help the democratically elected Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro stave off bankruptcy and prevent the country's possible relapse into civil war.

LEAD: Both physically and spiritually, Terry Riley epitomizes a protected Northern California innocence that seems to have long fled the rest of the country. But last week he was much in evidence in the heart of tough, urban sophistication, New York City.
LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation announced a reorganization of its business into four major groups yesterday.

LEAD: The long crescendo of publicity about environmental problems that preceded the celebration of Earth Day last month helped a number of stocks reach lofty prices. LEAD: Roger Donaldson's ''Cadillac Man'' begins with terrific promise: a leisurely, uninterrupted helicopter tracking shot over New York City's borough of Queens. The air is heavy with smog, as it often is on a hot, still summer day. The colors of the landscape are the muted grays of the tombstones in the vast cemetery below.

LEAD: An organizer of the Goddess of Democracy radio ship indicated today that the project to beam pro-democracy messages to China would be postponed indefinitely. The organizer, Christophe Nick, said the project had not received customs approval to bring aboard the ship a radio transmitter sent from France.

LEAD: The first half of ''From Poussin to Matisse: The Russian Taste for French Painting'' - opening on Sunday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - begins with Poussin, moves through a discreet yet cheeky little Watteau, includes some forgettable period pieces by Claude Joseph Vernet and Louis Leopold Boilly, as well as a big 1809 Jacques Louis David demonstrating that even great artists can be insipid.
LEAD: Justice John Paul Stevens has joined Justice Sandra Day O'Connor as the only millionaires on the Supreme Court, financial statements show.

LEAD: The extensive retrospective of the work of Lenore Tawney at the American Craft Museum is a mixed and problematic affair, one that informs without quite convincing.

LEAD: A few cries of ''It's not fair,'' rang out in Bensonhurst last night, but the streets were no more crowded or noisy than they are on any warm evening. People milled about discussing Joseph Fama's murder conviction in somber - and decidedly bitter - tones.

LEAD: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. is offering $150 million in 9.40 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of par through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. At pricing, the yield was about 80 basis points more than the Treasury's five-year note on a when-issued basis. It was on the high end of what most dealers had expected the range to be, about 75 to 80 basis points over Treasuries.

LEAD: What a trouper Taylor Dayne is! The result is 1990's pop as lab experiment, calculated to a fare-thee-well, strenuous and almost completely uninvolving.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board sent a strong signal that it has not eased monetary policy.
