LEAD: The First Fidelity Bancorporation in Lawrenceville, N.J., the 20th-largest banking company in the country, announced a sharp rise in problem real estate loans yesterday. Analysts expect the problems to result in a large loss for the second quarter.

LEAD: S. Parker Gilbert, who led Morgan Stanley & Company through the greatest period of growth in the firm's history, said yesterday that he would retire as chairman by the end of the year.

LEAD: Ralph A. DeJur, retired president and chairman of the DeJur-Amsco Corporation, which made photographic equipment and office copiers, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old. Mr. DeJur, who was born in Manhattan, founded the company in the late 1920's with his brother, Harry.

LEAD: Even rookie pitchers in spring training have better control than the people who are tossing around President Bush's budget numbers this year. In February, they estimated that next year's Federal deficit would be $101.5 billion. In March they said it might reach $115 billion, in April $120 billion and this week, $140 billion.

LEAD: Nearly all 188 counts in a state tax-fraud and tax-evasion indictment against Leona Helmsley were dismissed yesterday by a State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan, but he retained enough of them to leave what he called a strong case against her.
LEAD: The United States trade deficit widened substantially in March, to $8.4 billion, as exports and imports both surged, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 507 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.78 billion, to $381.71 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds increased by $270.10 million, to $91.75 billion. The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds were down $640.30 million, to $131.53 billion.
LEAD: The school bus wreck that killed 21 students near this tiny crossroads last September should have cemented a tragic bond between the Alton Volunteer Fire Department and its community.

LEAD: Unidentified attackers threw a hand grenade at President Guillermo Endara's party headquarters early today, causing minor damage to buildings in the area but no injuries, witnesses said. The police said they had no immediate clues to the identity of the attackers. No group claimed responsibility.
LEAD: Philip Morris G.m.b.H., the West German subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies, has agreed to acquire the East German cigarette manufacturer VEB Kombinat Tabak. Terms were not disclosed.

LEAD: The A. C. Nielsen Company, responding to a request from the television networks, said yesterday that it would study the feasibility of combining its existing ''people meter'' system with other methods of measuring television audiences.

LEAD: TENNIS Gilbert and Krickstein Lose Two Americans, top-seeded Brad Gilbert and second-seeded Aaron Krickstein, were eliminated yesterday in Rome as Alberto Mancini of Italy and Guy Forget of France moved into the quarterfinals of the Italian Open. Mancini, seeded 16th and the defending champion, defeated Gilbert, 6-2, 6-1, on the clay surface.

LEAD: Maybe it was fitting that the sorry affair involving Dave Winfield, the Yankees and the California Angels played itself out in the month of May. It is the month that became associated with Winfield in a way that may have capsulized his nine-year relationship with George Steinbrenner.

LEAD: Yitzhak Shamir, the caretaker Prime Minister, was given three more weeks today to form a narrow coalition government with small religious and right-wing parties. He said he would announce its composition soon.

LEAD: S. Arthur Dembner, a book publisher and former executive with Newsweek, died on Monday in the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, Queens, after suffering a heart attack that day while on his way to play tennis. Mr. Dembner, who was 69 years old, lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Robert J. Stetson, the Burger King Corporation's chief financial officer since February 1989, was named the fast food company's chief operating officer today.

LEAD: So great has been the progress on human rights in the Soviet Union that it is tempting for the West to relax its vigilance and pressure. That would betray the prisoners of conscience still wasting away in remote labor camps and psychiatric wards. The context, however, has changed. Talks with Soviet officials on human rights are now routine.

LEAD: In a new effort to break the deadlock over a major civil rights measure, a bipartisan group of senators today announced a compromise that they said would remove the major roadblock to gaining White House support for the legislation.
LEAD: The middle dropped out of the Preakness Stakes today when Champagneforashley and Pleasant Tap suffered leg injuries that will keep them both out of the race Saturday.

LEAD: What do you have when you have 50 lawyers together on a couch? It sounds like yet another lawyer joke. In fact, what you have is a partnership retreat of Morrison, Cohen, Singer & Weinstein in New York, and there is nothing funny about it.

LEAD: The four Frank Sinatra concerts at Radio City Music Hall that were postponed because of Sammy Davis Jr.'s death have been rescheduled. Tickets from May 16 will be honored on June 17, tickets from May 17 will be honored June 14, tickets from May 18 will be honored June 15, and those from May 19 will be honored June 16.

LEAD: With virtually all of their differences over this year's spending resolved, lawmakers today continued to wrangle over the state budget because of Republican demands for a spending cap that would not take effect until next year.

LEAD: The head of the House panel that oversees the National Endowment for the Arts announced today the formation of an advisory group, made up of representatives from major arts organizations, to help resolve the endowment's mandate, structure and future.

LEAD: The actress Paulette Goddard has left more than $20 million to New York University to establish scholarships, endowed professorships and a development fund for junior faculty members, the school's president announced yesterday.
LEAD: An independent police report published today says that British security forces passed information about Irish terrorism suspects to outlawed Protestant paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland.

LEAD: Todd Lichti, a rookie guard for the Denver Nuggets last season, underwent surgery for a broken bone in his right foot yesterday after he was injured in a one-car accident outside Lovelock, Nev., that killed the driver, team officials said. Lichti, a first-round pick out of Stanford, was headed for his parents' home in Concord, Calif.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Republican candidates for governor in Connecticut misstated former Senator Lowell P. Weicker's party affiliation. Mr. Weicker is running for governor as an independent candidate, but says he is still a member of the Republican Party.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera House became a dance hall on Tuesday night. A glittering suspended globe - a decoration found in many ballrooms - hung above the stage, casting sparkles of light throughout the auditorium. Beneath it were romantic young couples who looked ready to dance all night.
LEAD: President Joaquin Balaguer and his longtime rival, Juan Bosch, remained locked in a close race today, a day after national elections, as some politicians said the vote count was extremely slow.
LEAD: A search committee has recommended that the next City University chancellor be chosen from three finalists, two Californians and a CUNY administrator, university officials said yesterday.
LEAD: The failure of a large central office telephone switch in Stamford, Conn., cut off all but emergency service to a quarter of Stamford's telephone lines for nearly 20 hours yesterday.
LEAD: President Bush said he and Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed that once Germany is reunified, it should remain in NATO and the rights of the Allies should be ended. Page A6.
LEAD: A secular age of faith appears to have collapsed in China, turning into a time of despair and doubt in which many people have no heroes and nothing to believe in.
LEAD: In selecting a governor, New York voters never had to choose between Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, and Thomas E. Dewey, a Republican. But the Thruway Authority did, and Mr. Cuomo has won.
LEAD: Herman Cohen, the president of Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore from 1952 to 1986, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Baltimore. He was 95 years old.

LEAD: A memorial service for the puppeteer Jim Henson, who created Kermit the Frog and many other Muppet creatures, is to be held at noon on Monday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. Written instructions left by Mr. Henson, who died of a bacterial infection at 53 years of age on Wednesday, requested that no one attending wear black.
LEAD: * Andersen Consulting, Chicago, a unit of Arthur Andersen Worldwide Organization, named William E. Storts managing partner for banking practice for the Americas.
LEAD: Bruce W. Nichols, a senior partner in the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, died of prostate cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: It takes a lot to stop Barbara Walters in her tracks. LEAD: Shift on Cigarette Exports The Government's leading health agency, which for months has been campaigning against smoking, backed away from its past criticism of efforts to open new world markets for American cigarettes. LEAD: This is a springtime of renewed hope in the nation's Grain Belt.

LEAD: The National Endowment for the Arts comes before Congress for reauthorization this year in the midst of a political firestorm generated by a few works - especially some nude photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. LEAD: James M. Wallace, retired executive vice president of N. W. Ayer Inc., the advertising agency, died in his sleep Tuesday at his home in Pennswood Village, Newton, Pa. He was 86 years old.

Fifth Avenue will be closed Sunday from 44th Street to 86th Street from noon to 4 P.M.

LEAD: In a move that could lead to the restoration of one of Wall Street's most famous names, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is examining a plan to reorganize its four operational units into two divisions, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

LEAD: Dr. Lawrence Brown Jr., an internist who specializes in treating drug and alcohol abuse, was named by Commissioner Paul Tagliabue yesterday as the National Football League's drug abuse adviser.

LEAD: Think of it. There have been seven games and seven victories, nearly all of them dominant. The pitcher who has won them all is employed by his hometown team, is financially secure, has found instant popularity in the city where he plays and dresses daily next to his former college teammate.

LEAD: A Las Vegas chemist, David Roberts, was promoting Stopp, a lotion that he said relieved soreness caused by everything from bumps and bruises to lower back pain and arthritis. He first patented the compound as a hair thickener in 1972 and later discovered that it relieved pain as well.

LEAD: If anybody decides to remake ''The Caine Mutiny Court Martial,'' the new Captain Queeg might play with the Polygonzo tube instead of those metal balls.
LEAD: The Federal Government said today that it would take control of the Southwest Savings Association, a large, troubled Texas institution that regulators had created two years ago.

LEAD: The Rev. Donald Larsen, director of the Lutheran Immigration and Refugee Service in Manhattan, died of liver and kidney failure on Thursday at the Hackensack (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in River Edge, N.J.

LEAD: A study by a nonpartisan research group has concluded that the spending limits that Democrats have proposed for Senate campaigns are too low and would therefore maintain advantages that incumbents already enjoy, stifling competition in election races.

LEAD: Many business and professional people pursue their work so single-mindedly that they have no time to deal with personal finances. Soon they have the financial equivalent of a neglected garden in fertile soil; weeds - or debts - threaten to take over. Two-income couples are particularly vulnerable.

LEAD: Couples who work are being confronted with a new puzzle: how to coordinate the different flexible benefit plans offered by their employers. The goal is to get the right benefits for the family at the lowest total cost without duplicating coverage.

LEAD: A 19-year-old white man was acquitted yesterday of killing a 16-year-old black youth who crossed one of the invisible barriers that separate white from black New York when he went to the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn last Aug. 23.
LEAD: If you've always wanted to be a Scottish baron, today was the day to be at Glazier's Hall, London, with a pocketful of money.

LEAD: A new Federal grand jury today began a criminal inquiry into the Iran-contra affair that is expected to center on the activities of mid-level Reagan Administration officials, Government officials said.

LEAD: I am a first-generation American offspring of Holocaust survivors, and I don't want to see a Holocaust museum on the Mall in Washington (''Holocaust Museum: A Troubled Start,'' by Judith Miller, April 22).

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 2 2 5 SEPTEMBER, by Rosamunde Pilcher.

LEAD: Summer Squall avenged his Kentucky Derby loss to Unbridled by scoring a 2 1/4-length victory in the Preakness Stakes today at Pimlico, but there will be no rubber match between the colts in the final leg of the Triple Crown.

LEAD: THE senior Pakistani official looked warily about the room at a diplomatic gathering here last week. ''In a practical sense, it's all over,'' he said, referring to the issue he has been wrestling with as a member of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's inner circle.

LEAD: For fun, she visits formal Italian gardens and scuba dives to view underwater floras. For work, she creates gardens and topiaries. Deborah Reich attributes her interest in gardens in large part to childhood visits to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
LEAD: To the Editor: We frequently find ourselves in Britain on business and will extend our stay for pleasure. We enjoy bed and breakfast lodgings outside London.

LEAD: FOURTEENTH STREET is in for a rough ride beginning next month, when a long-anticipated reconstruction of roadway, sidewalks, curbs, water mains and sewer lines is to start. The result is promising, but not all of the businesses that now line the street may live to see the day.

LEAD: PROCRASTINATION is so common a trait that it seems a natural human tendency - a minor personality flaw and sometimes humorous. We are entertained by news coverage of dual national events highlighting the ultimate in mass procrastination; each spring hordes of taxpayers wait in lines at the post office to file last-minute returns.
LEAD: Beyond disputes over dollars and weapons, the battle of the military budget reflects a debate over the shape of the American military in a transformed world.

LEAD: Item: The Jefferson Group, a Washington, D.C.-based government affairs firm, is hiring for a new office that will focus on environmental and workplace safety. Why? ''Many companies will need help n understanding and meeting the new requirements,'' said Mark D. Cowan, Jefferson's chief executive.

LEAD: These are dark days for the boys of Bensonhurst. Their world is fading as fast as the summer sun over the city some of their fathers and grandfathers helped build. They are angry the way people are angry when they see a sure thing slipping through their fingers.

LEAD: If John Cullerton and a majority of his colleagues have their way, it won't be long before college athletes in Illinois begin drawing salaries and enjoying due-process civil rights protection in investigations by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Under the pressure of subpoenas, the United States Government is likely to disclose for the first time the amount of money it paid Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama in the years he worked for American intelligence agencies, two Justice Department officials involved in the case say.

LEAD: The arms control breakthroughs announced by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Moscow today put the two superpowers back on track toward concluding major agreements cutting long-range nuclear arms and slashing stockpiles of chemical weapons.

LEAD: By formal agreement concluded Friday, the two Germanys will become one on July 1, barely eight months after the wall's fall. To most people, what was unthinkable then seems unremarkable now. Polls indicate that Americans are less concerned about German unification than are the Germans themselves.

LEAD: TWO decades ago Communist reformers in Eastern Europe wanted to build a new type of economic system, one that would be a bold mix of Marxism and the free market. Eager to shun Stalinist repression and stagnation as well as to avoid capitalist evils like unemployment, these idealists dreamed of constructing ''socialism with a human face.

LEAD: In art as in stocks, the action is in the quality end of the spectrum, but the rest of the market seems to be alive as well.

LEAD: It seems ironic that Dean Robert C. Clark, who ''deplored contemporary students' ignorance 'of how one goes about proving something,' '' should use obfuscating language himself in trying to justify corporate law as a career choice. ''Corporate law,'' he says, ''is intensely moral, you know.'' The challenge of it, he says, is ''to devise optimal controls on managerial discretion.

LEAD: A grand dame in retirement, the Queen Mary has given up the trans-Atlantic run for a permanent berth as a hotel-cum-tourist attraction in Long Beach, Calif. But she's still got glamour. Consider the Observation Lounge, once the First Class cocktail bar, with its burnished paneling and festive mural and glittering chrome.

LEAD: IN 1834, when Francis Gillette built his country house at what is now 511 Bloomfield Avenue in Hartford, people came by carriage from miles around to admire it. The multicolored stone building in Greek Revival style was a rarity in those days of predominantly wooden construction.
LEAD: THE spring concert season is just about over. But a few worthy programs remain on the agenda.

LEAD: BECAUSE of the collapse of the energy industry, the 10-year commercial building boom that shaped this city's skyline has, since the mid-80's, come to a virtual standstill - except on the 600-acre campus of the Texas Medical Center next to Rice University.

LEAD: LAND sales in Maine's North Woods have remained strong in recent months despite a general slowdown in the state's real estate market, according to brokers trying to sell and conservationists trying to protect the land.

LEAD: Ari Socolow has completed the 34 courses needed to graduate from Tufts University, and he completed them in six semesters, not the usual eight, making the dean's list last fall and this spring.
LEAD: An important focus of do-it-yourself stamp collecting is the maximum card, which straddles the intersection of philately and deltiology - the study of postcards.

LEAD: Seymour Hersh told me he was writing a ''revisionist'' history of the Iran-contra investigation. His article ''The Iran-Contra Committees - Did They Protect Reagan?'' (April 29) is more revision than history.

LEAD: MIGRANT SOULS. By Arturo Islas. (Morrow, $16.95.) In this second novel by Arturo Islas, we meet three generations of a Chicano family as they sink roots in the fictitious Texas border town of Del Sapo. The Angel family - which also figured in Mr. Islas' first novel, ''The Rain God'' - wrestles with problems of identity and values: Are they Mexicans or are they Americans of Mexican heritage?

LEAD: Elizabeth Glaeser, the manager of capital markets for Mobil in New York, and Dr. Edmund Chaitman, a psychoanalyst in Englewood, N.J., were married yesterday at the Georgian Suite in Manhattan. The Rev. Bruce Bayne, an Episcopal minister, and Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Susan M. Safenowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Safenowitz of Old Westbury, L.I., was married last evening to Alan D. Levine, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Levine of Searingtown, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.
LEAD: Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., the State Assembly minority leader, announced today that he would not seek the Republican nomination for governor.
LEAD: Newport has flirted with sailors and the sea since it was settled in 1639, and its history charts the rise and fall of life under sail from Colonial days through the era of the America's Cup.

LEAD: A SWIMMING pool can be a community association's most appealing amenity, but it also can be a major source of trouble if rules are not drafted for safe use and in accordance with state and Federal requirements.

It also rose those two days against other major currencies, except for the British pound. It is not clear if the rally is just a correction after the sharp drop of the week before or rather the start of a new trend.

LEAD: To the Editor: To change from a 750 milliliter bottle to a one liter bottle, as you tried to do in the chart accompanying the article on duty-free shops, you must add one-third of the former, not the 25 percent or one-fourth that you reported. Properly scaling the price to one liter gives $38.40. To reach the $36 for a bottle of liqueur in midtown Manhattan by adding the 25 percent listed in the footnote to the table, the 750 milliliter would have cost $28.80.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: David Parsons is an intriguing performer with a stage presence that shifts tantalizingly between the diabolical and the angelic. Like Paul Taylor, whose company he danced with, Mr. Parsons has a big but lithe build and an extraordinary kind of grace. He has an almost indolent authority in motion, so that what he does on stage seems less a matter of dancing than the expression of a privileged relationship with the floor and air.

LEAD: Madonna throws both fans and skeptics a curve ball with ''I'm Breathless: Music From and Inspired by the Film 'Dick Tracy' '' (Sire/Warner Brothers 26209; all three formats). Taking a tangent from a career in which she has reshaped a decade's dance music and pop, Madonna has made an album in which 9 out of 12 songs are anachronistic, doo-wacka-doo numbers, mock period pieces intended to echo the quasi-1930's flavor of the forthcoming movie ''Dick Tracy.

LEAD: The men wore safety pins, instead of studs, on their formal shirts, as Thomas N. Armstrong 3d always does. The women wore bow ties because Mr. Armstrong has never been one for a four-in-hand. Another nod to the guest of honor was the windup toys at dinner, especially the dancing tomatoes.

LEAD: No doubt Marilyn Forman is a well-meaning friend of animals, but her letter to the editor (April 15), the ''missing facts'' she purports to supply to my story about Ducky, the one-winged swan, are not all facts, but rather an attempt to justify her own actions.

LEAD: When you announce to your loved ones that you are hopping a freighter to South America and will be gone for two months and they bid you fond farewell on the eve of your departure, why are you seen skulking around town a week later? Because just as time and tide wait for no man, freighters don't depart for a ready woman.

LEAD: AFTER communicating by satellite for 18 months, two high school students - one on Long Island and the other in Moscow - are about to realize their dream of establishing a center for biotechnology education in Moscow.

LEAD: The Southampton Town supervisor has proposed spending $15 million to buy hundreds of undeveloped acres for water conservation, recreation and protection of endangered species.
LEAD: Now that Barbara Bush is bringing Raisa Gorbachev along to share the podium at the Wellesley College graduation, more students say they have someone with whom they can identify.

LEAD: The Yankees definitely need Dave Winfield. He has had an extremely consistent career in the field and with the bat. His value has somewhat declined because of his injury, but consistency is something the Yankees need especially since their front office contributes to the team's unsettledness. Winfield had the ability to help the Yankees in turbulent times if he had been given the chance to play out of his current slump.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FOR ALL OUR EXPLORING, SPACE IS STILL A MYSTERY; one tiny, pockmarked moon, after all, is as far as we've set foot. Perhaps that is why we demand more than just dry data from those assigned to study the planets and peer beyond the Milky Way. A space scientist has to be a visionary, a poet in a white lab coat who can give voice to our collective craving for adventure, our fascination with a universe we have not been able to touch.

LEAD: Dancing came of age on Broadway in ''A Chorus Line,'' in 1975. It wasn't just the choreography, fluid and expressive though the dances of Michael Bennett and Bob Avian were. LEAD: Five months after toppling their Communist dictator, the people of Romania will take another step on Sunday on the bumpy road toward democracy when they hold the nation's first free elections in more than a half-century.

LEAD: CLOVER. By Dori Sanders. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $13.95.) In Dori Sanders' striking first novel, Clover, a 10-year-old black girl from a small town in South Carolina, chronicles her bewildering but gradually deepening relationship with her white stepmother following her father's tragic death only hours after the marriage.

LEAD: Christine MacRae Mummert and Michael Anthony Lewis were married yesterday at the home of the bride's grandmother Mrs. Reuben T. Carlson in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Mary Speers, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

LEAD: Greeks on the whole do not drink to drink but to see and be seen, and Kolonaki Square in downtown Athens is where it happens: any one of an array of sidewalk bars and cafes provides a suitably public setting for the macho strut and eye contact over the ouzo.

LEAD: The trauma of Watergate seems to have left Congress determined to avoid the impeachment process again, at all costs. Our nation is indeed morally bankrupt when President Reagan, John Poindexter and Oliver North can virtually walk away from such irresponsible and dangerous activities - offenses far more serious than those committed by Richard M.

LEAD: As their uprising against Israeli occupation unfolds through a 30th month, Palestinians confront a range of divisive and unresolved questions that turn on a central issue: what new tactics can re-invigorate the revolt and counter Israeli assertions that its flame has dimmed?

LEAD: In the campaign for the Democratic nomination for governor of the most populous state, Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp of California is a politician of paradoxes.

LEAD: Nearly every day, Gail Bishop travels through small towns in northern Colorado like a circuit rider, visiting families that have suffered a death in the last year. She works for a funeral home that not only buries the dead but also helps survivors deal with their grief.

LEAD: Bolstered by mounting demands from industry and a national shortage of technical students, career opportunities for science and engineering graduates are making a strong comeback after recently experiencing a slump.

LEAD: While other students are completing problem sets and studying for exams, some college students here are putting their fears aside, donning red berets and, as Guardian Angels, patrolling this city in an effort to combat crime.

LEAD: On Friday at 9 P.M., PBS will broadcast ''The Stations of Bach,'' a 90-minute biography structured around a tour of the places Bach (at right) lived in or visited throughout Germany. The cameras visit Bach's birthplace in Eisenach and various later stops, including Weimar, Dresden, Celle and Hamburg, offering views of sumptuous churches, palaces and countryside.

LEAD: At the local headquarters of the ruling National Salvation Front, about 30 party workers watched intently today as a videotape of their campaign rally on Thursday was played and replayed. They were gathering evidence. The rally ended in violence when counterdemonstrators stormed the speaker's platform.

LEAD: Serious Fun, the performance arts series that has brought experimental music, dance and theater to Lincoln Center for the last three years, will return to Alice Tully Hall July 13 for its fourth season. The 16 performances will run through Aug. 2.

LEAD: They may be barely old enough to date, but Monica Seles and Jennifer Capriati, the hard-hitting teen-age phenomenons programmed to topple Steffi Graf from her perch, have already left a string of broken hearts behind them.

LEAD: Reuben Mark, the Colgate-Palmolive Company's chief executive, has just made part of each executive's bonus contingent on hiring or promoting at least one additional woman or minority member. ''Putting money on the line puts teeth into management's value statements,'' he said.

LEAD: ''We had no model; we were unrehearsed and unprepared for what followed, not only here, but at Columbia, Berkeley and other places,'' said Ralph Hanson, the director of the University of Wisconsin police and security.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Special-interest newspapers abound at the University of California at Los Angeles: Nommo, for black students; La Gente, for Hispanic students; Ha'Am, for Jewish students; Together, for feminists; Pacties, for Asians and Pacific Islanders, and TenPercent, for homosexuals.

LEAD: The Yankees needed Dave Winfield, but it's too late now. I hope by this time, he's back to stardom and helping the Angels strive for the pennant. Steinbrenner could never stand Winfield. The athlete earned every penny of his salary by his playing accomplishments, but the owner never forgave him for outdoing him on the business transaction of his 10-year contract.

LEAD: LEGISLATION approved last month by the New Jersey Senate that would allow competent adults to specify in advance their wishes about the use of extraordinary means to sustain their lives promotes ''passive euthanasia'' and ''assisted suicide,'' critics of the measure say.

LEAD: People fall in love with music for different reasons and at different speeds. Most gifted musicians find themselves ensnared willy-nilly, for better or worse, virtually from birth. For some modestly talented listeners, the experience of being thrilled by a particular sequence of pitches and rhythms comes with telegraphic suddenness, often in adolescence.

LEAD: One day I was playing a round of golf with my friend Miles Jaffee, an excellent sailor, skier and tennis player who never bothered to master the art of batting balls through pastures. After one particularly bad shot, Miles picked up the ball and threw it toward the hole. His eyes lit up; the thrill of invention was about to replace the agony of defeat.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Bayport $320,000 215 Suydam Lane 5-bedroom, 6-bath, 25- year-old ranch; fireplace, patio, 1.3 acres, 2-car garage; taxes $6,900. Bay Shore $520,000 65 South Awixa Avenue 6-bedroom, 5-bath, 119-year-old Victorian colonial; dining room, sun porch, 2 fireplaces, 3-car garage, 1.5 acres, 166 feet of bulkheading; taxes $9,700.

LEAD: Eda Atkinson Martin, a daughter of Dr. William W. Martin Jr. of Richmond and Eda W. Martin of Williamsburg, Va., was married yesterday to Charles Hoyt Sherman Joyce, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Joyce Jr. of Washington. The Rev. Frank F. Fagan, an Episcopal priest, and Msgr. J. Joshua Mundell, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St.

LEAD: Lisa Cecile Michaelis was married yesterday to William Coxe Schlosser at the Mark Hotel in New York by the Rev. Lisa Ward, a Unitarian minister. The bride is the daughter of Marianne Zelnicker of Mobile, Ala., and Arnold Michaelis of New York. Mr. Schlosser is a son of Leonard B. Schlosser and Mary Coxe Schlosser, both of New

LEAD: THROUGH the misty morning we had rambled along the edge of the Ennerdale Water. On a clear day we should have seen a succession of nubby peaks - Bowness Knott, Starling Dodd, High Stile - but the clouds lay about them like an old feather bed. We ate our lunch leaning against a stone fence at the end of the water, just where the woods began.

LEAD: As a young girl in Detroit, Carolyn A. Kley often listened to her grandmother's tales of what life was like in Poland before she immigrated to America. This summer, Caroline, now a student at the University of Michigan School of Business Administration, is going to Poland to help its Government manage the difficult transition from a planned to a capitalist economy.

LEAD: THE day began with worthy intentions. Wanting to get away for a few hours, my wife suggested, ''Let's head over to Stroudsburg and look around.'' On this dreary day, gray and chilly enough to inhibit outside activity, yet not really nippy enough to make cold-weather options attractive, the prospect of spending our weekday off uncovering a neat little museum or bistro across the Delaware held some appeal.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read Paul Hoffmann's ''Seven City Hostelries'' (Travel, March 18) with nostalgia. Born and raised in Budapest, I left Hungary in 1940. My husband and I returned many times and stayed in all of the hotels mentioned except the Atrium Hyatt.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Disclosure on Noriega

LEAD: Three stone buildings within a mile of one another house one of the largest and most comprehensive collections of tools and machinery from the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries - a tribute to America's industrial revolution.

LEAD: MY husband has had his wallet stolen or rifled four times on three continents, making him a world expert of a sort. None of the incidents occurred in his home territory, New York City, which, considering that he spends most of his time there and the publicity New York gets on such topics, one might suppose they would.

LEAD: The Little Mermaid 1989. Disney. $26.99. Laser disk, $29.99. 1 hour, 23 minutes. Closed captioned. G. The Hans Christian Andersen story of the mermaid who failed in her bid to become human is a marvel of skillful animation. Teen-agers will appreciate the story's rebellious heroine; adults will be charmed by the pretty look and robust score, and small children will be enchanted by the sunniness and perfect simplicity.

LEAD: In the crowded months of July and August, sailing yachts at Porto Ercole's small public quay (no dock fee, but little fresh water) are tied up eight-in-line, rather the way souvenir Indian elephants are linked, an arrangement that encourages new friendships and a lazy reluctance to put out to sea.
LEAD: THE WORST YEARS OF OUR LIVES Irreverent Notes From a Decade of Greed. By Barbara Ehrenreich. 275 pp. New York: Pantheon. $19.95.

LEAD: AS surely as God made Alar-free apples, newcomers to Fairfield County are asked, ''Have you been to Stew Leonard's yet?'' The reference is to the enormous gray barn of a food market covering 125,000 square feet on Route 1 in Norwalk.

LEAD: Veracruz is where it all began: the first settlement on the North American mainland, founded in 1519 by the conquistador Hernando Cortes. Ever since, this languid and funky tropical port on the Gulf of Mexico has regarded itself as a guardian of tradition, one of the proudest of which is a leisurely hour or two spent sipping cool drinks at El Gran Cafe de la
LEAD: Ann Pasquale and Dr. Joseph Haddad Jr. were married yesterday at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The Revs. Emilio Salerno and Stephen Almagno officiated.

LEAD: BECAUSE people who have undergone chemotherapy for cancer often feel isolated, one of the best ways friends or family members can show support is to encourage them to get back into the mainstream of life. Despite the seriousness of their disease, people with cancer long to resume various interests and activities.

LEAD: When William Gates, co-founder and chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, recruits young programmers he looks for the sharpest college graduates who excel in mathematics or physics. For example, scoring in the nation's top 100 in the prestigious Putnam exam, a puzzle-solving mathematics test for college students, will guarantee a career with the Redmond,
LEAD: ''Scotch and water,'' said Claude Beland, uttering the words with a shudder usually reserved for cod liver oil. ''Here, we drink wine.''

LEAD: TWO years ago, when Francelia Butler thought of teaching conflict resolution through a Peace Games Festival, a lot of people were skeptical. But on Wednesday, more than 1,000 students in grades 5 to 12 will attend such a festival, at the University of Connecticut's new sports arena, Gampel Pavilion, on the Storrs campus.

LEAD: The one-act play is a faithful suitor, if short on conversation. It is making its annual visit to the Ensemble Studio Theater for the group's 13th one-act marathon. Running through June 17, at 549 West 52d Street in Manhattan, the program consists of three evenings of four plays each: Series A (through today), B (Wednesday through June 3) and C (June 6 through 17).

LEAD: THE COAST OF CHICAGO. By Stuart Dybek. (Knopf, $17.95.) Stuart Dybek could flip a coin and win a bet that it would land on its edge. In his second collection of stories, he gambles (usually successfully) that the paradoxical borders and margins of life are the most interesting places to locate his fiction.

LEAD: It may still be spring, but the official color of summer is already in midseason. That would be white, which on the milder days of the past few weeks burst forth in a profusion of outfits, most of them anchored by cotton, linen or tweed jackets.

LEAD: As a recent graduate of Harvard Law School and a clerk on the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, I was intrigued by Ken Emerson's article ''When Legal Titans Clash'' (April 22).

LEAD: Robyn A. Loring, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Loring of St. George, S.I., was married last evening to Dr. Leon K. Specthrie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jared Specthrie of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider officiated at the Grand Summit Hotel in Summit, N.J.

LEAD: Militants set fire to a dozen shops and shot 2 people to death today, bringing to 21 the number of people killed in the last week in clashes between rival ethnic parties, the police said. They said members of the Mohajir Quami Movement, a militant Indian immigrant party, and Sindhi nationalists demanding independence or greater autonomy were responsible for the violence.
LEAD: As fear widens that a disease that causes fatal brain disorders in British cows might spread to humans, Members of Parliament have announced a wide-ranging investigation into the ailment.

LEAD: Not long after he became president of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries last year, Kentaro Aikawa took a tour of the company's sprawling aerospace works here. Mr. Aikawa spent most of his career as a shipbuilder and turbine engineer for the company in Nagasaki, so he was something of a stranger to the rows of F-15 fighters, Boeing 767 fuselages and Japanese rockets under construction.
LEAD: THE artistic director of an emerging small professional theater company in northern Westchester is out to prove that audiences want offbeat, visceral theater.
LEAD: BASEBALL IN APRIL And Other Stories. By Gary Soto. 111 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

LEAD: The United States national soccer team, bound for the 1990 World Cup finals next month in Italy, ends a domestic schedule of games today when it plays one of Yugoslavia's best club teams, Partisan Belgrade, at the Yale Bowl in New Haven.

LEAD: A man who has become the main focus of a Federal investigation into a series of bombings in the Southeast last year was put in a lineup this week in a move that some investigators called an indication of important developments.

LEAD: Albert A. Grobe, who retired in 1973 as chief announcer of WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, after more than three decades with the station, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in White Plains.

LEAD: At the graduation ceremonies last week at New York University, it was the school that received the biggest present: $20 million from the estate of Paulette Goddard. Students cheered at President John Brademas's announcement of the bequest, the largest ever for N.Y.U. Ms. Goddard, who died April 23 at the age of 78, left everything to the university.

LEAD: IN the pantheon of things black and white and red all over, the Balinese textile called gringsing must certainly be the most obscure. The double-ikat technique used to make it - that of tying and dyeing the threads of both length and width, warp and weft, before weaving - is done nowhere else in Indonesia.
LEAD: ONE of these days, Connecticut will have an arts organization clearinghouse coordinate dates and avoid cultural logjams.
LEAD: MICHAEL STERN was thrilled, if a little surprised, to meet a real composer.
LEAD: GALIMOTO By Karen Lynn Williams. Illustrated by Catherine Stock. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

LEAD: One person's idea of drudgery is another's inspiration. Considert his: Many people think that kitchen chores - like cooking and cleaning up - are menial, even demeaning duties, and that aprons are what you wwear to do them in. But then there are those for whom cooking cloths and clothes kindle deliciously romantic visions of picnics on the grass, barbecues int he backyard or creative repasts stirred up in a kitchen fit for a gourmet.

LEAD: With a new $9.1 million contract to salve bitterness and doubt, Dave Winfield is a California Angel now. For almost a week, starting when he was yanked away from practice and told he was being traded, Winfield refused to leave. Even George Steinbrenner, who had fought with Winfield for most of the outfielder's nine years as a Yankee, seemed embarrassed; he said the trade was not his idea and ''was not handled with dignity.

LEAD: Dorinda Scharff, a daughter of Eleanor M. Scharff of Philadelphia and the late Robert K. Scharff, was married yesterday to Roland J. Hawkins, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Otho Hawkins. Gregory R. Manning, a former judge of Riverhead (L.I.) Justice Court, officiated in the bridegroom's home in Remsenburg, L.I.

LEAD: Beyond the want for a drink, solitude can be tricky to achieve in a Dublin pub, for even the urban Irish strive to live up to the national weakness for tending to the quiet stranger's soul. If you want to join the flow, and sample a weave of rich conversation that literally goes back to such tough customers as Parnell and Michael Collins, the Bailey on Duke Street never seems to fail, except when the singing breaks out.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Dimenstein of Milford, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for Mrs. Dimenstein's daughter Michelle Ilene Gitlitz and Jonathan Daniel Lupkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley N. Lupkin of Bayside, Queens.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The politics of AIDS has fundamentally shifted in Congress, turning lawmakers who once cringed at voting for money to combat the epidemic or assist its victims into vocal supporters of more Federal aid.

LEAD: After signing a 10-year contract with the Yankees in 1981, Dave Winfield had a few productive and successful seasons. He challenged the leaders in many statistical categories and was a fixture in the mediocre Yankee teams of the 1980's.

LEAD: MARLENE POPP, a small gray-haired woman in a pink raincoat, stepped gingerly from the tour bus and gazed at the tall birches that lead to an arched stone gate. ''Isn't this beautiful!'' she said. Then, hurrying to catch up with her friends, she entered Lourdes in Litchfield, singing ''Ave Maria'' as she went.

LEAD: The staid Securities and Exchange Commission and the upstart Commodity Futures Trading Commission have gone to war. The issue is important, and heated: which agency should regulate the market in stock index futures.

LEAD: GLASGOW, the 1990 European City of Culture, after such choices as Athens, Florence, Amsterdam, West Berlin and Paris? People who think of Glasgow as it was in the 1960's, a place of sooty slums and idle shipyards along the River Clyde, will shake their heads in disbelief.
LEAD: The Lithuanian Parliament began today to debate how far the republic was willing to retreat from its declaration of independence in an attempt to coax the Kremlin to discuss the issue.
LEAD: Lithuania, China, Israel.
LEAD: As the president of George Washington University in Washington, Stephen Trachtenberg has heard all the talk about corruption in college athletics and what to do about it.

LEAD: I was dismayed by the false impression Ken Emerson gave that I am among a supposed group of professors who ''politely but pointedly distance themselves from [Alan] Dershowitz.'' Not only is Alan a friend of mine, but I have enormous respect for the important work he does.

LEAD: Judging by the current spate of exhibitions devoted to the images of little known or long forgotten photographers, one might think that the world was running out of photographs. But since photography is by nature a prolific medium, and practically anyone can take a picture, some less obvious possibility than a paucity of pictures must be at play.
LEAD: NOTHING hates a vacuum as much as politics, and the Congressional vacancies created by last year's gubernatorial election are attracting much of the attention in this year's elections.
LEAD: WORLD CUP SOCCER

LEAD: FOUR years ago, John Kinsman stood outside his barn in Lime Ridge, Wis., and vowed to halt a new advance in farm technology, a genetically engineered drug to increase milk production in cows, that he believed would sweep small dairy farmers like himself from the land.

LEAD: Closings in the week ended May 5 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $260,000 1 Fifth Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, remodeled kitchen and bath, steamroom, landmark district, partial Washington Park view; maintenance $725, 39% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn Weigner Real Estate)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For those Americans of a certain generation, and for anyone who's decided that travel, let alone life, isn't quite as exotic as it used to be, Saigon (now Ho Chi Minh City) can still exert a powerful tug.

LEAD: The 42 member nations of the new Bank for European Reconstruction and Development, established to provide financial aid to Eastern Europe, tonight elected a French official as its president and selected London as its headquarters.

LEAD: The sap flows, the soil parts, and the green shafts burst into life. Ta-dah! Earth's very own spring style statement, mostly in conservative greens (followed by a blooming orgy of color), has inspired fashion makers in every category this season, from Ungaro to the Gap.

LEAD: ONE can never be sure how people will react to Syracuse, a city that appears hesitant, uncertain of its magnitude and its identity, belonging neither with the big Sicilian ports of Palermo, Catania and Messina nor with the smaller and sleepier provincial capitals like Agrigento and Enna. Some visitors to Syracuse are fascinated by the evocative atmosphere of faded glory in what was once the greatest and perhaps most beautiful of the Greek cities in the western Mediterranean.
LEAD: OUR GRANDMOTHERS' DRUMS By Mark Hudson. 321 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $18.95.

LEAD: On Thursday the New Jersey Legislature passed the nation's toughest law on assault weapons.
