LEAD: Clyde Drexler sank five free throws in the final 26 seconds of overtime today and the Portland Trail Blazers took advantage of a crucial breakaway foul call to beat San Antonio, 108-105, in the deciding seventh game of the Western Conference semifinals.

LEAD: Mike Witt pitched an impressive six innings in his first start for the Yankees yesterday, but Dave Righetti diluted the effort by failing to retire any of the five batters he faced in the ninth inning. The turnaround, in which the Yankees squandered a 4-1 lead, would have made it understandable for Manager Bucky Dent to erupt if a close game-ending call had gone against the

LEAD: He has won more games than any other American college hockey coach and now Len Ceglarski, who has a record of 632-309-35 in his 32 years at Clarkson College and Boston College, is getting some recognition. He will receive the 1990 Lester Patrick Award for service to United States hockey. . . . Joe Theismann, the former Notre Dame and Washington Redskins quarterback, has been inducted into the GTE Academic All-America Hall of Fame along with Jamaal Wilkes, the former U.C.L.A.

LEAD: A charter bus carrying European tourists lost its brakes on a winding mountain highway on Friday, slammed into an embankment and rolled over, killing one person and injuring 44 others, the authorities said. The the dead woman was identified as Marguerite Finat, 60 years old, of France. The bus, operated by Southwest Charter Co., had left Las Vegas for Mammoth Lakes.

LEAD: IN just a few words - ''Here are the keys'' - the investment banking firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert let its landlord know that it would no longer be needing 108,000 square feet of space in the Fulton Landing development on the Brooklyn waterfront.

LEAD: In the spring of 1970, students at Michigan State University built Tent City on an empty area on campus they called People's Park. Students who camped there protested everything from United States involvement in Cambodia to chain fences around grassy areas.
LEAD: THE TOWN THAT STARTED THE CIVIL WAR By Nat Brandt. Illustrated. 315 pp. Syracuse: Syracuse University Press. $29.95.

LEAD: The London stock market has been buffeted in recent months by fears of recession, high interest rates, inflation, poll tax riots and the political troubles of the Thatcher Government. After hitting a record high of 2,463.7 on Jan. 3, the FTSE 100 fell 14.6 percent to a low of 2,103.4 at the end of

LEAD: More graffiti deface walls along the West Side Drive and elsewhere. More trash fouls public space. But city officials cry poor. Cleaning up is labor-intensive, they say; New York can't afford more scrubbers, sweepers, collectors and baggers right now. They're right about the lack of money, wrong about the lack of remedies.

LEAD: An article on April 8 about an entrepreneur's success in starting a magazine for parents misstated, through information supplied by a magazine consultant, the number of magazines that have failed since 1988. A recent recalculation of figures from the Standard Rate and Data Service, a magazine reference guide, indicated that there were 225 new magazines and 119 that ceased publication.

LEAD: Unlike most cities, Los Angeles does little to encourage the unexpected chance encounter. Geography and traffic work against ordinary social interaction. And so the notion of the gathering spot, the watering hole, is almost unknown in a city where meeting a friend for drinks often begins with a 45-minute drive and ends with an $18 parking ticket.

LEAD: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts yesterday urged the 253 graduates at the 155th commencement of Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., to take responsibility for the future, emphasized the importance of preserving the environment and encouraged his audience to shape the future through public office.

LEAD: An air fare listing in the Travel Watch column on page 21 of the Travel section today includes erroneous entries for the New York-Chicago route. Pan Am's lowest restricted round-trip fare for the route is $250; its lowest unrestricted fare for the same route is $533. American, Continental, Northwest, TWA, United and USAir also offer the $250 fare.

LEAD: Who's No. 1 on the charts? The answer isn't just Madonna, who has the top single in the ''Hot 100'' chart of the May 19 issue of Billboard magazine. Or Sinead O'Connor, with the top album. It's also Z. Z. Top and Midnight Oil and Johnny Gill and M. C. Hammer and Kid 'n' Play and Clint Black and Kitaro and the Gipsy Kings and Carman and the Mississippi Mass Choir and Ana Gabriel and the duo of Rod Stewart and Ronald Isley.
LEAD: I did not read Seymour Hersh's piece beyond the point where he referred to Arthur Liman's speculation that a Reagan impeachment would have destroyed a chance for arms control with Russia.
LEAD: IT'S not just a hit. It's more like a home run.

LEAD: Many of the top-ranked stars on the international scene are used to playing against each other but have never played as partners. That situation was remedied for some earlier this month at the World Individual, hosted by Omar Sharif at the Showboat Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City.

LEAD: IT'S 3:30 IN THE MORNING AT BRADLEY'S, THE GREENWICH Village restaurant and jazz club. The dark, oak-paneled room is filled, mostly with young musicians who have dropped in after their jobs. The pianist John Hicks and the bassist Walter Booker, both well-known veterans of the New York club scene, are laying down a surging rhythm under the trumpet of Roy Hargrove, which is tearing its way through an up-tempo blues.

LEAD: THE seven members of the Enamel Guild of New Jersey decided to share the secrets of their ancient craft in the show window and display area of the First Mountain Crafters Gallery here. ''People just don't understand how it's done,'' said Katharine Wood of Princeton, a guild member.

LEAD: Dave Winfield, Devon White, Dante Bichette and Wally Joyner each hit a home run today, powering the California Angels past Toronto, 11-9, and sending the Blue Jays to their fifth consecutive loss.
LEAD: A Shiite Muslim militia today offered to return to Israel the remains of at least two Israeli soldiers if Israel agreed to release several hundred Arab prisoners held in southern Lebanon.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I have just returned from Poland where I met with many of its leading economists and politicians. From the vantage point of the United States, it may look like that country's commitment to a quick transition to a market economy, which some call the ''big bang,'' is universal. But my discussion with economists and politicans in Warsaw, revealed that some

LEAD: WHEN Beth and Timothy Dennis went house hunting on Long Island three years ago, about a year after their marriage, they thought their biggest challenge would be scraping together the down payment and making sure their salaries covered monthly mortgage and tax bills.

LEAD: W. Daniel Hillis is searching for the elusive teraflop. He is competing with scientists at Intel Scientific Computers in Beaverton, Ore., and to a lesser extent, Cray Research Inc. of Minneapolis. Mr. Hillis is the 34-year-old creator of the Connection Machine, a futuristic supercomputer that he believes will be the basis for the first teraflop computer.
LEAD: LARGE-BLADED ceiling fans are more economical to operate than air-conditioners and can add to comfort and energy savings the year round.

LEAD: On the walls of Merrill Stenbeck's Manhattan kitchen are whimsical Palissy-style plates with serpents crawling across the surface. ''They're supposed to scare you out of your wits when you sneak into the kitchen for a midnight snack,'' says Merrill Stenbeck, co-owner of Valley House Antiques, a shop in Locust Valley, L
LEAD: THE PARTIES
LEAD: MARKERS By Sidney Zion. 426 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $19.95.
LEAD: Afloat With Dolphins

LEAD: Momentum is a mysterious factor, bringing with it an aura of invincibility while it lasts, but liable to plummet back to earth at any moment. After the 10th round of the Watson, Farley and Williams International Tournament in London, which ended May 3, Patrick Wolff of the United States had won 8 points and it looked as though his steamroller would never stop.

LEAD: The good days are gone now. When they vanished last season, Mike Pagliarulo hoped he could forget them quickly, but now, some 10 months after the Yankees casually traded him away, he still has the memories.

LEAD: THE MONITOR (RIGHT) IS 14 feet high. The keyboard (above) is 25 feet long. The floppy disk is six feet on a side. In an era in which the desktop computer stands as a monument to miniaturization, the walk-through computer exhibit being installed at the Computer Museum in Boston is iconoclastic in its dimensions, if more conventionally educational in its purpose.

LEAD: Kristen Rei Nordlie, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter G. Nordlie of Vienna, Va., and John Bleecker Leggett, a son of John W. Leggett of Napa, Calif., and Mary Lee Leggett of New York, were married yesterday by the Rev. James Carver at the Vale Methodist Church in Oakton, Va.

LEAD: Allison B. Farber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Farber of New York, and Peter C. Cheston, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Cheston of Bethesda, Md., and London, were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at Union Theological Seminary.

LEAD: Have the supporters of the museum considered other alternatives to the project? Surely the victims and survivors of the Holocaust deserve nothing less than a legacy that combines remembrance, regeneration and reform. Why not establish memorial institutes dedicated to research into the physical, political and economic ills afflicting societies?
LEAD: LONDON

LEAD: AT THE CHRIS BROWNLIE AIDS hospice in Los Angeles, Maria Cruz has brought soup she made for her 32-year-old son, Jose, who can no longer eat. He lies in bed curled toward the wall, a spindle of a man, nearly blind now. It is black bean soup and, untouched, it has grown cold on the tray beside him.
LEAD: THE latest Asian cuisine to find a welcome in downtown New Haven is Korean, and judging by the crowds flowing in and out of the large dining room of Seoul, this was overdue.

LEAD: When Delah McKay found herself out of work last year, she went back to her first love: designing. She whipped up a black velvet jacket reversing to an ocelot print and showed it to boutiques in the New York area. Tallulah, in Woodbury, L.I., took six, and Asena in Manhattan took four. Both shops sold out in the first week and immediately reordered.

LEAD: Marlon Brando's son Christian was ordered held without bail Friday after he pleaded not guilty to a charge of first-degree murder in the shooting death of his sister's boyfriend on the actor's estate Wednesday night. Judge Rosemary Shumsky of Municipal Court denied a plea from the defendant's lawyers that a bail hearing be held immediately.

LEAD: Senate 1. AIDS Relief: Vote on an amendment to a bill authorizing up to $2.9 billion over five years to help cities and states that have been hardest hit by the AIDS epidemic. The amendment would have allowed small states with few AIDS cases to use their allocation to help victims of other serious chronic illnesses.

LEAD: If we accept the fact that James Stevenson is not a conglomerate, the question remains, how can one man write and illustrate as many as half a dozen picture books a year - three this season - (plus illustrating one or two for other authors) while regularly turning out New Yorker cartoons, essays and covers?

LEAD: The interest in New Jersey place names (Letters to the New Jersey Editor, April 15) reminds me that several years ago I wrote to a gentleman in London asking if I could buy or exchange a book he had bought at auction that I wanted. He responded that he did not approve of allowing British treasures to fall into the hands of foreigners.

LEAD: Patricia McVey Anastasia, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McVey of Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Louis A. Perez, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Perez, at St. Mary's Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Alcorn, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Ashton, Balanchine, de Mille, Taylor, Tudor are all major names in 20th-century choreography and all were represented on American Ballet Theater's matinee and evening programs Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

LEAD: ON APRIL 8, I PUT IN A CALL TO BUDAPEST and got the news: the Alliance of Free Democrats had finished second in Hungary's parliamentary elections. My interest in the outcome was both personal and professional. For the last six months I had helped advise that lively, upstart party of former dissidents through Hungary's first free election campaign in 43 years.
LEAD: THE DEVIL, LONG lingering in the details of language, now stalks the corridors of the Pentagon.

LEAD: BEFORE the performance of George Bernard Shaw's ''Pygmalion'' begins at the Yale Repertory Theater, one can read about the misanthropic sculptor whose statue came ''miraculously alive'' upon being kissed. The gist of the tale is spelled out right on the curtain.

LEAD: Business has grown tremendously at the Sleep Disorders Center at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, which may help explain why the center's director, Dr. Neil B. Kavey, is himself trying to get by on six or six and a half hours a night. Like other researchers in this growing field, Dr.
LEAD: Dave Winfield, like many other fading stars who refuse to accept a role-playing position, was upsetting the chemistry of the team.

LEAD: IN 1700, Louis XIV of France observed his grandson's accession to the Spanish throne with satisfaction: ''the Pyrenees have ceased to exist,'' he boasted. Luckily for those who crave the satisfactions of great massifs, the Sun King's edict left undisturbed this soaring frontier dividing France from the Iberian peninsula.

LEAD: For those who relish the thought of dropping in on a Senate debate to observe a bit of history in the making, Washington holds a year-round fascination. But quite apart from the heady whiff of power and the abundance of museums and historic sites, there is nothing quite like springtime in the nation's capital.

LEAD: For those of us spending the summer at home, the public library has become a kind of clubhouse. We 12-year-olds haunt the corridors, carrying staggering armloads of books, acknowledging one another grimly as we pass. The building has no air conditioner, and we are sweating under our labors, but somehow we feel purposeful here in this small suburban branch library, where the children's librarian occasionally looks up at us from her heat stupor, nodding in approval.

LEAD: LAURENCE GILGORE contemplated the intricate music score spread out before him on the conference table in the Stamford Chamber Orchestra's offices, calmly turning pages and drawing on a steady stream of cigarettes. In two days, he would conduct the premiere of the piece. Now it was time for rehearsal, and the composer, from Latvia, was downstairs awaiting Mr.

LEAD: Tax on Selling Fixtures Question: After more than six years of litigation with the owners of the loft where we live, my husband and I are close to a settlement on the sale of the fixtures and improvements we've made over the years. They have offered to buy them in exchange for our vacating the space.

LEAD: SUMMER is still a month away, but Hampton trendsetters are making a beeline to Basilico Restaurant. Everyone who is anyone has already made the trek. Old Southamptonites, looking like they just stepped out of a Ralph Lauren advertisement, rub shoulders with the straight-from-SoHo set decked out in the latest gear.

LEAD: When the Russian Nobility Association in America held its annual Easter Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on May 11, vestiges of imperial Russia were everywhere. There were a good many Romanovs, titles, rows of medals, colorful sashes and men wearing white gloves to dance. There were a ballet divertissement on Russian fairy tales, a dance orchestra and, late in the evening, a balalaika ensemble that inspired some high-spirited Cossack dancing.
LEAD: HOW do you teach the importance of health to young children? By entertaining them, said Kaiser Permanente, the nation's oldest and largest health maintenance organization.

LEAD: The site of the New York World's Fair, internationally famous for its 1939-40 ''World of Tomorrow'' exhibit, is less well known for an equally fascinating 1965 display of what may be the world's largest scale model - 9,335 square feet depicting almost every building in New York City. This mammoth model, containing 865,000 tiny structures built to a scale of 1 inch to 100 feet, has been updated for the first time in 16 years with 125 scale models representing major projects that have gone up since 1974, such as Battery Park

LEAD: Caroline Young, a daughter of Alexandra K. Self of New York and Walter Lee Young of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gerard J. Murray, a son of Constance B. Murray of New York and the late Peter D. Murray. The Rev. Paul McCarren officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New

LEAD: After signing a 10-year contract with the Yankees in 1981, Dave Winfield had a few productive and successful seasons. He challenged the leaders in many statistical categories and was a fixture in the mediocre Yankee teams of the 1980's.

LEAD: This is not an age with any consensus about style: for all that certain ideologues may claim otherwise, the 90's are starting out to be as eclectic as the 80's. There is still plenty of post-modernism, there is still plenty of late-modernism, and there is still every possible thing in between. But one thing is coming to stand out, and it is less a style than a sense that architecture is going to be asking less of us, whatever form it takes.

LEAD: Kristen Bouvier Peterson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Peterson 3d of Bernardsville, N.J., was married there yesterday at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church to William Brace Krag Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Krag of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Frederick Stephen Baldwin officiated.
LEAD: TO THE BIRDHOUSE By Cathleen Schine. 273 pp. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There is nothing like watching from the deck of a ship as a longed-for destination takes shape on the horison and then draws steadily closer. Lights twinkle, the harbor beckons, the anticipation heightens. The allure of port cities, languorous or bustling, remains undiminished from the days when ships came in under sail.
LEAD: THE stage was set for the start of construction of King's Court, a development of 20 town houses here in Camden County.

LEAD: When historic district designation comes to a neighborhood, some developers run the other way in fear of the restrictions imposed by the protective recognition. But the builder of a condominium project now under way in Brooklyn was not deterred when the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission included in the Clinton

LEAD: To the Editor: In addition to the people mentioned by Judith Shulevitz as habitues of the Cafe des Westens in pre-World War I Berlin (Travel, Feb. 25), there comes to mind the English poet Rupert Brooke, who was quite aware of such Post Impressionists as Franz Marc, Kokoschka and Kandinsky.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-18

LEAD: CAPTAIN SIR RICHARD FRANCIS BURTON The Secret Agent Who Made the Pilgrimage to Mecca, Discovered the Kama Sutra, and Brought the Arabian Nights to the West. By Edward Rice. 522 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $35.

LEAD: As prices rise for examples of the rarest United States coins - an Augustus Humbert $20-gold piece sold for $1.35 million last year - a United States silver dollar with a strange story is among the stars of high-priced coins.

LEAD: Groups of black men attacked white and Hispanic people early yesterday in two incidents that the police said were motivated in part by anger over the Mondello verdict. Both assaults were classified as bias crimes, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Tina Mohrmann.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Think of certain cities and you see the flash and shapely flow of water. No one would have trouble identifying them solely by the configuration of buildings on the banks of their rivers - the Thames, the Seine, the Danube, the Charles, the Hudson and, recently made familiar to us, the Vltava (crossed magnificently by Prague's Charles Bridge, where until last year defiant young folk singers purveyed forbidden
LEAD: You won't find too many professional athletes like Dennis Rodman of the Detroit Pistons, in any size, of any color, in any place, at any time, in any sport.

LEAD: The right to free speech clashed with Christianideals of ''responsible freedom'' at Wheaton College last week as nine students were disciplined for pieces printed in a student-run alternative newspaper.
LEAD: The growing environmental awareness of the past few years has brought with it the realization that we can no longer continue to be a throwaway society.

LEAD: President Lee Teng-hui said today that he would revoke his Government's declaration of a ''Communist rebellion'' on the Chinese mainland, clearing the way for constitutional rule here and moving a step closer to formal acknowledgment of the Communist Party's 40-year control over the mainland.

LEAD: The jury that acquitted Keith Mondello in the racial murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins did so because prosecutors were unable to prove that Mr. Mondello knew a tense racial confrontation would end in the 16-year-old's death, a member of the panel said yesterday.

LEAD: St. Patrick's Cathedral was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Marian Elizabeth Starr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Starr of San Francisco, and Arthur Edward Imperatore Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Imperatore of Fort Lee, N.J., and New York. Bishop Mark J. Hurley, a Vatican consultor, and the Rev.

LEAD: Phyllis Rose, the biographer, essayist and literary critic, and Laurent de Brunhoff, the children's author and illustrator best known for the Babar books, were married yesterday at the New York home of Wendy Gimbel and Douglas Small Liebhafsky. The ceremony was performed by Judge Pierre N. Leval of Federal District Court in

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about how Congress works misstated the profit that Tony Coelho, a former Representative from California, made in a junk-bond transaction.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FROM the Hudson to the Sound; from historic Sunnyside in Tarrytown to Playland amusement park in Rye, attracting tourists to take part in all that Westchester County has to offer has become a serious business.

LEAD: There are still some people around who truly believe that such words as ''dear'' and ''darling'' used in greetings and introductions indicate an intimate relationship, or at least a close friendship with the man or woman in question. Nothing could be further from the truth. What it actually indicates in most cases is that the greeter or introducer has totally forgotten your name.

LEAD: With the proliferation of chamber music in the United States in recent decades, all manner of oddly configured groups have arisen, often ephemerally. A trio consisting of a soprano, a flutist and a harpist might seem at best a casual alignment, born for a single occasion and then evaporating like dew.

LEAD: Jonna L. Godley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Godley Jr. of Frenchtown, N.J., and Dr. Keith Elliot Scharf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Scharf of Guilford, Conn., and New York, were married yesterday at the United Nations Chapel in New York. The Rev. Vernon Nichols, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: After failing three times in the last two months to retake a strategic Red Sea port, and losing more than 30,000 soldiers either killed, wounded or captured, the military Government of Ethiopia is in imminent danger of collapse, Western diplomats say.

LEAD: ''I have a feeling that the whole country slept through the 80's. We were all nodding off in front of the TV.'' On a recent morning in his home in New York City's East Village, the composer Philip Glass seemed anything but sleepy. Speaking briskly, he was describing the climate of ''do-nothing conservatism'' that, he said, caused him to create ''Hydrogen Jukebox,'' his new chamber opera based on poems by Allen
LEAD: A leading cocaine exporter for Colombia's top drug trafficking organization was convicted in a Federal court today on two counts of drug conspiracy.

LEAD: Sagging art market? Not when Ryoei Saito is around. Shopping at Christie's and Sotheby's last week, the Japanese industrialist paid the highest and the second-highest prices ever paid for a work of art at auction. First was Vincent van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' $82.5 million, on Tuesday. Next was Pierre Auguste Renoir's cafe scene ''At the Moulin de la Galette,'' $78.1 million, on Thursday.

LEAD: I'LL TAKE IT, by Paul Rudnick. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Supposedly in search of the glories of autumn, the Esker sisters go on a factory outlet shopping spree in New England, ending their adventure by robbing L. L. Bean. The novel ''may be morally iffy, but it is great fun,'' Susan Isaacs said here last year.

LEAD: The P. T. Barnum of the avant-garde, Robert Wilson began his career in theater in the late 60's with a war on language. In silent epics like ''Deathman Glance'' he ignored it. In masterpieces like ''Einstein on the Beach'' he deconstructed it. Now this sworn enemy of speech is rehearsing Shakespeare's ''King Lear,'' one of the greatest arrays of words we have.

LEAD: Representative Newt Gingrich's vision of the conservative future came to Sprayberry's Barbecue here today. Satellite trucks rolled up in the parking lot, Mr. Gingrich took his spot before the cameras, and a national teleconference began, grandly aimed at inaugurating a ''citizens opportunity movement.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: LONG ISLAND Congressional races are shaping up this year not only as confrontations between Republicans and Democrats but also between what is being called a new alignment in American politics - incumbents and nonincumbents.

LEAD: The Egyptian Government said today that in an effort to ease regional tension centering on Iraq, Egypt has secured an assurance from Israel that it will not launch a first strike against any Arab country.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: FISH EYES A Book You Can Count On. Written and illustrated by Lois Ehlert. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

LEAD: The draft lottery, the annual game the National Basketball Association plays to give the weaker teams a chance to get better, will be held today at the Equitable Center in Manhattan. At stake will be the order of draft selection for the 11 teams that failed to make the playoffs.

LEAD: Melanie S. Kelton, a medical student, and David H. Landau, an associate at the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, were married last evening at the Hotel Inter-Continental in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner and Cantor Howard Nevison officiated.

LEAD: As a former concentration-camp inmate, I agree with Lucy S. Dawidowicz that the memorial should be one of ''compelling austerity.'' I would urge those in charge to show their respect to those who perished by using as examples such memorials as Yad Vashem in Israel, the Memorial of the Unknown Jewish Martyr in Paris and the Vietnam Memorial in Washington.

LEAD: What must be conceded about ''The Passionate Eye: Impressionist and Other Master Paintings From the E. G. Buhrle Collection,'' at the National Gallery of Art through July 15, is that it includes 85 works of quality and consistency.

LEAD: WHAT was previously the Squibb Gallery has become the Gallery at Bristol-Myers Squibb. Titles must expand along with capitalism, it seems. Still, there is much to be grateful for: this could have been the Gallery at Bristol-Myers Beech-Nut Life Savers Squibb if the pharmaceutical company had not sold its gum and candy interests, in 1981.

LEAD: I HAVE had occasion to ride along the Ocean Parkway from Meadowbrook to Captree almost every week in the last few months. This is a ride I always enjoy, both as a driver and as a passenger. It soothes and pacifies to see the sky meet the ocean and the bay. The variety of colors and shapes, the chance of seeing wildlife, the absence of commercialism and the absence of people are among the attractions.

LEAD: Karen E. Helle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Helle of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church to David S. Nemiah, a son of Mrs. William Geist of Rehoboth Beach, Del., and Dr. John C. Nemiah of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ANOTHER ROSY DUSK SETTLES OVER THE SET IN Tangier, and Bernardo Bertolucci is up to his usual tricks. In the glow of the ancient chalky walls, under a giant eucalyptus tree, a man and woman bend close, so absorbed in each other they seem unaware of the movie crew preparing to capture a scene before darkness swallows the moment.

LEAD: Tennis Graf and Seles Reach Title Match: The two hottest players in women's tennis will meet for the German Open championship in West Berlin today. In yesterday's semifinals, top-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany beat Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, 6-4, 6-2, and second-seeded Monica Seles of Yugoslavia beat Sandra Cecchini of Italy, 6-1, 6-3.(AP)

LEAD: The advent of the readily portable video camera and the extraordinary popularity of the new ABC television program, ''America's Funniest Home Videos,'' combine to raise the question: what is happening to the ways we perceive the world as we move in and through it?

LEAD: A Federal district judge has rejected the Bush Administration's attempt to derail a record $5.5 million settlement of a lawsuit against the Unocal Corporation for its pollution of San Francisco Bay.

LEAD: Lisa A. Bippart and Timothy M. Ghriskey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Williamson Ghriskey of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Charles Bippart of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. George Chorba performed a combined Presbyterian and Episcopalian ceremony.

LEAD: American and Soviet officials announced major progress today toward a treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons. They also said they had concluded an agreement to end their chemical-weapons production and sharply reduce their chemical stocks.

LEAD: THE Hamakua Sugar Company, one of Hawaii's biggest sugar companies, is hoping to sell 8,000 acres - almost all of it zoned for agriculture - to help pay off its debts. It will begin by offering 5,000 acres at two auctions here, on June 28 and Aug. 16, at which it expects to raise $65 million.

LEAD: As to Henry Kissinger's fear that a national Holocaust museum might constitute ''too high a profile'' for American Jews, I say we must remember that the lessons to be learned from Hitler's reign of terror are not about guilt or apology or remorse but about understanding that this must never again happen to any group of people anywhere, ever.
LEAD: ''WE don't try to make money on amenities,'' said Eric Eicher, president of Sabal Park, a big office campus outside Tampa, Florida, ''but in the long run, they pay for themselves.''

LEAD: THE softening of the real estate market after a decade of dizzying growth has changed the plans and prospects of developers, businesses, institutions and even governments. Yet a look backward to earlier hard times shows that many troubled projects have managed to survive and prosper.

LEAD: As a group of black demonstrators marched by, chanting ''boycott'' and ''freedom fighters,'' a multiracial group of religious leaders held a prayer meeting ''to heal New York'' yesterday in the troubled Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In April last year, Howard Goldsmith bought station WSBR-AM in Boca Raton, Fla. Its ''oldies'' format had been losing money. Because Boca Raton is popular with wealthy retirees, Mr. Goldsmith immediately changed the station's format to all-business. This year, he said, the station will make a profit.
LEAD: THE ROAD TO MEMPHIS By Mildred D. Taylor. 304 pp. New York: Dial Books. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

LEAD: PRACTICALITIES: Marguerite Duras Speaks to Jerome Beaujour. By Marguerite Duras. (Grove Weidenfeld, $15.95.) Marguerite Duras is probably best known in this country for her autobiographical novel ''The Lover'' and her script for Alain Resnais's film ''Hiroshima Mon Amour.'' Readers will recognize the fragmented, elliptical style of these works in ''Practicalities,'' a collection of transcribed conversations with her friend Jerome Beaujour.

LEAD: Dr. Alison Reams Baldock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lawrence Baldock of Springtown, Pa., was married yesterday at the Old Moravian Chapel in Bethlehem, Pa., to Dr. Richard Albert Rockar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Andrew Rockar of Cabot, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Douglas W. Caldwell officiated, assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: Kristin Wishart Ludington, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ludington of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Wayne Fritz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Fritz of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: Gov. Jim Florio and other Roman Catholic public officials in southern New Jersey who disagree with the church's teaching on abortion will not be allowed to speak at church events under a policy announced by the Diocese of Camden.

LEAD: The National Football League owners will gather in Dallas on Wednesday and Thursday to address a bushel of items. The agenda includes awarding Super Bowl XXVIII in 1994 to either Atlanta, New Orleans, Tampa, Fla., or Miami; the introduction of the league's new drug advisers, Dr. John Lombardo (steroids) and Dr.

LEAD: NOT so long ago, an author wrote a novel and a publisher paid for it. Today, in the quest for big-name authors and bigger profits, the order has reversed. Publishers are now increasingly using multimillion-dollar advances to woo best-selling novelists into signing contracts, sometimes without even a glimmer of what they will be writing about.
LEAD: THE MOUSE RAP By Walter Dean Myers. 186 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

LEAD: Michelle Pfeiffer slithered and sang on a piano and walked away with THE FABULOUS BAKER BOYS (1989, I.V.E., $89.98), Steve Kloves's stylish first film, to be released this week. But the movie owes a good share of its sophisticated charm to strong, generous performances by its male stars, updating a theme as old as Cain and Abel - only here it's nonviolent and has music.

LEAD: A little over a century ago, according to a favored and probably apocryphal story here, the territorial government gave the citizens of this city a choice between a new college and a prison. They chose the prison because they didn't like the kind of people attracted to a college.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A CRITIC wrote of Philip II of Spain, who raised political ambition to high art, ''no experience of the failure of his policy could shake his belief in its essential excellence.''

LEAD: THE man who has been credited by the artistic community with helping to convert New Jersey from a cultural backwater into a thriving arts center in less than a decade has come to Washington to tackle an equally formidable task: defending the embattled National Endowment for the Arts.
LEAD: THUNDER CAKE Written and illustrated by Patricia Polacco. Unpaged. New York: Philomel Books. $14.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

LEAD: The seasonings - dill, coriander, cinnamon and turmeric - in this lamb and rice dish, as well as the yogurt, are what turn an otherwise prosaic recipe into something infinitely more interesting than a traditional preparation.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

LEAD: Felix Lazo's harvest of coca leaves lay on the floor of his cinder-block house, unsold because actions against drug dealers and processing laboratories in Bolivia and elsewhere have destroyed the market for the raw material of cocaine.
